**Type C Water Softeners**

INTERNATIONAL Type C Water Softeners are suitable for continuous long run regeneration of high softening rates. High rate performance is made possible by the use of CRYSTALITE, a high speed, high capacity zeolite and an exclusive International Filter Co. product.

Many improvements in the Type C Softener have been desired for years but haven't actually been attained before in zeolite water softeners. Only a general comparison of zeolites will be made here; for the purpose of this bulletin is to describe and illustrate Type C softeners so that their application to water supply conditions may be better understood.

**Zeolite**

Zeolite is a term that has come to be applied to all base exchange silicates used in water softening. All such substances are not if the mineralogical definition is strictly applied.

Among the "zeolites" that have been used are those made from various natural clays and sands, as well as from artificial mixtures of known fused and precipitated ingredients. More recent advances in the art are concerned with a zeolite made from concentrated solutions. The proper mixture of the solution forms a gel which dries to a flint-like state, in which form the particles are sufficiently hard to scratch glass.

**Control of Properties**

One of the most important in manufacturing the gel type of zeolite is the possibility of controlling the size, weight and capacity of the finished product. Size of zeolite particles, together with weight—that is, its effective weight in water—is most important for it is by these factors that the zeolite becomes practical in its appearance.

Compared to greensand, the particles of which are very small, the grains of CRYSTALITE are giants. Were it not for the fact that usually several of the tiny greensand grains are held together as one by a foreign clay or cement-like binder, they could hardly be used. When separated by wear or use, the pores would be too small to be retained by any material except the binder.

Greensand is used in making this comparison because no control of size can be brought to bear in its preparation. It is necessary to take it as it comes. The same that can be done to separate each out the single small nodules will save the larger usable grains. Whether these larger particles will hold together for any length of time is a question. Certainly they do not appear with us and this fact accounts for the increased pressure losses experienced by all users of greensand softeners.

As lower backwash rates become necessary in order that the fine material may be retained in the apparatus serious packing with consequent high pressure loss occurs. While the retained fine material continues to soften some water, it accomplishes this at a much increased cost. This packed condition which holds about unequal contact between hard water and greensand explains the reason for short capacity runs. The usual results of this condition are the necessity for more frequent regeneration, higher rates of wash water, greater waste of wash water and, of course, greater pumping costs to overcome the drop in pressure.

The average size of CRYSTALITE grains is much greater than that of greensand and the CRYSTALITE grain is not made up of many smaller granules which tend to separate with use. CRYSTALITE grains are sharp cornered and irregular in shape and this fact alone lessens the chance of CRYSTALITE to pack to such a great extent that the pressure loses through a bed of CRYSTALITE are only a fraction of those through a bed of greensand of the same volume and under similar conditions. It is obvious, therefore, that high softening rates are possible with CRYSTALITE while the rates for greensand must be greatly limited.

---

**FOREWORD**

CRYSTALITE is a zeolite possessing those properties which enable it to meet the practical requirements of supplying zero hardness water with greater efficiency than has been attained heretofore. Its development is an interesting record, but telling the story is hardly possible outside the bounds of a purely technical treatise. For those who are interested in this phase of the subject a separate special treatise prepared by our technical staff will be sent upon request.
Why Greensand Came Into Use

Greensand came into general use because of its then comparatively rapid softening activity and quick regeneration. While possessing these characteristics, it has at the same time proved to be limited in total capacity, requiring a greater amount of water per bed; several regenerations are required in order that the apparatus may be of reasonable size and cost.

Zeolites that preceded greensand were abandoned largely because of their much slower softening activity, not because they were inferior, as several of them were of much greater total capacity than greensand. Also, the flexibility of these early zeolites was beyond question, for there are notable cases of where they have operated successfully for periods of over ten years time.

The Type-C Solenizer is now in use frankly and with due regard for all points including VER-DITE, the superior greensand used for over five years by the International Filter Co. The main purpose is to make available the advantages in zeolite softeners, to have the superior performance of CRYSTALITE, and its greater total capacity, a decided advance. These points are dealt with in the following pages.

Advantages of Greater Capacity

Although the depth of the zeolite bed in the apparatus may be varied somewhat, this dimension of the bed is not varied so much as the cross-sectional area. Usually the sectional area is circular because of the uniform softening action. Although many are operated in vertical position, some are placed in a horizontal position solely to obtain greater area in a single unit. In this position the shape of the cross-section is of course, more nearly rectangular.

It is the area that must vary in proportion to the flow required in gallons per hour. For example, a bed of 500 square feet area will require twice the area of one 250 gallons per hour, etc. The unit of area, therefore, as in filter practice, becomes the unit by which the size of a water softener is reckoned, and the size of area of the bed is fixed. A bed of greensand of standard depth and one square foot in area has a capacity of about 10,000 grains of hardness calculated as calcium carbonate. This means simply that it can soften 500 gallons of 20 grains hardness, or 250 gallons of 40 grains, each multiplied by the hardness in grains, will equal 10,000 grains—total of softening work. Each time this amount of work is done, the bed must be regenerated—a process requiring (1) a cleaning wash, (2) a contact with brine, and (3) a fresh water wash to expel the waste products of regeneration. Altogether, a square foot column of greensand consumes 50 to 60 gallons of water in each cycle of regeneration. The amount of water wasted is 10 to 12 percent of the capacity (500 gallons) with water of 20 grains hardness, and this percentage becomes higher as the hardness increases because the capacity of the bed reduces in the same proportion as the hardness increases and vice versa, while the amount of water required for regenerating is about constant. This item of waste water and regenerating costs the same amount of labor and is an important consideration especially with the harder waters.

CRYSTALITE with its much greater total capacity reduces this item of cost fully 50% and the reason is obvious. The capacity of one square foot bed of CRYSTALITE of usual depth is twice that of greensand, or 20,000 grains, which is equal to 1000 gallons of water of 20 grains hardness.

Since the bed of CRYSTALITE regenerates with substantially the same amount of waste water, namely 50 to 60 gallons, the waste is only 5 to 6 percent. Another thing, the frequency of attention for regeneration is reduced to half that necessary for greensand.

When water itself is an item of cost, and it usually is even when pumped from a nearby free supply, the Type-C Solenizer cuts this cost item in half.

The Advantages of Greater Speed of Activity

Zeolites that preceded greensand were capable of handling water of 20 grains hardness at only slow rates of flow. The usual flow per square foot of area was about 85 gallons per hour. With greensand, this increased to about 160 gallons per hour and because of this quite radical increase one can readily reconcile the term "rapid rate" which came to be applied to greensand softeners.
Now because of a similar increase, CRYSTALITE softeners are termed "super-rapid," the rate per unit of area having been increased 100% over that of greensand to deliver tons per hour of 30 grain water.

CRYSTALITE softeners offer some great greensand softeners; therefore, possess twice the capacity per regeneration and 100% greater flexibility. Or to make the more practical comparison, CRYSTALITE softeners of the same capacity per regeneration as greensand softeners use half the area and thus require less space for installation and are of equal flexibility in flow rate.

Also, because of the lesser area, the amount of water wasted per regeneration is 50% of that of the greensand softener.

Salt Consumption and Economy

The usual rating given to CRYSTALITE is 1000 grams of exchange capacity for each half pound of salt consumed. By varying the amount of salt used for regeneration, the capacity total in gallons may be varied considerably at will. This variation can cover a range of nearly 200% with the salt rate varying from .4 to .7 of a pound per thousand gallons.

Thus it is possible to select a salt rate which will give a capacity fitting the soft water requirements of any shift or day. Also the selection of salt rate makes possible a constant supply of soft water regardless of the small changes in hardness of the raw water.

Effective Size and Weight

The weight of a zeolite may be greatly misleading. To state that greensand weighs 90 pounds per cubic foot while CRYSTALITE weighs but 50 pounds per cubic foot sounds discouraging for the latter. The effective size of greensand, however, is another subject entirely. While greensand is actually heavier on the scales than an equal volume of CRYSTALITE, the importance of effective size and relative weight in water softening cannot be overlooked. The same is true of sands selected for filtration work—many are rejected because the grains are too small to measure up to the effectiveness required.

It must be kept in mind that in a slowly rising column of water, very small particles of even a very heavy substance will tend to lift while larger particles of the same substance will tend to settle. This is because the very tiny particle has more surface for its bulk and weight than a larger particle of the same substance; the surface friction of the passing water on the green sand is the case of smaller particle, its tendency to move along becomes greater as the size of the particle diminishes.

Greensand has an effective size of 0.25 millimeters, and when many of the grains break up into the minute particles of which they are composed, the effective size becomes so reduced that loss on back washing must occur; or if the wash rate is reduced to prevent this loss, then the bed becomes mud-like and almost impervious to the passage of water.

CRYSTALITE has an effective size of 0.45 or nearly double that of greensand. And while this difference is partially offset by the lesser dry weight of CRYSTALITE, the result is an effective weight in water slightly greater for CRYSTALITE than for the greensand grains of proper size.

This means that at the same washing and cleaning rates, CRYSTALITE is less tendency to bleed CRYSTALITE with the same water than is the case with greensand. Further, it is possible to greatly reduce this danger by increasing the effective size of CRYSTALITE, a matter entirely beyond the control of man in the case of the natural greensand.

Effect of Size on Resistance to Flow

It has been pointed out that the effective size of CRYSTALITE is nearly double that of greensand. A crude example will illustrate the effect of size upon the resistance to the passage of water. **The Smaller Sizes**

Vertical softeners of the C Type are built in two styles. The smaller sizes of this type are of our Style P design which applies to those having a diameter of 42 inches or less.

**The Larger Sizes**

All larger sizes ranging in diameter from 48 inches to 108 inches are of our Style S design. Description of these two general styles is given in sufficient detail to serve as a specification.

**The Style P**

Containers for Style P International Softeners are built for working pressures of 100 pounds per square inch. While lighter metal would be used for these Style P sizes for lower working pressures it is not deemed good practice to use it. Deterioration of the containers is mostly from the outside in, and is due to the tendency to apply paint to the paint after the original shop or field coats have worn out. Condensation which forms on all cold metal surfaces subjected to a humid atmosphere together with the exposure to air works havoc with metal. Without proper paint protection, renewal when...
necessary, serious rusting of the outside takes place, thus weakening the metal. For this reason heavier metal than required for ordinary pressures is used and the standard of these International Softeners is for 100 pounds working pressure.

**Style P Container Design**

The design of the Style P container takes into account the comparatively small inside space of these sizes, also the fact that assembly is often handled in the field without our supervision. To facilitate handling and setting them, no pipe underdrain is used, thus avoiding the usual concrete fill for the bottom and saving the time for the setting. Instead, these sizes are provided with heavy steel pipe underdrains containing No. 3 International Tobin Bronze Strainers, the same as used in International filter plants. Spacing of the strainers is six inches center to center and the throat size is \( \frac{3}{4} \) inch diameter.

**Style S Container Design**

The larger sizes of the Style S design are built for a working pressure of 67 pounds per square inch. To save head room, the lower connection of these containers is placed in the side of the shell and made up to the central header of the underdrain consisting of lateral pipe spaced six inches center to center. The laterals carry No. 3 International Tobin Bronze Strainers placed six inches center to center in both directions. After the underdrain is assembled in the shell, the remaining space is filled with concrete and the top cemented over to form a smooth floor for the softener bed. Only the strainers project through the cement from the underdrain to provide the necessary water passages to and from the softener bed.

The upper connection is in the center of the top container head which is provided with the necessary man-holes. Instead of the usual cast concrete immediately under the upper connection, a water stilling baffle is built into the container, requiring no assembly or attention during installation.

**Supports**

Containers of all Type C International Softeners are equipped with heavy cast iron supports at main level floor of proper thickness to carry the weight. Ball type flanges riveted securely to the bottom head prevent tipping and avoid the danger of injuring workmen engaged in setting containers when placed upon loose or jointed supports. The ball flanges rest upon heavy cast floor plate sockets extended sufficiently to give the necessary under clearance.

**Type C Control**

All main operating valves for each Type C International Softener Unit are furnished together with the necessary fittings, arranged in an assembly ready to be mounted on the softener front. Six main operating valves are required for the three simple operations of regeneration. Only two valves are open at a time—one to bring brine in, second—to admit the regenerating salt brine, and third—to wash out the waste products of regeneration.

While the Softener Unit is in service, its two main valves, inlet and outlet, are open, all others being closed. It will be noted that all valves are within easy reach and logically arranged so that operation is readily understood.
Flow Indicator

The control of each Type C Softener Unit is provided with a flow indicator gauge to guide the operator during the regeneration cycle. It is necessary to backwash the filter type softener immediately prior to the following salt brine regeneration. This is a process which is performed best and with most economical use of water, at a certain rate of flow. The Indicator Gauge permits the operator to tell the operator at a glance when the flow is exactly right. Adjustment in flow to the correct indicated wash rate may be made by slight increase or decrease in the wash valve opening.

The same Flow Indicator serves during the re-wash operation—merely opening the rewash waste valve until the gauge registers proper flow for the operation is all that is necessary. The importance of performing this operation accurately alike each time is possible should not be left to the judgment of the operator. No man can look at a stream of water and state the quantity of flow with any degree of accuracy. The International Indicator Gauge completely eliminates the guess work; reduces the regeneration to routine operations which are always handled alike; and brings the resulting performance up to and maintains it at highest efficiency.

Interconnected Loss of Head Gauge and Test Cocks

Each Type C Softener Unit is provided with suitable pressure gauge interconnectors and pressure test cocks so that either inlet or outlet pressures may be observed. The use of one gauge for this double purpose is necessary on the International Softener because the usual difference in pressure between inlet and outlet is too little to be registered by separate gauges or a duplex gauge of ordinary accuracy.

The main purpose of the loss of head gauge is to provide the operator with means for keeping track of the softener bed condition, especially during times of peak loads or during times when the turbidity of the raw water may be higher than ordinarily should be supplied to the softener.

The manifold connections for the loss of head gauge are provided with cocks for drawing samples of raw or soft water for test purposes, and, in all, with the centralized valve system bring every means of control to the front of each softener unit.

Soft Water Meter

The meter supplied with each Type C Softener Unit is a standard make with straight reading register in Imp. Gallons, rate indicator hand, and set-back contact arm and connections for electric signal bell. A differential float type meter is placed on the soft water outlet so that only clean soft water passes through same. This position of the meter avoids set back adjustments for regeneration water which would be necessary if the meter were placed on the inlet side.

Measure of water for backwashing and rewashing is provided for on the Type C Unit through the use of the Flow Indicator Gauge used to control these operations. It is possible, therefore, to keep a constant check at all times on the performance and cost of operating the International Type C Softener.
Salt Storage Brine Tank

The storage tank is several regeneration tanks provided from the International Softener Tank. Although the standard brine tank is made 48 inches in height for convenience in recharging, tanks of any size or shape to better accommodate available space, and of greater storage for salt, can be furnished. For unusual conditions, designed self storage will be drawn up so that purchasers may build their own brine tanks or reservoirs.

In addition to being a storage for salt, the International brine tank is also equipped with a brine solution accumulator and measuring device. Each standard brine tank is fitted with an underdrain or draw-off system located at the entire bottom. This system is overlaid with a layer of 12 to 16 inches filter gravel which supports the bed of salt above. The advantage of this method of construction is in avoiding the use of wooden or concrete boxes which take up space and prevent uneven withdrawal of brine from the salt bed above. Also, more rapid withdrawal of brine is possible with assured obtaining saturated solution and therefore accurate measure of salt used each time.

Salt Handling and Measure

It is not necessary to measure or weigh the salt piled in the brine tank. To assure saturated solution in the draw-off, a layer of salt at least 10 to 12 inches deep must lie upon the layer of gravel at all times. The full charge of salt may form a bed 24 to 30 inches in depth, but should be replaced when used down to the level of the removable cover placed above. Handling the salt for charging the brine tank is therefore a simple matter—a chore to be performed once in a week or ten days depending upon size of equipment.

The normal measure of the salts is secured by drawing out of the tank a given amount of saturated solution for each regeneration. Since saturated solution of brine contains a fixed amount of salt per gallon or other unit of volume, measure of salt is secured volumetrically. This method of measure is not only extremely accurate, but is simple to handle.

A depth gauge and indicator mounted in the brine tank shows the exact number of inches of brine drawn out each time.

Brine Delivery

Delivery of the required amount of brine to the Softener unit undergoing regeneration is usually by hydraulic pump or ejector. The suction of the ejector is connected through the side of the brine tank to the draw-off system. The discharge is connected through a control valve to the ejector inlet, and the discharge of diluted brine is piped from the ejector to the brine inlet valve of the softener control front. Ejectors of generous size are supplied with International equipment systems so that the quantity of brine required for a regeneration may be quickly handled to save time.

When water pressures are too low to operate hydraulically, and the installation is sizeable, motor driven brine pumps may be used instead of ejectors. Such pumps may be started and stopped by remote control electrical devices when distant settings are required. When conditions are understood, we are pleased to submit drawings for most suitable arrangements of equipment required.

Quality of the Soft Water and Test

When the Type C Softener is installed and operated according to the operating instructions, it produces a full capacity of zero hardness water. By zero hardness water, we mean water containing no lime or magnesia that can be detected by the ordinary analytical methods employed in water examination.

The field soap test should not be confused with or considered the equal in accuracy of the analysis performed in the laboratory. It is merely a rough, handy, and quick means of checking end points of softening. The field soap test is arranged for use with the International Softener is arranged for making a quick, simple determination. The soap solution furnished for the test is made to such a standard that when two ounces are required to form a permanent suds in a given amount of water contains 1.0 grain per Imp. Gallon, or 17 parts per million of hardness as Calcium Carbonate.
Each additional drop in securing a permanent result, after the first two have been used, counts as another grain of hardness.

The capacity soft water delivered by the International Softener requires but one drop of this soap solution for the test.

Zero-hardness Water Has Many Important Uses

The Zeolite or base-exchange water softener has a wide range of application in practically every water-consuming industry or institution. The benefits from use of zero-hardness water are of far-reaching and enduring nature. They are actually measured and credited fairly to the softener. These benefits range in value often to the extent of several times the cost, in a year's time. In certain cases, operation with zero-hardness water is so impractical that it becomes almost impossible.

A generally important benefit derived from zero hardness water, is prevention of scale in boilers, heaters, feed pumps, feed pipes and hot water distributing lines. Clean boilers and heaters use less fuel and operate longer without shut-down.

In laundering, as is obvious, water of zero hardness saves large percentages of soaps, alkalies, and other washing supplies, which are factors in cleaning operations. More work and labor is also saved and what is equally important, the zero hardness water assists materially in improving and maintaining quality of work.

For many purposes zero hardness water is one of the prime essentials. Uniformity of quality, color and finish all revert back to the condition of the water used. Uniform water of zero hardness becomes an integral part of the conditions under which all work may have an even start. Although net water saves enormous quantities of supplies, much additional benefit is derived through saving of time and labor, rejects, reruns, and spoils.

Institutions, such as hotels and hospitals, which have many water-consuming departments and extensive plumbing systems, use zero hardness water with advantage all along the line. Hot water equipment and its maintenance are of no small importance, for service must be unfailing.

The laundering of the linens is of special importance. While there is saving of wash-room supplies with the zero hardness water, the life of linens is greatly increased and the cost of replacements reduced from a third to a half of the amount with hard water washing.

Special Industrial Uses for Water of Zero-hardness

1. Feed water for all types of boilers used in stationary steam power plants.
2. Feed water for locomotives, locomotive boilers, crane boilers, steam shovels, boilers, and the like.
3. For cooling steam or ammonia surface condensers.
4. For cooling internal combustion engines, furnace doors and jackets, air and ammonia compressors, transformers, steam turbine bearings, etc.
5. Absorption of ammonia gas for manufacture of aqua ammonia.
6. For preparation of cutting oils.
7. For soap making.
8. For canning, especially peas and beans.
9. For filter-char washing in sugar and syrup industries.
10. For preparation of beverages and certain extracts.
11. For tanning, especially scouring of hides.
12. For wool scouring.
13. For dyeing, bleaching and finishing of all textile fabrics.
14. For automobile body washing.
15. For automobile radiators.
16. For preparing food products and many other purposes.

Soft Water for Municipalities

With a zeolite which lends itself to more economical operation, the application to city water supplies becomes possible. The two principal operating costs are for the salt used to regenerate the zeolite, and for the water used in the regeneration process. The salt used for regeneration may be reduced to as low as one-third pound per 1,000 gallons of zero hardness water per hardness grain to the gallon.

For instance, a water containing 15 Grains per Imp. gallon of hardness CaCO₃ would require 1 pound of salt per 1,000 gallons softened to zero hardness. Bulk salt in car lots ranges in price from $5.00 to $10.00 per ton delivered, depending considerably upon the freight rates.

The softening cost with such water ranges therefore, from $12.50 to $25.00 per million gallons. Further reduction in salt cost may be accomplished by by-passing part of the treated, unsalted water into the soft water lines to increase the hardness from zero to about 3 grains per gallon. With water of 15 grains hardness, as much as one gallon may be by-passed to every five gallons that are softened, thus diluting the hardness of the raw water down to 15 grains in 5 gallons, or 3 grains to one gallon. Incidentally, this reduces the softening cost 20%, bringing the figures for salt per million gallons down to $10.00 to $20.00 depending upon the salt cost.

Water cost for regeneration will vary greatly with the different types of zeolites. Since the pressure of water required per square foot of softener bed area is fairly well fixed, the pressure varies inversely with the total exchange capacity of the zeolite selected. It is this property of Crystalite—namely high total capacity which by inverse ratio results in low regeneration water cost—and the low salt cost that bring Crystalite to a practical possibility for municipal supplies.

While softening plants for this purpose will all of the same general principles of operation, there are different arrangements of equipment possible. Either of two types of equipment, pressure or gravity, may be used, depending upon the nature of the water supply, methods of pumping, storage, etc., and the need for preliminary sedimentation and filtration.

Crystalite may be used in open gravity basins. The softener bed of Crystalite three feet in depth may be operated at a rate of 100 to 150 gpm per minute per square foot of area with a maximum water head of only eleven and a half feet. As with gravity filters, this total head may be partly positive and partly negative in order that the softener bed area may be of the same size as compared to gravity filters, even though they are similar.

Surveys will be made and complete plans for plants of any capacity will be furnished to engineers desiring to install water softening plants as bona fide projects. A nominal charge for handling this work is made with the understanding that if the project is carried out and our equipment is used, this charge will be cancelled.

Complete information involving our broad experience in the design and application of plants of this kind will be gladly furnished without charge at any time.

International Household Softeners using Crystalite assure the home of clean, clear soft water for all domestic purposes. Literature describing these softeners, of which several thousand are now in successful use, will be sent upon request.

Early Methods:
Historians state that there has always been a desire for clean, clear water, at least for drinking purposes. The ancients often went to considerable effort to obtain their water supply from sources of spring water, sometimes at a considerable distance from the town. Rome was supplied with three qualities of water—purest for ceremonial purposes, the next best for the fountains and washing troughs and the very best exclusively for drinking purposes.

Where turbid waters were, or necessary, used for drinking water there is record that porous sand and porous earthenware filters were used by the ancient Egyptians and also by the Japanese. There is also record of clarification of turbid water by means of a porous vessel filled with a vessel to another by the capillary action of porous material, such as a skin of wool.

Slow Sand Filters:
The practical application of filtration to ensure pure water supply dates from about 1800. Records show that in about 1800 slow sand filters were installed in Scotland and that in 1829 one of the London water companies installed slow sand filters at Stepney. The eventual adoption of this system for all of the London water supply, and for many other English cities, was due to the fact that the English system was its use spread throughout Europe.

Slow sand filters are still used to a considerable extent in Europe and also in a number of localities in North America. These filters consist of a number of beds of sand varying in size from one-quarter to one acre, usually rectangular in shape and covered, if the ambient temperature is below thirty degrees. The fine filter bed is superimposed on three or more layers of graded gravel, under which is a simple form of underdrainage, usually with a concrete base provided with suitable piping to control the influent, effluent, etc.

Some waters may be put onto slow sand filters without any preliminary treatment; but in the majority of cases preliminary sedimentation and sometimes sedimentation and coagulation are used to prepare the water for the filters.

With the slow sand filters an immense surface area becomes available to reach the desired results. The rate of filtration should be maintained at about three million gallons per acre per day. In some cases the rate is half and in others twice that figure. As the sand used is of rather small grain size and the filter bed is shallow, the sand itself acts as a strainer, taking out considerable suspended matter. However, with the slow sand filter the surface of the sand bed provides a place for great numbers of organisms to grow and develop. They form an adherent mat that absorbs and holds the finer organic substances in the water. This mat or film (sometimes referred to as the schmutzdecke) is the active part of the bed until it has been clogged. The efficiency of the filter is very low. To ripen the filter bed the slow sand filter is started at about one-third of its usual rate and then increased gradually so that not until three or four weeks is the filter operated at its normal capacity.

Depending upon the diameter of the slow water tank whether it has been given preliminary treatment, the rate of filtration, the maximum loss of head allowable, etc., the slow sand filter will operate when carrying 30,000 to 400,000,000 gallons per acre of filter are before cleaning is necessary.

The slow sand filter is cleaned by scraping and removing from the filter an inch or two of sand from the surface of the bed and then backwashing and either pouring back into the bed immediately or put in the storage bins and replaced after the backwashing (cleaning).

Slow sand filters are limited in use to handling waters of low turbidity and color and where sufficient ground area is available to provide for the immense filter beds and settling basins.

Rapid Sand Filters:
The first rapid sand or "mechanical" filters were built in the United States during the early 1800's. They were initially by the paper industry to solve the problem of clarifying large volumes of water and removing the finer particles of suspended matter that were spoiling their product.

These early filters consisted of cylindrical tanks provided with a simple draining underdrain system, a series of pipes and troughs with water troughs and operating piping. They were not capable of removing the finer or colloidal suspended matter, nor did they depend on removal of bacteria. However, they crudely served their purpose and represented an immense saving for the factory because of savings in first cost and space required.

Rapid sand filters differ from slow sand filters not only in the rate of flow of water through the sand bed—but also in design, construction and operation. The smaller area of the filter bed, consequently less possibility of clogging, requires means for rapid and automatic cleaning. The rate of flow is high to quickly wash the sand gate to the early days of mechanical filters. The high rate of filtration (12,000 gallons per minute per dry yard or even more) necessitates the use of a coagulant and uniform filter sand—as well as the formation of an adherent mat on the sand bed.

When the introduction of chemical coagulants to gather together the finer suspended matter and to make this artificial mat gave the coagulant plants a big up and fed as a solution.

Practically all waters are alkaline and this natural alkalinity, calcium carbonate and magnesium carbonates, precipitate as alum with a resultant heavy white flocculent precipitate of aluminum hydrate. If the water is not naturally alkaline, the natural alkalinity has been neutralized by continuous dilution and refiltration as in swimming pool filter systems—artificial alkalinity is added in the form of soda ash or sodium carbonate or of sal-soda if a preformed alkalinity feeder is used.

The action of the insoluble gelatinous sticky aluminum hydrate can be compared to that of the white egg in clearing coffee. It coalesces all the suspended matter, absorbs the color, and gathers the finer particles into floes that can be readily removed or which are caught on the filter sand being pressed down through the spaces between the grains. The coagulum forms a gelatinous mat on the surface of, and in the
upper part of the filter sand, constituting the real filtering medium.

During coagulation, the originally round or cloudy water undergoes a complete change in appearance; for in place of the murkiness the impurities become coarse grains and flocculent, with the result that they find their way to the bottom. It is then a comparatively simple matter to filter the water.

**Underdrain Systems:**

The underdrain system of a rapid sand filter serves a two-fold purpose—it must be uniformly distributed the water during washing and to collect the filtered water without loss of sand. The underdrain actually consists of the gravel layer and the distributing manifold system.

Aside from supporting the sand bed—the gravel is the principal means of distributing the wash water and many cases of faulty filter operation can be traced to improperly graded, poor quality or not sufficient filter gravel.

To uniformly collect the filtered water—but more important—to supply wash water to the underside of the gravel—is the purpose of the distributing manifold. The systems in common use are:

- A pipe manifold system with bronze "strainers" or orifice nozzles screened into the tops of the holes between the laterals.
- A pipe manifold system, the pipes perforated on the underside in either single or double rows.

The "Wagner Bottom"—distributing pipes with large perforations interspaced by slotted precast concrete blocks.
- Concrete "sand valley" with perforated bronze plate or perforated pipe in bottom of valley.
- "Wheeler Bottom" with balls geometrically placed in pyramid hoppers.
- "Strainers" or orifice nozzles in false metal or concrete bottoms.

**Gravel Layers:**

In order to properly support the filter sand, the gravel must be small enough in the top layer, and to diffuse the wash water—must be fairly large at the lowest layer around or on top of the distributing manifold. Each grading must be of fairly uniform size and practically free from flat pieces. The gradation must be such that the small pebbles from falling through lower layers.

Modern practice calls for as many as five and sometimes three gradations ranging in size from 2½ inches at the bottom to ¼ inch diameter at the top.

**Filter Sand:**

Silica sand, which was the first material used, is still the accepted standard material of today. Crushed stone, crushed marble, charcoal, etc., and screened anthracite coal have also been used—but usually to take care of some special conditions. Porous filter materials are to be avoided as they cannot be washed clean and are breeding places for bacteria.

Whereas action was formerly paid to the quality and uniformity of the filter sand, recent practice has proven that for proper results definite standards must be met and now this filtering medium must pass rigid tests and specifications.

Sand performs its function as a filtering medium through its ability to hold back the coagulated or floe containing the suspended and colloidal matter in the water. Practically speaking, the top surface of the sand performs this duty, and it is assumed in practice that none of the finer grades penetrate to a depth of six inches into the sand. It is customary to provide a depth of sand of from 18 to 36 inches in industrial filters, to as much as 10 inches in municipal filters, the latter extreme depth being required only when the filter is operated on behalf or the individual practice of some engineers.

The sand bed should not be so shallow as to be easily clogged or broken through during filtering and yet not deep as to offer needed resistance to the flow of water.

Suitability of a sand as a filtering medium depends upon its mechanical character, freedom from clay, dirt, organic matter and other impurities, and its grading. Since the smaller uniform size the smaller grains will pack in the voids between the coarser grains causing undue resistance to the flow of water. Coarse uniform grains are considered preferable to sharp grains because the former do not pack so readily and clean much better.

Two measures are used to draw a fairly accurate picture of the size and grading of filter sand. These are the "Effective Size" and the "Uniformity Coefficient."

By "Effective Size" is meant the size of the sand grains—usually expressed in decimal fractions—a percentage—than which 10% by weight of the sand is finer and 90% coarser. Thus the "Effective Size" is the minimum size of the sand grains that will pass, but it does not indicate either the limits of coarseness or the degree of uniformity in the size of the particles added in the 90%.

Therefore, in order to assure that the filtration is not impaired a test analysis of the sand is made. This is the size of sand grains than which 60% by weight of the sand in the sample will pass. This value divided by the "Effective Size" is called the "Uniformity Coefficient."

For example, if a screen analysis showed that 10% of a sand was finer than 0.40 millimeter, and 60% was finer than 0.64 millimeter—the Effective Size would be 0.40 millimeter, and the Uniformity Coefficient would be 0.64 divided by 0.40 or 1.6. Obviously, the more uniform the sand the closer the sizes will be the sizes of grains than which 10% is finer and than which 50% is finer—or the closer will be the Uniformity Coefficient approach 1.0.

The most desirable "Effective Size" and "Uniformity Coefficient" depend upon the condition of filter sand and the quality of filtered water desired. Modern practice calls for at least two gradings of filter sand. Internationally, the range of variation of the "Effective Size" of from 0.35 to 0.55 m.m.—as conditions warrant—and Uniformity Coefficient of from 1.75 to 1.6.

When a filter is washed, the entire sand bed rises and gradually moves down the pipes on top, grading down to the coarsest at the bottom—so that such sand automatically produces the several size condition that is most desired.

**Chemical Requirements:**

The filter bed must be insoluble in water and must not contain any filter aids. The gravel from clay, dirt, organic matter and other impurities, and its grading. Since the smaller uniform size the smaller grains will pack in the voids between the coarser grains causing undue resistance to the flow of water. Coarse uniform grains are considered preferable to sharp grains because the former do not pack so readily and clean much better.
Rates of Filtration:

The maximum rate of filtration depends upon the required quality of filtered water, the character and condition of the sand bed, and the character of the water to be filtered. Water can be forced through a pressure filter at enormous rates if sufficient pressure is applied—but the water will be heated and at excessive rates the water will hardly be "strained," the coagulant will be driven down into the sand and thus not be eliminated during the wash.

For efficient operation and proper quality of effluent, the rate of filtration should be carefully controlled and fluctuated. Standard practice has set a rate of from two to three gallons per minute per sq. ft. of filter area as being satisfactory. Rates higher than these may be required or allowable under special conditions.

The standard specifications for pressure water filters, as approved by the American Waterworks Association and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, give the following rates of filtration as standards:

Whenever the water is to be used for domestic purposes, the rate of filtration shall be such that the capacity shall be based on a rate of filtration not to exceed 2 gallons per minute per sq. ft. of filtering area and a coagulant must be used.

Rates of filtration for various uses should conform to the following schedule:

- 2 gals. per sq. ft. per minute for all supplies used for drinking, or for the preparation of food products.
- 2 to 4 gals. per sq. ft. per minute when filtering a treated municipal supply of approved bacterial purity.
- 2 to 5 gals. per sq. ft. per minute for swimming pools and for all industrial uses.
- 2 to 5 gals. per sq. ft. per minute as conditions may warrant for domestic filtration, using sand and activated carbon, where reduction of color, odor, taste or certain forms of iron is desired. This method of filtration is not to be applied for bacterial purification.

Washing:

Provision for proper washing of the sand bed is equally as important as the filter itself. The filter must be cleaned regularly to remove what is removed from the water and will continue to work satisfactorily only so long as it is properly washed. A filter cannot be operated at its maximum allowable loss of head is reached—or until the desired rate can no longer be maintained.

This can be regulated by shutting off the filter out of service, the waste valve opened and water—preferably filtered water—admitted to the unfiltered side of the filter. This will wash the sand or float the sand bed, to scrub or scour the sand and to flush out the accumulated impurities.

From three to five minutes of wash time are required to clean the sand bed—with six minutes as an average figure. From nine to ten percent of the water filter is the wash amount of wash water used—with three per cent an average.

The rate of flow of wash water required for efficient cleaning depends upon the size of sand, the system of washing, and the efficiency of the wash water distributing system. The modern—and simplest—type of filter is called the "high velocity" wash where the velocity of the wash water alone thoroughly scours and cleans the sand.

High velocity wash needs the most efficient form of distributing manifold system and proper grading grading to provide washout of the gravel layers and provide uniform distribution of wash water. The rate of flow of wash water required is 15 gals. per min. per sq. ft. of filter area (24 inches vertical rise per minute), although rates as low as 8 gals. per min. (13 inches vertical rise) have been found satisfactory.

When wash water is not available for high velocity wash—air or mechanical agitation may be used to loosen the filter bed. With such preliminary agitation, the wash water requires wash water at a velocity of 12 to 15 inches vertical rise per minute (8 to 10 gals. per sq. ft.). The use of mechanical agitation is obsolete but the air wash system—if properly designed—will satisfactorily solve the occasional problem of insufficient wash water.

The proper rate of flow of wash water is not important—provided at low rates of wash for even long periods of wash water does not wash out the impurities during backwashing, the waste outlet, trough or pipe should be a definite distance above the surface of the sand bed. This distance is determined as the depth of the sand bed.

Freeboard:

To prevent sand from being washed out with the impurities during backwashing, the waste outlet, trough or pipe should be a definite distance above the surface of the sand bed. This distance is determined as the depth of the sand bed.

Pressure Filters:

The use of pressure filters is as old as the practice of rapid sand filtration. The term "pressure" is used to designate any type of rapid sand filter in which the filter bed is placed in a closed container, through which the water passes under pressure. This does not mean that high pressure is required to pass water through the filter. To operate economically the pressure consumed is not more than two pounds at its maximum, and is usually measured about one pound directly after the filter is washed.

In comparison with gravity and open type rapid sand filters, the pressure filters have certain apparent advantages. Connection may be made up to the filter tank and there is no need for water distribution except that contained in the filter, as mentioned above. Repumping of the wash water is not necessary, and the filters may be quickly installed on simple foundations and usually fit into some available space. Therefore, the loss of water due to frequent backwashing may be eliminated. Less precision in operation is demanded. The first cost is lower.

Coagulation:

Coagulation and filtration are very intimately related in the field of water purification. The use of a coagulant in connection with the pressure filter is essential if it is desired to remove all suspended matter visible to the naked eye. The spaces between the granules of the filter bed are sufficiently large to allow the finer particles to pass through the filter. In order to retain all the suspended matter in the filter bed it is necessary that the impurities be brought together into comparatively large particles. This is accomplished by introducing a coagulant, alum, by means of the coagulant feeder. The small amount of alum fed into the water is entirely and immediately decomposed by the alkalinity originally present in the water or which may be added. The chemical reaction which takes place produces hydrate of alumina, a heavy, sticky compound of alumina. At the same time, the electrolytic force set free induces the finer particles to gather together in floes, each of which becomes enveloped in the sticky hydrate of alumina.

Sedimentation:

While comparatively few waters require sedimentation in connection with International Pressure Filters, it can be used advantageously with very turbid waters. The purpose of preliminary sedimentation are to allow the suspended and coagulated matter to settle, to provide time for coagulating compounds to reach precipitation, to remove most of a large amount of work (at least 80 percent), thereby reducing the washing of filters to a minimum.

The time required for settling out suspended matter varies depending on the size and weight of the particles, amount of coagulant used, etc. Where coagulation is considered preliminary to passing the water through International Filters, a period of two to six hours holding time is generally allowed. This period determines the size of settling basin required.

International Distributing Manifold System:

The only practical distributing manifold for use with pressure filters is the pipe manifold consisting of a header pipe with distributing lateral pipes spaced six inches center to center. The units and the steel tank construction does not readily permit the use of systems such as the Wagner type connecting head boxes.

False bottoms of steel plate—unless ridiculously remote—will pulsate or "breathe" so that it is impossible for the orifice nozzles or "strainers" from working loose and blowing out during washing. If the plate is perforated in place of using gravel grading its action during washing will displace the gravel layers.

To provide perfect collection of filtered water and uniform distribution of wash water from all points directly under the surface of the filter bed the International manifold is of the pipe manifold type. The header pipe is oversize and the laterals are spaced not more than 6 inches center to center, and are of area larger than the total area of the perforations or orifice nozzles in each lateral. To meet certain conditions, the manifold system can be installed in the lateral type, where perforations, spaced 3 inches center to center, are set in the underside of the gravel pipe and the latter set close to the concrete floor of the filter. Jet action is overcome by the extreme steepness of the concrete floor and driving before changing direction and working downward through the gravel layers.

The standard manifold system on International general purpose pressure filters is of the pipe manifold type with International Umbrella Nozzles. Header and lateral pipes are oversize and the laterals are spaced six inches center to center. The orifice nozzles are of the umbrella type—center center to center in both directions—are screwed into the top side of the laterals. The concrete floor of the filter is brought up to inside of the lateral system and provide a smooth floor under the gravel.

International Tobin Bronze Distributing Nozzle:

The International Tobin Bronze Distributing Nozzle was developed to provide a "strainer" that would accomplish every required purpose—to stand abuse and wear under all operating conditions—and to eliminate the common faults of ordinary "strainers."

It is made in but two pieces—the body and the cap—both parts of genuine Tobin bronze. The body is a forging, the cap and the rivets being an integral part of the body—and of real riveting metal. The cap is of one piece, scientifically formed with a chamfered cone and umbrella edge—both perfectly formed for efficient distribution. The river heads are spun and polished to assure a perfect seal between cap and body. The throat is accurately bored to proper diameter with chamfered edge to insure free inflow. The strainer is accurately graded ½ inch size by automatic dies. The hexagon shaped part of the body permits the use of a standard wrench for installations.

The term "strainer" to describe this part of the distributing system is now obsolete. Before it was learned that proper gravel and correct gravel grading should be depended on to keep the gravel bed clean, many other forms of actual sand strainers were used—and many are still being offered today. With correct gravel grading and the distributing manifold system of efficient design and construction, there is virtually no possibility of burying the gravel or allowing sand to get to the bottom of the filter. The purpose of the "strainer" of today is to store and convey wash water and is that of an efficient distribution of wash water under the entire bottom of the gravel bed.

A few of the advantages of the International New Tobin Umbrella Type Nozzle are:

- It has but one interior orifice which will not clog because it is constructed with multiple orifices or slots inevitably clogging within a comparatively short time.

- It prevents rapid diffusion by the cone umbrella cap, diverting the water downward in all directions with rapid "get-away" yet extremely low velocity. This prevents rapid diffusion throughout the entire underside of the gravel layers. Multiple orifice strainers produce a jet action which is undesirable and destructive to the gravel bed—but in any case as a jet or number of jets—which puts the responsibility of diffusion throughout of the gravel bed and uniform distribution is rarely accomplished.

- Better constructed entirely of Tobin bronze it is far superior in its resistance to corrosion than strainers of brass or so called "acid bronze."

- The base—with its rivets—being a forging, it is more homogeneous and stronger than the more or less harsh of ordinary strainers and the rivets are much more uniform and ductile. The rivets, being an integral part of the forging, will never work loose.
Operation:

Water enters the International Filter through the top and is distributed evenly throughout the filter area by a baffle which prevents the incoming water from striking the sand bed and disturbing the surface film. The water passes downward through the filter bed and travels the clean filtered water uniformly collected from beneath the gravel by the manifold system, through which it flows to the outlet connection.

To remove the collected sediment or suspended matter, the filter is periodically cleaned by reversing the flow of water. The dirty water enters at the bottom, is first distributed by the manifold system, further distributed by the umbrella plates and finally washed out through the gravel layers. As the water rises the filter bed expands and is loosened; the sediment lifting and passing out to waste with the wash water.

Sir:

Some time ago I received a communication from the Reverend Principal at the Gordon's Indian Residential School that the 10 H.P. engine in use there was worn out and not properly functioning. I requested the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co. to send one of their experts to look over and report upon the engine as it was bought from them, and I have just received this.

Information from the company indicates that the cylinder is very badly scored and that to renew this and provide a new piston, a new cylinder head, complete with valves, etc., and completely overhaul the engine, would cost approximately $500.00. While this seems to me a large amount, the engine should be overhauled before the cold weather sets in. It has only been in use for the past six years and the expert can offer no reason as to why it should now require so much repairing. I am assured, however, that for the expenditure named, it can be placed in first class condition.

The Principal requested that it should be replaced by a 15 H.P. engine, but I am of the opinion that the lesser expenditure involved in repairing the old one would be more economical and should prolong its life for another four or five years. I shall be glad if the Department will advise me whether the work may be proceeded with.

Your obedient servant,

W. W. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir;

Re. Filtration Plant and Engine Room, Gordons School.

I am enclosing herewith three copies of B. Dunster's account for the work on above at Gordons School. This work has run into more time than was at first anticipated, but with so much changing of machinery which had to be kept running, it could not be avoided. Before the filtration plant could be installed the engine had to be changed from its original foundation onto a new one built in the new engine room. Before this was done the generator had to be moved, as it was in the spot required for the engine. The generator could not be placed on its new foundation until such time as the engine was also moved as the light had to be kept on for the school. This was arranged by temporarily installing the generator and then when all was ready making the change in one day; running a temporary line to the switch board from the generator.

As soon as engine and generator were on their new foundations it was necessary to arrange for the running of the laundry machinery. This we had expected to do by a twisted belt from the drive wheel to a pulley on overhead shaft, but this after several trials was found to be impracticable and we had to rearrange the laundry machinery, which now runs much better with a direct driven shaft.

When we had the laundry machinery running, the old engine bed, a large concrete block, had to be broken up with cold chisel and hammer so that the filter tank could be installed; this tank in the meantime was in the new engine room.

With the engine bed demolished and the concrete in shape to receive the tank it was moved onto its proper position and the fitting and installing commenced. This involved running the water main under the concrete floor to the filter tank and then to the pressure tanks; also the running of a waste from filter tank to sewer to septic tank. When the actual connecting up of the filter was done the two large pressure tanks had to be emptied and the work done so that the water supply to the school was not interfered with. This was managed by working during the night hours.

After we had the filter functioning O.K., the switchboard and batteries had to be moved into the new engine room which naturally involved a lot of work on the wiring from generator to switchboard.

1.
With the present layout the school has an engine room that is safe to move around in and a compact filtration plant right alongside the main water supply tanks, and the laundry machinery is running with less loss of power.

The Fairbanks-Morse expert was up a few days ago and the engine now appears to be in good condition. The alum sulphate for the coagulant tank of the filter was obtained through the local druggist.

If there are any further details of the work done, I shall be pleased to furnish you with same.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

I am taking the liberty of writing to tell you some of my troubles in the hope that you may see your way to help me and am writing the letter "personal."

Last year the Department were unable to sanction the building of a house for the Farm Instructor or to enlarge the barn. Might ask you to grant this favour this year.

During the month of March last year Commissioner Graham engaged a Farm Instructor for me and promised him a house—perhaps I should say the man told me he promised it—which house of course was not built.

The man was married and came from Ontario.

In the month of June he asked me if his wife and baby might come on a visit. They came and stayed for some time but the arrangement was far from being satisfactory and I had to ask him to leave. Mr. Graham did not say anything to me but I don't think he was pleased at my action.
The reason for asking him to look for other work was because his wife made trouble among the members of the staff and a change became absolutely necessary. I never told him the reason as I would not talk too much about his wife but I think he quite understood the conditions.

I have an opportunity of securing a good married man now but would not think of doing so unless you sanction the building of a house. It is very desirable that we should not be continually changing our staff and a married man is more likely to settle down than a single man. Also this is no place for a woman who has no work to do as she is liable to make trouble.

Barn

We have not sufficient room for our stock or feed. Our present are very over-crowded and it is very difficult to do our work properly.

The other matter I wished to put before you is the question of land.

As you know we have a half section on part of which stands the old school. There are only 60 acres bordering
This half and although we are clearing the land around the present school hoping to ultimately join it up to the south land — it is a very slow process. Last year we pulled 850 stumps on eight acres and then ploughed it. There is some open land just north of school and I would be very grateful if you would allow us to work it as we really cannot grow sufficient food on the small holding we have. Mr. Moore, Indian Agent at Punnichy, knows all the circumstances and knows also that I am trying to do all in my power to make the best of what I have but I do require some cleared land.

Apologizing for bothering you with such a long letter about my troubles but with the earnest hope that you may be able to assist me.

I remain

Yours very truly,

J.K. Irwin
Principal.

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the desirability of providing a farmer's residence and enlarging the barn at the Gordon's Indian Residential School. With reference to securing a parcel of land to the north of the school, I have directed that enquiries be made and you will be advised later in the matter.

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report of an inspection of the various schools in the Touchwood Agency which was made by Mr. Inspector Hamilton.

I see nothing in this report that requires much attention, excepting the Inspector's remarks regarding the residence of the teacher on the Day Star reserve. This house is in bad condition, but as the people who are occupying it are of little or no account and they are about to leave I thought we could let this matter stand until such time as we get people in there who are capable of looking after things and then we could put the house in shape.

With reference to the appointment of a Farming Instructor at the Gordon Indian Residential School, I do not know whether the newly appointed Principal has any knowledge of farming or not. If he has not this school is going to be in a bad way. Canon Irwin had no practical knowledge of farming and surrounded himself with the poorest class of men possible, and if the new Principal is not an improvement I am afraid we cannot look forward to any great change for the better. As regards the dryer in the laundry, the mechanic should be able to fix this and should do it without assistance. As regards the matter of a chicken house, this can be attended to when we are fixing up the stable this summer. You will note that the doors

GORDON'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The classroom work here is carried on in the senior room by Miss Atwater. She has been here for a number of years and is doing good work.

The junior room is in charge of Mr. Sinclair, and I believe his work is quite satisfactory.

In both classrooms the children appeared well along in their grades, and the work examined was good. The children were clean, and I found the classrooms well aired and tidy.

Mrs. Collins was in charge of the kitchen, where I found the work being carried out with good discipline. The food was well prepared, and I think, in all respects, Mrs. Collins gives good service.

The sewing teacher, Miss Wilkins, is quite capable, but unfortunately was leaving the following week. Both the boys' matron and laundry matron had recently left, but Rev. Canon Irwin informed me he had already engaged new officers.

Mr. Dunster
Mr. Dunster is now engineer. He is an experienced man, and I feel sure can carry out any repair work required.

Since the Farming Instructor, Mr. Headrick, left no one has received the appointment. A first class man is badly needed in this position. Canon Irwin informed me he had a man in view, but was unable to hire him as he has no accommodation at present for a married man.

I found the school in good repair and clean throughout. The filter is giving splendid satisfaction, although it does not soften the water.

The dryer in the laundry is of little use. I believe this could be made to do good work, but would require about $50.00 worth of pipe and material. The engineer informed me he could do the work if the material were supplied.

The chicken house has not been in use since its erection. Only one ply of boards were used in this building and these have divided apart so that it is unfit for winter use. This should be put in shape so that poultry may be kept.

I found the other building in good repair, and the work horses in much better condition than ever before. The cattle appeared to be receiving good care.

Very little sickness has occurred at this school during the winter, and the children looked exceptionally well. I believe they receive good care and plenty of wholesome food.

Sir,

In the Touchwood Agency Estimates for 1928-29 I inserted an item of $1000.00 to provide a soft water reservoir and $120.00 for fencing, both of which are urgently needed at Gordon's School. The soft water reservoir was authorized at one time but the amount allowed was entirely inadequate and nothing was done to provide for the storage of soft water. This really is an urgent necessity and I shall be very glad if some means can be found to provide it.

I am exercising the strictest economy, saving wherever possible on such items as have been allowed but this is a case where an ordinary, everyday facility should have been provided long ago and I trust the Department will be able to provide for an expenditure of $120.00 for the above mentioned items.

Sir:

Recently the Reverend Principal of the Gordon's Indian Residential School wrote stating that the fire hose and extinguishers at the school are in bad condition. I requested the Indian Agent to let me have a report and he states that the hose appear to be leaking badly although not cut or cracked, and suggests using a dressing. This, I understand, should not be used with linen hose and it is possible that the hose is dry and that running water through will swell the weave and prevent the leakage. I am directing the Indian Agent to have this done and report again.

In regard to the extinguishers, he states that they need acid and two of them require new hose. These are matters which the Principal should have attended to and I am directing the Agent to tell the Principal to buy acid and new hose. He states that they need "two more small extinguishers of the long thin cylinder type at $3.00 each" for the engine room, and three additional 2½ gallon extinguishers for the upper storey. Will the Department please arrange to have these supplied.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

sir:-

I beg to inform you that it has been necessary to have the generator at the Gordon's Indian Residential School overhauled.

In correspondence with the Agent regarding this matter he states that from his own observations a great deal of the trouble lies in the human element. There have been different men in charge of this plant during the past four years; some experienced no trouble whilst others had nothing but trouble, all depending upon their experience and common sense. The Agent goes on to say that while he was at the school with a local electrician the school engineer started to disconnect the batteries from the generator while the latter was running full speed, but he was stopped in time. On the way back to Punnichy the electrician who was sent out to fix the plant stated that it would be all right with a new generator if it was left in capable hands and not monkeyed with.

I am writing this letter to impress upon the Department the absolute importance of seeing that the school authorities employ competent help to run these expensive machines. I am satisfied in my own mind that thousands of dollars are wasted annually through mismanagement of these plants, and I have been harping on this subject for some time hoping that a change would be made. It is hard to stand by seeing this destruction going on without making some comment on it. The plants are up-to-date and in no time there are large bills for unwarranted expenditures.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Confirming my telegrams to you regarding the Gordon's school fire, at the time of writing, 1 o'clock Saturday, the only information I have had over the phone is that they have not as yet discovered the cause of the fire. Mr. Moore is out there now holding an investigation and when I receive his report it will be forwarded to you at once. In the meantime, I can assure you that everything possible is being done to take care of the children. I expect there will be around thirty going to Elkhorn. There is building accommodation there for that number. It might be a good idea to take some to the File Hills School later on.

The loss is a great one; it was really a splendid building and we were just getting things lined up - a new Principal and a first class Farming Instructor who was going to make changes there. The stock and other buildings, of course, will be looked after by the members of the staff. At the time of writing, I cannot tell you just what the Church authorities intend to do. They will likely want to carry on some of the work at the old stone building. Mr. Christianson is in Alberta, Mr. Murison is at Saddle Lake and Mr. Hamilton is in bed.

I will write you when I get further particulars.

Dear Sir:

Re. Gordons School.

In accordance with your instructions of Wednesday last I have made an inspection of the remains of the school and beg to report as follows:
The footings are of course perfectly good, and the basement walls up as far as the concrete and tile construction goes are O.K. This means that from the top of the footings there is 5'6" of concrete and tile wall that is fit to build on. That is 1'6" above the ground.
The asphalt mastic flooring of the basement is burnt but this has protected the sub-floor of concrete which will require no repairing.
The walls of the boiler room and tank room are in good condition, although the chapel above was completely destroyed. The water tanks and filtration plant appear to be generally O.K. except for the gauges and small pipe connections. The two low-pressure steam heating boilers appear to be little the worse except for gauges etc.
The hot water tank is O.K.
Many of the cast iron radiators, I think, could be salvaged, although they are all mixed in the debris in the basement.
The two metal fire escapes can be reused.
A large number of bricks could be salvaged and used for backing up and interior partition walls.
The large chimney to boiler room is O.K., but although the kitchen chimney is standing I am of the opinion that it should be taken down; it would be dangerous to work around it. All the laundry machinery is a complete loss. The engine and generator are also a loss, but the switch-board and storage batteries were saved from the fire. If the intentions are to rebuild I would like to suggest that the building be of fire-proof constructions. This could be of the lighter type such as used in many of our city schools; brick and tile walls with Massillon bar joist construction for floors, and partition walls of gypsum tile. Stairways of concrete or steel. I am of the opinion that such a structure, built from the same plans, with minor changes in layout, could be put up for less than the original cost of the school.
It must be considered that all excavating, footings, concrete floors, and part basement walls are already in place. The water supply is piped to the building, the septic tank is connected to the basement, and all underground plumbing is in. The rainwater tank is also in position.

If such work is contemplated it might be a good idea to have the Indians undertake to clear the debris away before they commenced their spring work on the land.

If there is anything further that I can do for you in this matter I shall be only too pleased to have your instructions.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) Wm. Swan.

P.S. I may say that during my inspection I had the opportunity to talk with Mr. Williams, who I believe was boys' supervisor, and he tells me that he was with the engineer when they both went to the boys' lavatory to put out the fire. They went in from the playroom but the smoke was too thick for them to stay in so they went out and around to break in the windows, and then got down to work on the burning partition with portable extinguishers. But as the fire was in behind the asbestos wainscoting on this wall they were unable to put it out and in a few minutes the upper part of the partition near the ceiling was flaming. He is of the opinion that no blow-torch was used that day; and if it was I see no reason for using it near that partition. Also, seeing that there was no wiring in the partition, the theory of a short circuit is out.

W.S.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith copy of a report that I received from Mr. Wm. Swan, of Punnichy, who, as you know, had charge of the construction work at the Gordon School. I am not in favour, however, of having Indians remove this debris unless there is a competent foreman in charge and perhaps two or three white men. Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th. instant, with reference to the salvaging of material from the Gordon School. You ask me to give you some idea as to what it would cost to clean up the place and provide storage for the materials worth keeping, and in reply I would say that it is difficult to answer this question. In the first place, all these boilers are down in the bottom of the basement floor and they could not be removed, excepting at considerable cost, and if we were going to protect them from the weather it would mean we would have to go to work and build a temporary shed which would cost a lot of money. Then again, there is a lot of material around that would have to be taken apart. Altogether I believe it would cost $2000.00, if not more, to look after this material for the period of a year, and I think it would pay the Department to seriously consider re-building the school at once. The money that would be spent on housing this material could be applied on a new building. Of course, if the school is not to be rebuilt steps should be taken to remove the boilers, etc., to another part of the country.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant No. 121-1-5, informing me that if funds are provided by Parliament it is the intention to proceed with the rebuilding of the Gordon's School, enclosing copies of the floor plans of the school as it appeared before the fire, and asking me to interview the Church authorities and return the blue prints with any changes that might be desired. In reply I may say that I had Archdeacon Knowles, who represents the Church in this matter, and who is the practical man on the committee, go over the plans with Mr. Swan. He has only suggested one slight change and that is that the clothes room be thrown open into the sewing room, and this to me seems a practical suggestion as it will give more light and there is no reason why it should be partitioned off.

There is a slight extension to be made to the engine room. We had this extension framed in before, but we might as well have the concrete basement walls extended to include it.

Aside from the above there are no changes that I can suggest, and these changes are noted on the blue prints which are returned herewith.

The front entrance steps as shown by the red marks were constructed on these lines in the original building.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

I have your letter of the 2nd. instant No. 121-1-15, and I note that the plans for the new Gordon's School will be ready in a few days, and that tenders will be advertised for at once.

With reference to that part of your letter in which you advise me that my letter of the 21st. of May did not reach the Department until the 21st. of June, I may say it was only yesterday I discovered the reason for this delay. The plans were received in my office on Saturday, May 18th. Knowing the great importance of the matter I dealt with it on Monday, the 20th., made the necessary changes in the plans and dictated the letter. This letter was written on Tuesday, the 21st., and together with the plans was sent out to Mr. Hay for mailing on that date, but for some reason he did not send it out and it remained in his desk for fully three weeks before he discovered it. When he did come across it again he mailed it without making any mention to me of the fact that it had been delayed, nor did he mention it to the Clerks in the office until some time after the 13th. of July on which date I sent you a telegram asking if the Department had come to any decision regarding the building. The whole incident is most regrettable, and the cause of the delay for this period of three weeks rests entirely with this office. I note, however, that the letter did reach the Department on the 21st. of June last.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
