Where there are special circumstances which in the judgment of the Minister of Labour make it expedient that he should do so, he may, in any case, rescind, revoke, amend or vary the provisions above referred to, determining what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages for overtime, and what is the proper classification of any work for the purposes of wages and hours. Immediately upon receipt of notice of any decision of the Minister of Labour hereunder the contractor shall adjust the wages and hours and classification thereof so as to give effect to such decision and if the contractor shall fail so to do or to pay to any employee or employees for any services performed or for any hours of labour, wages according to the rates fixed therefor by the Minister of Labour, the Minister of Labour may authorize and direct the Minister to pay any amount fixed at rates so fixed and to deduct the amount thereof from any moneys owing by the Government to the contractor and any such payment shall for all purposes as between the contractor and the Government be deemed and taken to be payment to the contractor, and the contractor shall be deemed and taken to be bound by such authority and such payment as aforesaid. The powers of the Minister of Labour hereunder shall not be exercised as to any employee or employees where it is established to his satisfaction that an agreement in writing exists and is in effect between the contractor and each of such employees, or which such employee or employees belong or the authorized representatives of such class of employees fixing rates of wages, overtime conditions and hours of labour.

(2) The Contractor shall post and keep posted in a conspicuous place on the premises where the contract is being executed, occupied or frequented by the workmen, the Fair Wages Clause or Schedule inserted in his contract for the work herein mentioned, also any decision of the Minister of Labour under the preceding paragraph.

(3) The Contractor shall keep proper books and records showing the names, trades, and addresses of all workmen in his employ and the wages paid to and time worked by such workmen, and the books or documents containing such record shall be open for inspection by the Fair Wage Officer of the Government at any time it may be expedient to the Minister of Labour to have the same.

(4) The Contractor shall not be entitled to payment of any money which would otherwise be payable under the terms of the contract in respect of work and labour performed in the execution of the contract unless and until he shall have filed with the Minister in support of his claim for payment a statement attesting that he has complied with the following (1) the rates of wages and hours of labour of the various classes of workmen employed in the execution of the contract; (2) whether any wages in respect of the said work and labour remain in arrears; (3) that all the labour conditions of the contract have been duly complied with, not in default of notice given by the Minister of Labour of claims for wages until the same are settled. Dear Sir;

Re. Gordon School.

As suggested by you on your visit to Punnichy this week, I herewith offer a few suggestions which would in my opinion save the Dept. of Indian Affairs money in the building of the new school.

In the first place the removal of the large amount of debris from the basement will take some time after the contract is let, and as the weather cannot be relied upon for more than another two months; it would appear that things could be speeded up by having the Indians and other local labour start to clear this at once. This work could be done either by the day under a good foreman, or by the load of material moved.

Threshing on the reserves and in the surrounding country is now finished and labour is therefore available at very reasonable rates. In doing this all materials that are fit to use could be checked and stacked, and a price allowed by the contractors doing the work. This would also give the inspector of the work a better chance to say what could or could not be reused. There are about twenty thousand brick that could be cleaned and reused in the interior walls of the basement, at least 75% of the angle iron lintels could be used again, and the two fire escapes have only been damaged by falling bricks, and can be easily put in usable condition by a blacksmith. The two pressure tanks with their supports are in good condition and only need refitting with gauges etc.

The filtration plant only needs new fittings to put it in working order. There is a considerable quantity of 12" and 6" tile which could be cleaned up and used.

There is also a quantity of material that can be salvaged and sold, which would not be used in the new building; such as the two old boilers, the hot water tank and heater, the cast iron columns, and all the old radiation and pipes. Much of the latter would be merely sold as junk, but is an item that might be considered.

The white glazed brick in the kitchen came through the fire in very good condition, except for a slight gray tinge the glaze appears to be perfectly good, and as the largest portion of these are still standing in the walls they could be salvaged.
with very little breakage.

If this work of cleaning up were done by the Department it would certainly result in them having a large quantity of material to sell which many of the contractors are now figuring on using without allowing very much for same. You can readily see that unless some definite check is made of this old material much of it will find its way into the new building, and the Department will not have credit for it; and what is worse the use of it may be very detrimental to the new structure.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., September 26th, 1929.

Dear Mr. Scott:

While at Touchwood the other day I examined what remains of the Gordon's School, this being the first time I had seen it since it was burnt.

I found the basement filled almost to the ground level with brick, iron pipes, radiators, boilers and other material. Mr. Swan, who supervised the building of the first school, happened to be on the ground looking over the site, and in a conversation with him, he thought it would have been a wise plan had the Department removed all this material and salvaged anything that might be used in the new building. I asked Mr. Swan to write me a letter giving his view on the matter, which he has done, and I herewith enclose same.

I might say that the Department would be very well advised to employ Mr. Swan as Building Inspector on the new school. He is very competent, and as it requires more than an ordinary man to look after this job and check up the work, especially in view of the fact that some of the old material will be used in the reconstruction, I would advise that Mr. Swan be given the job. I have already recommended this man for the position, but have heard nothing from the Department on the matter.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir;-

We are enclosing you our bid on the re-building of Gordon Indian School at Punnichy, Sask.

We have examined the job as it stands today, and a few things we might mention are as follows;-

If four dormitory wood cupboards, as we take them to be, and four passage wood cupboards, and all of the winter clothes closets we figure are in wood, if the above are not to be put in the new building in wood, you can deduct from our tender $1015.00.

While specifications do not specify the toilet partitions to be in steel, we have included them all in steel with steel doors, on second floor only.

While we have gone carefully over the building and examined every part of it we can see, we do not think that there is a part of the concrete footings or walls that require to be re-built in new concrete, therefore we have not estimated on any part of the outside wall footings or wall above footings which is in concrete now to be in new work. A few places require a little repairing. We have included this, but nothing for new walls or footings under outside walls of the
building. We have included all new walls and new footings for inner partitions, and we think this is all that is required.

Yours truly,

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 17th October 1929.

The Committee of the Privy Council have before them a Report, dated 7th October, 1929, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, stating that same being necessary, tenders were called for the re-building of the Gordon's Indian Residential School, near Punnichy, in the Province of Saskatchewan, which was destroyed by fire last year, and that the following were received in regular form and accompanied by the required deposit security:

- Shoquist Bros., 211 Dunbass Sts., Saskatoon, Sask. ........... $133,895.00
- A.W. Cassidy and Co., Ltd., Saskatoon, Sask. ......................... $137,700.00
- R.M. Wyatt, Lombard Ridge, Winnipeg, Man. ....................... $136,900.00
- Macneil and Macdonald, Winnipeg, Man. ......................... $143,470.00
- Smith Bros and Wilson, Ltd., Regina, Sask. ...................... $146,993.00
- P.W. Graham and Sons, Ltd., Moose Jaw, Sask. .................. $147,068.00
- J. Albert Tremblay, Winnipeg, Man. ......................... $150,843.00
- Poole Construction Co., Regina, Sask. ......................... $175,315.00

The Architect of the Department of Indian Affairs has reported that the lowest of the above tenders, namely, that of Shoquist Bros., of Saskatoon, in the Province of Saskatchewan, is fair and reasonable, and the Minister recommends that it be accepted pursuant to the requirements of Subsection 3 of Section 36 of the Public Works Act. Funds for this purpose have been provided from Parliamentary Appropriation for Indian Education.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

The Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Sir:

Your favor of the 19th instant, mailed from Ottawa on the 23rd instant and received by us on the 28th instant, confirming your telegraphic advice of acceptance of our tender for the rebuilding of Gordon's Indian Residential School, together with contract forms in duplicate have received our attention.

We note that entire completion according to the contract is to be effected by April 20, 1930, and in this connection we may state that our estimated period of construction as shown on our tender form called for six months, and we may frankly state that this refers to six construction months, because it is impossible to lay brick or do concrete work in the severe temperatures obtaining during a portion of the winter months, and we feel sure that the Chief Architect or his representative would not permit this work to be done under climatic conditions that might seriously detract from the permanence of the completed structure. We are at present engaged in clearing the site and delivering material to the job, and will do everything in our power to rush this work to completion compatible with good workmanship, and we trust that this will meet with the approval of the Department of Indian Affairs.

We have completed execution of the Agreement in duplicate, and take pleasure in inclosing same herein. Doubtless one copy will be returned to us in due course.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir;

Re. Gordon's Indian Residential School.

Upon receipt of your letter of Oct. 22nd last, appointing me temporarily as inspector of construction for the rebuilding of the above school, I arranged to visit the site with Messrs. Shoquist Bros., the contractors. This we did on Oct. 27th.

The contractors had had a small gang of men on for several days previous to this, clearing out debris and building bunk houses etc.

In discussing matters with the contractors I found that they had the impression that they would have all material salvaged; as I did not read the specifications that way I consulted with the Commissioner, Mr. Graham, on the matter, and he advised that a careful check be made of materials with a view to having the Department credited with any that was of value.

I also found that the Contractors did not expect to carry on all winter, but in view of the fact that I had not seen their contracts, the matter was left for further discussion with Mr. Gurney Orr.

I continued to make a daily inspection of the work as the cleaning up proceeded, and found that the concrete floors over all of basement had suffered nothing from the fire; the walls to grade were in good condition except for the inner four inches of tile which was removed and concrete poured to give an eighteen inch solid concrete wall.

Mr. Gurney Orr was in Punnichy on the fourth and fifth of Nov., and all points in question were gone over and settled. Since Mr. Orr's visit the cleaning up has been completed; the old boiler room and laundry walls wrecked and new footings and foundation walls poured for rear additions.

The Contractors have the cement, crushed stone, and lime on the job; the lime and cement being properly housed in tight sheds.

Mr. Hooff the estimator and representative of Shoquist Bros.

1.
was down to the job today in response to a telephone call from me regarding shipment of tile. This I found was being delayed because the twelve by twelve were not available for two weeks. Arrangements were made with another firm to ship four by twelve and eight by twelve immediately.

The steel plans from the Dominion Bridge Co., were checked and we are assured of quick action in the shipping of all steel.

I expect to see the bricklayers on the job by Thursday next, as the mill have promised delivery of the basement window frames by Wednesday.

Footings for the new columns have been excavated for, and these will be poured as soon as reinforcing steel is delivered. The plumbers have arranged to have a man on the job right away to check over the existing underground pipes, so that all breaking and patching of existing concrete floor may be done at one time.

I have written the H.A. Lister Co., of Winnipeg for a layout of the electrical plant so that if necessary we may arrange for a larger generator room, but up to date I have not received this.

With the definite understanding between Mr. Gurney Orr and the Contractors that the work was to proceed during the winter months I am striving to have them deliver materials so that a large gang of men may be kept busy until we have any extremely cold weather. At the present time we are having a mild spell and the early fall of snow has practically disappeared.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction,

Dear Sir;

Re. Gordon's Indian Residential School. Report No.2.

Since my last report on Nov.16th work on the above has gone on at only a fair rate; although delivery of material has been good. Delay in the delivery of reinforcing steel for column footings, and of the basement window frames, has held things up. On Nov.26th we had a mild day during which the column footings were poured, and covered in to protect from frost. On the 27th the basement frames were being set and three bricklayers were at work; there are now eight bricklayers at work and they are doing a good job.

During the last two days the weather has turned quite cold, and I am holding up the pouring of any concrete. Brickwork is going on; the men using hollow metal mortar boards with a low flat lamp inside, and as the mortar is put on the boards hot from being mixed with hot water and hot sand, the work is alright. I have received a letter from R.A. Lister Co., in which they stated that the generator room as shown was quite large enough. The new pump has been connected up with the existing supply line and there is now a good supply of water on the job. The south wing of the building is now up eighteen courses of brick above the concrete foundation wall, and there are several courses up on the remainder. With anything like reasonable weather during the next two weeks we should be ready for the ground floor steel joists.

I have made an appointment with the stone-cutter to come up from Regina on Tuesday next and go over the whole of the cut stone required, so that there may be no delay or errors in the shipments of stone as required. On Nov.28th I issued the first certificate for payment.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir;

Re: Gordon's School, Punnichy. Report No. 3.

Since my report of Nov. 30th last the above work has shown only fair progress. The weather in the West has been very cold for this time of year, and during several parts of days the bricklayers have not worked. I really do not consider it wise to have bricks laid up under the present conditions, and am notifying the Contractors that no more brick will be laid, after the walls are up to joist level, until more favourable weather. I feel that with the low temperatures now prevailing, it would be necessary to enclose the work in a temporary shell of boards and paper to secure a first class job of brickwork for bearing walls. I am writing Mr. Gurney Orr in detail on this subject.

At the present time only four of the steel columns have been set; none of the cast iron columns or steel beams have been delivered yet. One car load of Massillion steel joists is on the job. Practically all the frames from the mill are on the job, and most of the stone sills have been delivered. All the face brick are on the job, and the hollow tile is being delivered quickly.

By Tuesday the 17th I expect the bricklayers to be up to joist level when they will leave the work until milder weather after January. In the meantime the steel will be erected and the steel joists put in place.

A certificate was issued and mailed to you yesterday.

Your obedient servant,

THE SARCO Steam Trap differs from every other type of steam trap, as it utilizes the pressure of a fluid (a heavy hydrocarbon oil) hermetically sealed within a tube.

When the Sarco trap is connected, any steam in the line heats the expansion cartridge, the piston of which instantly moves out and closes the vent. As condensation collects, this cools the expansion cartridge and the trap opens, whereupon water is immediately ejected to the discharge. Steam, following again, heats the cartridge and closes the trap. No live steam ever passes but the lines are kept free of water at all times.

The use of the thermostatic principle is of great merit. The difference in temperature of steam and of the cooled condensation gives ample power to operate the trap. The action is at all times unfailing as the operating oil never tires and there are no friction losses.

No air binding is possible as air opens the trap in the same way as the water does.

A simple adjustment enables the user to discharge condensation at various desired temperatures.

The elimination of wasteful storage space in the trap, toggle joints, levers, buckets or floats, means less cost and less wear. Thus, the use of the Sarco ensures lower first cost and lower maintenance with maximum efficiency.

For variable steam pressure, use Sarco Steam Trap No. 9. (List No. 22.)

For heating systems, use Sarco Radiator Traps Type E. (List No. 8.)

For heavy service, use Sarco Blast Traps Nos. 9-3 and 9-4. (List No. 26.)

There are many semi-packless Inlet Valves on the market, but the Sarco is of the true packless type. By the use of the well-known Sarco helical tubing, it avoids the necessity for packing of any kind. The ordinary valve is usually hard to turn and leaks after a few months of service. The semi-packless types, relying on springs for packing effect, bind and are therefore jerky in their action.

The Sarco helical tubing, which takes the place of packing is not annularly corrugated but made in the form of a helix or spiral. The construction is unique and ensures a perfectly even distribution of the movement without the least danger of stressing the metal beyond its fatigue point. This feature ensures long life and reliability.

It is the only type of Packless Valve that should be used on a system which will operate below atmospheric pressures, as the most difficult leaks to detect and overcome, also the most disastrous to the vacuum, are those occurring through faulty packing glands in inlet valves.

The Sarco Inlet Valve has a heavy brass body, well nickeled and with pleasing lines. Each valve is fitted with a Jenkins long life composition disc.

Note that the handle is made so that the maximum of strength is obtained. This is achieved by making in one piece the handle proper and the stem connecting with the lift screw. This is a feature found only in Sarco Inlet Valves.

The dial is distinctly marked and will, after years of service, be as readable as when new. It is a handsome, well-built valve and a fit companion for the remarkably successful Sarco Thermostatic Radiator Trap. It can be used on all vacuum and vapor heating systems.

The new Sarco Self-Adjusting Steam Trap No. 9 is a development of the universally known Sarco Steam Trap for high and low pressure but is factory adjusted and works on widely varying pressures as well as on steady pressure.

It uses the unique Sarco helical bellows made from a seamless bronze tube. The helical form is greatly superior to the annular type of bellows as the movement is distributed over the entire number of corrugations with the result that the life of the bellows is greatly increased. The motor element never tires as it is never unduly stressed.

For a thousand applications in the industrial field the Sarco No. 9 has no rival in size, ease of installation, capacity, efficiency and price. It is the one leading trap for steam jacketed cooking vessels, live drips, high pressure heating coils, pressing machines, laundry equipment, kitchen and hospital fixtures. There are many semi-packless Inlet Valves on the market, but the Sarco is of the true packless type. It is the only type of Packless Valve that should be used on a system which will operate below atmospheric pressures, as the most difficult leaks to detect and overcome, also the most disastrous to the vacuum, are those occurring through faulty packing glands in inlet valves.

Sarco Temperature Regulators

For Liquids and Atmosphere

Principle of Design

Science has demonstrated that within a certain range the most efficient temperature control can be obtained by the utilization of the contraction and expansion of a sensitive liquid. It is this which forms the motive power of the Sarco Temperature Regulator, operating the unique Sarco helical bellows.

The expansion and contraction of a sensitive liquid permits the design of apparatus far more positive in action than thermostats relying on the use of a volatile fluid, which becomes a gas. With liquid expansion the power is always there. It is certain, positive and reliable. For a given increase in temperature, there will be a given increase in volume. More power is developed by liquid expansion and there is a gentle controlled and graduated action of the valve which insures considerable economy in the use of the heating or cooling medium and prevents fluctuations in the controlled temperature of the product.

Self-contained and Self-operated

Sarco Temperature Regulators, as compared with other thermostatic devices on the market, are self-contained and more compact, requiring no exterior operating means, such as compressed air, water or electricity. This form of construction, being virtually a power plant in itself, accounts for the success of the Sarco, as it reduces the first cost of the apparatus, lessens installation expenses to the lowest possible point, and eliminates maintenance expenses, there being no parts in the thermostat to get out of order. It also avoids the use, in the thermostat itself, of rubber or leather diaphragms, which are of a perishable nature and of metal disc diaphragms, which change their form with considerable resultant inaccuracy. No packing or stuffing boxes are used.

Positive Acting

The Sarco Regulators are very substantially constructed and a slight increase in the temperature of the surrounding liquid or atmosphere expands the operating fluid, producing a powerful hydraulic pressure tending to close the valve, while a decrease in the temperature produces immediately a responsive contraction of the fluid and a gradual opening of the valve. Thus, the action of the regulators is positive and so reliable as to make them suitable for even the most delicate manufacturing processes as well as for ordinary room temperature regulation.

Steam, Water and Gas Valves

The Sarco Regulators operate steam, water or gas valves, and have been widely adopted. They can be supplied with reverse valves to open with rise of temperature.
How Sarco Regulators Operate

In its essentials the SARCO Temperature Regulator consists of a tube "A" (the thermostatic element) containing a readily expansible, heavy hydro-carbon oil, which, on being heated, generates a pressure that is transmitted through a capillary "D" to a tube "G" (the control element), where it moves a packless piston to operate the valve "K."

Thermostat "A" and control "G," in communication through "D," a fine bore heavy-wall copper tube, form a closed system, hermetically sealed.

The corrugated tombac tube "B" in thermostat, the length of which is controlled by the adjusting screw "C," serves solely to vary the temperature at which the regulator valve functions, this being accomplished by changing its length in the thermostat. It will be observed that if its length is increased, the oil has less space for expansion and consequently the valve will be actuated at a lower temperature. If it is contracted by turning the regulator head, the valve operates at a higher temperature.

Control "G" contains corrugated tubing "F," which is exposed to the expansive force of liquid in "A" transmitted through "D," and thus acts through piston "H" to move valve stem "I" and open or close valve as may be desired.

The spring "J" is opposed to the direction of expansion and tends to keep the valve "K" open.

HOW SARCO TEMPERATURE REGULATORS WORK

(The sketches are diagrammatic only and are not intended to show method of installation. Advice on this when requested will be gladly furnished on receipt of drawing or blueprint of Supply Lines and Apparatus.)

If a metal cylinder completely filled with oil were hermetically sealed and then heated, the oil would expand with such great force as to split the cylinder. This same pressure is utilized in the SARCO temperature regulator. Referring to the illustration below, the oil cylinder communicates through a pipe with another cylinder in which there is a piston, the entire system being completely oil filled. The piston in the piston cylinder actuates a valve. If the oil cylinder is immersed in a tank containing the fluid, temperature of which is to be regulated and that tank is heated, say by a gas flame, the supply of gas to which is regulated by the supply valve, the mode of operation is obvious. When the temperature of the tank rises, heating the oil in the oil cylinder, the expanded oil pushing the piston outward in its cylinder and closing down the supply valve, thus reducing the gas flame. If on the other hand the tank temperature falls, the oil in the cylinder cools and contracts, thus allowing the piston in the piston cylinder to go back under the influence of a spring (not shown) opening the supply valve and thus turning the gas flame higher.

Were the piston in the piston cylinder of the conventional type, trouble would ensue because obviously successful operation requires that the oil system be absolutely tight; the escape of even a minute quantity of oil altering the whole setting. In other words, it is imperative that the piston sealing be leakproof, capable of withstanding the enormous pressures which are involved, and at the same time frictionless. Here the SARCO spirally corrugated tube comes into play, a section of the same being hermetically attached to the outer surface of the piston at one end, and to the inner skirt of the oil cylinder at the other end, as shown in the illustration below. The SARCO spirally corrugated tube will withstand pressures in excess of three thousand pounds per square inch.

While the regulating system as so far described is complete and would be commercially operative, it is naturally desirable to add some means of adjusting the temperature setting. This is accomplished by having the connection tube issue from the side of the oil cylinder instead of from the top, and then inserting from above a piston which can be adjusted up or down by a regulator rod. When adjusted downward the temperature in the tank and evidently rise less before pressure is transmitted through the connection tube to close the supply valve, and if adjusted upward the temperature must rise higher before closing will take place. The construction is shown in the illustration below. It will be seen that SARCO spirally corrugated tubing is again brought into service to provide a pressure-proof packless flexible fit.

This describes all of the elements of the SARCO regulator with the exception of a relief element which will yield if the pressure after the control valve has been closed should for some special reason continue to rise and exceed even the high limit of strength of the SARCO tubing. That element is a special heavy spring interposed between the manually adjustable head of the rod in the oil cylinder and the piston which the rod pushes. The spring strength is such that it will yield when pressure is too high, restoring itself to normal length when normal conditions are resumed.

Dear Sir;

Re. Gordon's School, Punnichy. Report No.5.

Since my report of Dec. 26th last nothing has been done on this job, although delivery of material is still going on. The cut stone is all on the site and most of the window sash. Sand is being delivered steadily. The weather in the West continues very severe and no building operations involving brick and concrete work are going on.

I am enclosing herewith a third certificate for Messrs. Shoquist Bros., amounting to $17649.00, also copy of their third progress estimate. You will notice that this is dated Jan. 4th; the reason for the delay being that I was not satisfied that the money they were receiving was being used to pay for material on the job. I have been in touch with the Dominion Bridge Co., the Regina Sash & Door Factory, and the North American Lumber & Supply Co., and found that no steel, no millwork, and no brick and tile had been paid for. Of course I had checked up on wages and local cartage previously. I wrote Messrs. Shoquist Bros. that I would not issue further certificates until these accounts had been met; and I am now assured by the N.A.L. Co. who are supplying all brick and tile, cement, lime etc., that their accounts have been met. None of these supply people appear to be worrying about their account, but as the specifications call for regular payments I am insisting upon them.

Your obedient servant,

Principal wants, and herewith enclose you a blueprint of same; together with copy of my bill of material taken off to get a figure from the local lumber yard on materials. With the lumber bill at $490.95 I have figured that the hardware, paint, and labor would run the total cost to $700.00. What do you think of carrying the two class rooms the full length of the end projections; cutting out the bath room and putting them on the inside in place of the store rooms. As they would be right on the vent shaft I think it would not be so bad; many of the hotels have bath rooms with only artificial light now; in fact the new C.P.R hotel in Regina is one of such. The large bedroom space is not needed and I think some arrangement could be worked out satisfactorily to give the extra class room length.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Scott,

With reference to the letter from the Honourable Minister of Labour with regard to the Gordon's School I have to say that when the contract was let last fall it was understood that the work was to be proceeded with throughout the winter when weather conditions were favourable, and work proceeded up to the latter part of December when weather became so cold that it was impossible to lay the brick and be sure of a satisfactory job. The brick walls in this building are supporting walls and great care has therefore to be taken in building in order to avoid unnecessary settlement.

When I was in Punnichy last fall in discussing this building with Mr. Swan, Inspector of Construction I emphasized that it was the Department's wish that as much work as possible be done during the winter months, but that of course he would have to use his judgment when the weather became severe. From the last report received from Mr. Swan he advises that the work will proceed just as soon as the weather moderates sufficiently to be sure of a good job with the brick work.

Dear Sir:

Re. Gordon's School, Punnichy.

During the past two weeks work has gone on steadily except for a few hours on certain days when it was considered too cold to lay brick in the mornings until the weather had warmed up. The weather generally has been good during the day, but the nights are still cold. I am still having the sand and water heated before mortar is mixed, and slaked lime is being kept in a closed and heated shed.

The walls of the main portion of the building are up to the top of the ground floor level, and we have two floors of the steel joists on. The changes to enlarge the classrooms, sanctioned in your telegram of last week, will be carried out, and I have given the contractors a sketch of the changed layout. Enclosed you will find two photographs showing condition of the building at present.

Dear Sir:

As per conversation with you this afternoon with reference to the special burning equipment for Sask. Lignite coal, might say, that we have installed same in the following buildings during the past season:

Pat Burns & Company, Adanac Brewery, Bartleman Apts., Balfour Apts., Victoria Park Building, Broder Building, Champlain Hotel, Duncan Motors, Westman Chambers, Wood Vallance, Ltd., Queen City Cleaners, Davin School, Normal School, Haultain School, St. Augustine Separate School, Kitchener School, School Board Office, Bruce Apartments and several others.

The results obtained, in all cases, have been highly satisfactory, in no case have our savings shown under 20%, several of them between 25 and 30%, while at least four show as high as 40% reduction in fuel costs with less labour and higher efficiency.

We supply special non-sifting grates of the shaker type yet flexible, and allowing 40% air circulation, also forced draft equipment supplied by motor with fan attached and entered through the side of the ashpit wall under the grates and equipped with mercury steam pressure controls, so that the Engineer can regulate same as desired, for instance, if he desires three pound steam pressure he can set his control to cut off and set same to cut in again at any point under three pounds, making a narrow or wide range as desired.

Lignite coal burns with the long flame so that if the boilers have not been installed we would appreciate if possible a higher setting which can easily be arranged with the manufacturer. In the Davin Public School, Regina, we have a special setting with the boiler five feet off the grates and this sixteen room school was heated during our coldest January, 1930, at an average of $6.21 per day (and the system includes air-washers and vacuum ventilators) being a record for Western Canada in fuel costs and efficiency.

The Separate School Board advises me that our equipment in St. Augustine School has resulted in a saving of 40% reduction in costs with less labour.
If the higher set boiler can be arranged we would recommend at least thirty-six inches from grates to boiler, will assure us of good combustion, as the old theory of setting the boiler close to the grates has been exploded.

Furthermore, when a plant is equipped for burning Lignite coal it will burn any grade of coal with much higher efficiency, while on the other hand a plant set up in the regular way will not burn Sask. Lignite satisfactorily.

The Hulson grate is an American grate built in Keokuk, Iowa, and sells at approximately $21.50 per square foot.

The Pyramid Grate is built by the Riley Engineering Company of Toronto and sells at approximately $17.50 per square foot. The blower and controls sell according to the square foot of grate area.

It is usually arranged with manufacturer when installing our equipment to have the boilers shipped less the grates, thereby saving cost of the regular grate.

If there is any further information which you require will be pleased to give same at your convenience.

Thanking you, we are,

Yours very truly,

LIGNITE EQUIPMENT LIMITED

(Sgd.) J.A. Erskine
Manager.

Dear Sir;

Re: Gordon's School Punnichy.

Report No.7.

Since March 31st, we have had very good weather and good progress has been made with the brickwork. In another week's time most of the sixteen bricklayers will be away. The only concrete that has been run up to the present is the roof over the laundry and generator room, but we now intend to work on this with a large gang, and with the nights getting free of frost there is now no danger of having concrete frozen. I enclose four photographs showing the state of the building on April 9th.

The Principal, Rev. Stanford, has asked me to say that he wants to build a trench silo for use at the school, and would like to have the concrete walls put in by the contractors; can he have your authority to do this as an extra?

He also stated, when I discussed the placing of the laundry machinery with him, that they needed a rinsing tank between the washer and the extractor. He states that a galvanised iron one costing about fifteen dollars would do, and is asking that this be included.

I might mention that I have taken up the matter of running the laundry machinery with the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co. and R.A. Lister Co. and have decided to run the machinery from a line shaft driven by an electric motor from the electric plant. The total power required if all machines are running is 2½ H.P., and the Lister people state that their plant will take care of a 5 H.P.

Yours obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

P.S. The trench silo will be 100' x 16' x 10'.

Dear Sir;

Re. Gordons School, Punnichy, Sask. Report No.9.

Since April 26th there has been a good showing made on the interior work at the school. Most of the partitions are now up and practically all the strapping of exterior walls is in place. The back plastering is on in most of the rooms, and the plasterers are at work on walls and ceilings in the basement of the north wing. The plumbing is all roughed in and I will have a water test on the stacks on Monday. The steam lines have all been run and ceilings are being lathed.

All concrete is finished with the exception of the roof slab over the chapel and the basement floors.

We are now excavating for the tile drain from Laundry and rainwater tank overflow which will connect up beyond the septic tank.

Today the roofers started on the tar and gravel roof, and with a week of good weather the building will have a tight roof on.

We have found good clean sand on the reserve which is first rate for plastering, and the contractors have arranged with the Indians to supply all of this.

In going over the matter of cupboards the Principal has pointed out that none have been arranged for in the upper dormitories, and he thinks that these are very necessary. Will you please let me have your opinion on these at an early date?

Your obedient servant,

Dear sir;

Re: Gordon's School, Punnichy, Sask. Report No.10.

Since my last report most of the first and second costs of plaster have been put on although none has been done in the Chapel. The fire escapes and steel stairs are being erected and these should be in within a few days. Owing to several spells of rain and windy weather the roofer has not yet finished the tar and gravel roofs. Those of the north and south wings and the centre wing are finished, and a day or so with good weather will see these of the Chapel and Laundry finished.

The painters have started on the frames. In placing the grounds for blackboards in the class rooms it has come to our attention that the blackboard area is not quite up to the amount required by the Dept. of Education of the province of Saskatchewan. Could we arrange for about sixteen of the walls opposite the windows to have boards? I am arranging with the contractor to have an iron band and brace rod from the kitchen chimney to the chapel roof; this was put on the old chimney if you remember after we found that there was quite a sway to the chimney in a wind.

I have had the plasterers run a large quantity of lime for the putty coat so that there will be no danger of it going into the walls too new. As the building is shaping up now I think it should be substantially finished by the first of July.

I have not yet had your authority to place cupboards in the upper dormitories.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Mr. Erskine:

It affords me great pleasure in testifying regarding the efficiency of your Equipment for burning Lignite Coal. I have just made a check up on our cost figures and the following results testify better than I can as to really how efficient your system is.

The School Board is convinced of the wisdom in using the Forced Draft System in burning lignite together with your Coal Gas Burner. The System was first installed in the Haultain School and there we have had it in use long enough to make a comparison. From July 1927 to June 30th, 1928, Haultain School cost us $1706.60, whereas, the next year, after we had installed the Lignite Equipment, the cost was reduced to $1027.81. Our new Davis School, which went into operation last September cost us from September 1st, 1929 to April 1st, 1930, only $768.37, whereas, the Strathcona School, which is a slightly smaller school, but which, is operating without the Equipment, cost us $1056.46 for the same period, and the Thomson School, which has an Oil Burning Equipment, ran up to approximately $2125.13.

Last year we converted the Kitchener School, consisting of twenty rooms, to the System and also installed in our new Administrative Building.

This year we are building a large 20 roomed School on the North Side and a large addition to the Lakeview School. We are putting in new equipment in the Lakeview School for the entire building. Both these large buildings will have installed your Lignite Burning Equipment including the Forced Draft, Special Grates and Coal Gas Burners. We are also changing over the Albert Street School from Oil to Lignite Equipment this year. That will give us a total of six Schools and our office building equipped in the same manner.

We are delighted with the results, as shown above, and feel that it is only fair to the Ratepayers of the City of Regina that the School Board should take every advantage to save money for them.

Yours very truly,

(Signed) E.O. Walker.

Dear Mr.Orr;

Re.Gordon School.

As this job progresses I become convinced that Shoquist Bros., are not very satisfactory as regards their methods of financing. Once or twice I have delayed their certificates on account of complaints from some of their supply people. Alex Young Ltd.of Regina who supplied the cut stone were not at all satisfied with the payments they were getting, and threatened to put a lien on the building. Of course I immediately got in touch with Shoquists and asked for instant settlement, and then wrote the other firms supplying material; stating the amounts I had certified to as far as they were concerned and asking if they were satisfied with their payments. This brought forth an indignant letter from Shoquists as they stated that the Department had held them up, but after I had pointed out otherwise they were more or less apologetic, and promised that things would be looked after better. Yesterday I get a wire from the North American Lumber & Supply Co.of Winnipeg, stating that they can get no satisfaction by mail or wire from Shoquists, and for me to protect their interest to the extent of $6000.00. Before I issue another certificate I shall ask the contractors to supply me with a letter from the various subcontractors and supply houses stating that each is satisfied with their payments to date.

I intend to keep this matter checked up, but thought you might like to know this more or less confidentially, as I personally feel that they are a little out of their depth in running a job of this size. Should they be low on the Muskowequan I believe that the Department would do well to make a careful check-up before awarding the contract. As far as Gordons is concerned they have a pretty fair foreman on the job and I am keeping them checked up.

This is written to you personally unless you wish to impart the information to the Deputy Minister.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Re: Gordon's School, Punnichy, Sask. Report No. 13.

Since June 21st only fair progress has been made; there being delay in shipping the doors from the mill, and delay on getting the machine for rubbing down the terrazzo floors. At present things are going along very well; most of the windows have been hung, also many of the doors, the plasterers are through except for the laundry ceiling, which we are holding up on account of machinery shifting brackets etc., and the usual patching up after other trades.

The laundry machinery is all in place but not connected up. The electrical plant has been installed and light on in some of the rooms. Yesterday the heating system was steamed up, and for the next three days it will be checked over with steam on. The pump and motor for the water system is not yet on the job; at present we are using a small one for supplying water on the job. The pressure tanks and the filtration plant are all ready to connect up. Many of the plumbing fixtures are now installed, and the plumbers are working right along. May I suggest that the Department insist upon a thoroughly competent engineer being placed in charge of all the machinery as soon as the building is ready to be handed over. My personal experience with Gordon's school in the past has been that the Church hire cheap men who know very little about such plants, with the consequent trouble and expense on the machinery. With the splendid layout that they have to start with it seems a pity that any Tom, Dick, or Harry should be allowed to gain experience by experimenting with it.

The exterior brickwork of building has now been cleaned down and cleaning up of materials around building is in progress. The contractors delivered "Sterling" slate for the blackboards but I have refused to allow this to go in. I have not yet received your acceptance of the price on the painting of concrete floors.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;

Re: Gordon's School, Punnichy, Sask. Report No. 14.

The painters are now well along with this job, and the plasterers are through except for the few places where patching up is necessary.

There has been some delay over the linoleum but I am assured that it has been shipped through the Hudson's Bay Co., and will be on the job any day now.

The water supply pump and engine is not yet satisfactory; an electric one was tried but did not do the work. At present we have a temporary engine on the pump, but it is the intention to use an electric motor.

The ash hoist has not yet arrived on the job, but is on the way. The laundry machinery has not yet been connected up, as the pulleys are not on the job.

On receipt of your telegram the contractors were given instructions regarding the painting of concrete floors, and installing of cupboards in upper dormitories.

I have received a figure of $39160.00, for the fixtures required by the Rev. Principal, and enclose herewith list submitted by the contractors, and under separate cover blueprints showing items figured on.

This figure includes all painting, hardware etc., and the installing.

The contractors are now clearing up around the building, and shipping their equipment away, although I expect that they will have a few men at work in the building for two or three weeks yet.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
List of outside buildings required for the school:
Supplementary to the list of Furniture and Furnishings requested by Mr. Gurney Orr.

1 Store house, large enough to contain 300 bags flour, 50 bags rolled oats etc., 50 bags bran, shorts etc.
(We have never had and there is not in the new school, provision for storing flour etc. in any quantity. If we can buy our flour etc. in large quantities, i.e. for six or twelve months, we can buy more cheaply and economically.)

1 or more Granaries for the storage of feed oats, barley etc. for the stock, cattle horses and pigs and poultry. We shall need room for at least 3000 bushels this year as we have seeded 60 bushel acres to oats, 20 to barley. At present we have no granaries and have to store our feed in an old shed left behind by the workmen when the school was first built.
The above buildings should be either of metal or metal lined as this country is infested by rats which gnaw their way into any ordinary lumber building.

1 Six ft fence to enclose the Girl's playground.

1 Trench silo, to hold 200 tons of ensilage for the cattle feed in the winter.

300 loads of Gravel to grade us around the new school when finished, to prevent mud from being brought into the school during wet weather.

Some screen windows to cover the whole window for the school. The present specifications call for half screens on all windows except the casements. This must have been an oversight as with both top and bottom sashes opening or opening, it will be impossible to ventilate properly i.e. from the top, or if the windows are opened at the top, to keep flies etc. out. If all windows cannot be thus fixed, may we have some for dormitories and school rooms and play rooms.

Hon. J.C. Elliott,

House of Commons,

Dear Sir:

We wired you this A.M. with reference to interview with the Hon. Minister in charge of Indian Affairs regarding the installation of Lignite Burning Equipment in their new residential schools under construction at Punnichy, Lestock and Brandon and trust that you have been able to spare a few moments.

The approximate cost of the installation for the Brandon building is $1590.00, while at Punnichy it is $629.00 plus supervision.

The tenders are now being called for the Lestock school and we have not been advised of the grate area of boilers, so, that we are not prepared to give estimate until we receive this information, but can assure their department, that our work is being done and supervised by outstanding Consulting Engineers and, unless, the boilers are suitable for our equipment, where we are satisfied the investment will be returned in savings within a period of three years, we do not recommend the installation.

We trust that you have received favourable report from your Mr. Hamel, heating engineer, regarding the Regina and Moose Jaw post-offices and will appreciate very much your early attention regarding same, as all grates have got to be made to order and takes us from 30 to 35 days to get delivery of these and as the period is short in this country, where boilers are not in use, we have to make hay while the sun shines.

Thanking you for an early reply, we are,

Yours very truly,

LIGNITE EQUIPMENT LIMITED.

JAE/mb.

Dear Sir:

We have been in communication with your Department several times with reference to equipping your new buildings on the Prairie Provinces for the burning of Lignite coal, but, apparently we are unable to get any action on this matter.

We are equipping practically all the new buildings under construction in the West with suitable burning equipment for Lignite coal and we pleased to say that the results being obtained in economy and efficiency warrant the investment. The Provincial Governments are undertaking to equip all Public buildings for the burning of Lignite coal and we feel that, if the facts were before your Department we should receive some of the business.

We wrote you in connection with the Punnichy, Lestock, Brandon and Birtle Indian Residential Schools, but, so far, have been unable to make any progress.

We might just mention that in connection with the above Schools, although completed, all that is necessary on our part is to remove the grates and install our own, also the forced draft and pressure controls. This does not deface the boiler in any way, nor does it limit you to any coal, in fact, with our equipment completely installed more economy and efficiency can be obtained with any grade of coal than under the old system, while with the old method Lignite coal cannot be burnt properly.

With reference to tenders being called for Public building at Arcola and Kamsack wish you would give the matter of having our equipment installed, your attention.

Thanking you for your early reply, we are,

Yours very truly,

LIGNITE EQUIPMENT LTD.

Manager.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th. instant No. 121-1-5, enclosing for my comment and recommendation a list of outbuildings, etc., requested by the Rev. Principal of the Gordon's Indian Residential School, and reply to say that it has always been my idea that we should have a suitable granary at this institution for the storing of seed and feed. We should also have a fence around the playground, but I would not, under any circumstances, allow Mr. Stanford to have anything to do with this. He is not qualified, and is absolutely incompetent. He has had no experience in schools, and his advice on matters of this kind should not be accepted.

I notice also that he proposes having gravel put on top of the clay around the school. This would be a nice mess, and would tear the floors and linoleum all up in a short time. This is a matter that can be left until we have a Principal at this school who understands something about business.

-I note-

The Secretary,

Ottawa.
I note that Mr. Stanford has submitted a list of furnishings for this school. I am surprised to know that his recommendation has been acted upon, while at the same time the Department advises me to take up with the church authorities the matter of dispensing with his services. Memorandum: July 25th, 1947.

Re: Water Supply, Gordon's Indian School,
Punnichy, Sask.

Further to our memorandum of June 20th, and enclosed copy of report from the International Water Supply Limited concerning the test drilling undertaken at the above School, we have now received a report from Mr. Mitchell dated attch. July 17th, 1947, duplicate copies of which are attached herewith.

You will note that apparently two wells were drilled at the Gordon School in 1921, one to a depth of 350' and the other to 540'. It is possible that the records of these two wells might be found in the closed files of the Water Power Bureau or Indian Affairs, but we understand they are not available in the present office of the Water Power Bureau.

It is apparent that the general topography and the information secured in regard to the two wells previously drilled convinced Mr. Mitchell that drilling a 400' well in the vicinity of the School would not produce a suitable water supply.

The source of water which is recommended for development is a spring situated about one mile and a quarter south east from the School and was reported on previously by Mr. Lyon. There seems to be some little doubt as to whether this spring will produce a constant supply of water sufficient for the entire consumption at the School as it appears to be influenced by rainfall to some degree.

Mr. Mitchell suggests testing the capacity of the spring recommended for development which, of course, should be done if it is desired to abandon the present water supply from the lake, but it would appear to us that even tests which might prove satisfactory over a period of two weeks would not guarantee sufficient water for any subsequent period, as the flow might be dependent, to a great extent, on climatic conditions.

For the present it would seem necessary to haul drinking water from the spring and if Indian Affairs consider the expenditure of $24,000.00, to connect the spring by a gravity line to the School, will be an advantage and an economy over hauling the water by team or truck, this gravity line could be installed.

The decision as to whether the new gravity line from the spring should be built will depend not only on the present cost of hauling drinking water, but also on whether the cycle of dry years is near its end and whether water in the lake

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,

Department of Mines and Resources,

MEMORANDUM:

To: C.M. Walker, Esq.,
District Engineer.

Re: Water Supply, Gordon Indian School,
Punnichy, Sask.

On receipt of a wire from Mr. Hainstock of the International Water Supply Limited, Regina, dated May 21st, in which advice was given that he expected his drilling outfit to be at Punnichy and Gordon Indian School on May the 22nd, arrangements were made to leave Riding Mountain Park the following day.

Arriving at Punnichy May 22nd at 6 P.M. and after dinner, accompanied by Mr. Hainstock, the district manager of the International Water Supply, and Mr. Davis, the Indian Agent, an inspection of the present water facilities was made at Gordon's Indian School. Mr. Lyons' report of the test holes previously made during 1946 was read; the location of the holes inspected and discussed, from which Mr. Hainstock was of the opinion it would be useless to test the same ground, as the surface features did not indicate that the catchment area would produce any great quantities of water, in view that the gravel exposures were cut up by so many depressions which are primarily supported on a clay stratum. Mr. McKe, the principal of the school, informed us that he had been in conversation with Mr. W. Swan, Secretary of the Touchwood division, some days previously, during which Mr. Swan had informed him that during the building of the school the area in the vicinity of the school had also been drilled by an outfit from Regina in 1921. With this information it was decided by Mr. Hainstock and myself that we contact Mr. Swan the following day.

May 23rd, while the drilling outfit was being overhauled, Mr. Hainstock and I interviewed Mr. Swan, who informed us that he had been Clerk-of-Works during the building of the school, and although he had searched through his records for the log of the holes drilled, mentioned by Mr. Davis, he had been unable to locate them. However, he produced some letters from his files from the driller - Mr. Dempsey, who was doing the testing for the firm of McPherson and Thomas, Regina, and instructions from Mr. French of the Water Powers & Reclamation Branch. These letters indicated that during 1921 two holes had been drilled in the vicinity of the school, one to a depth of about 350 feet, and the other to a depth of 540 feet. The letter referring to the second hole did not say the test was at a depth of 540 feet, but mentioned that in drawing the pipe they had drawn 350 feet of pipe and had to leave 150 feet in the hole on account of saving. Mr. Swan informed us that both tests were unsatisfactory and as the work had been done under the Direction of the Water Powers and Reclamation Department the logs would be on record at Ottawa. In view that the tests were unsatisfactory Mr. Hainstock and I considered it would be useless to test the same ground.

Accompanied by Mr. Hainstock we returned to the school and scouted the district within a radius of a mile of the school buildings and decided that a No.1 test hole on the main drainage water course from the Fort Lakes, which at one time drained through the water supply

CANADA
lakes at the school, would be the most likely place to intercept any underground flowage or water-bearing gravel and, as the following day was a holiday, the drill was set up at this point on the 26th of May. Mr. Hainstock's report and log covers the result of this and other tests made during the following two weeks.

During the 24th, 25th and 26th I reconnoitered the district around the school for a distance of about four miles, inspecting various surface wells, also water holes or wells in the vicinity of springs which appeared to have surfaced at one time, and which had been dug or opened up by the Indians who had farmed these areas for many years. All of the surface wells were not over sixteen feet deep, had about four feet of water and had either been deepened or redug at various times. Many of the Indians hauled water from their neighbour's well on account of their own drying up or the water unfit for use. In the area that lies to the southeast of the school one and a quarter to two and a half miles where the springs or seepages occur, the older Indians informed me that their water holes or wells dug in the vicinity of these seepages had never dried up during their lifetime and some of these Indians were over fifty years of age.

On the 27th Mr. Hainstock returned from Regina and checked up with his driller on test hole No.1. From the records of the drilling and from his experience of testing in terminal moraine deposits he was convinced that it would be useless to continue the test on No.1 much further as the bottom of the test hole was 37 feet below the bottom of the lake and no water-bearing gravel had been encountered. I detailed to him my reconnaissance of the previous three days and accompanied by Mr. Hainstock covered some of the ground reconnoitered, and inspected the well at the spring one and a quarter miles southeast of the school. The possibilities here appeared to be more promising than elsewhere, and it was decided to make a pump test and if favourable, test the depth of the water-bearing gravel that the seepage came from.

On the 28th a small thirty gallon a minute pump was set up at the spring well. The cribbing of the well is four feet square and the water level before pumping, 1.3 feet below ground level, and the depth of water about three feet. After the water had been lowered, the well cleaned out, and a pump made, the inflow showed a very strong stream coming from the high ground with seepage around the low side of the cribbing. After pumping for thirty minutes the water level in an old water hole about twenty feet south of the cribbed well was taken down about two inches. A rough flow test was made by cutting down the rating of the pump to about ten gallons per minute and after the inflow had about balanced the discharge, the flow into a forty-five gallon drum showed a discharge of about ten to twelve gallons per minute, and Mr. Hainstock and myself considered a test hole should be put down to find the depth of the water-bearing gravel above the ground that the strong stream appeared to come from and the drilling rig was moved to drill hole No.2 at the spring.

On May 29th the crew got the rig set up at No.2 hole and commenced drilling at 3:00 P.M. Progress was very slow, as the bit was encountering numerous boulders. By 4:30 P.M., the hole had been driven about six feet only and was still in boulder gravel. The work was suspended for the day and drilling resumed during the forenoon of May 30th, but progress was even slower than the previous afternoon, and after the drill bit had been bouncing around on the top of a hard granite boulder at about eight feet deep for about thirty minutes without making any headway, the driller decided that he would either have to set the rig up in another location or test the bottom of the well by deepening. As Mr. Hainstock had left for Yorkton to inspect .......
Yorkton to inspect other work, the Company was working on, I approved of the driller's suggestion to deepen the well and this work was proceeded with. After deepening about 1.5 feet, and before quitting time, I had the driller make a rough flow test for about ten minutes. The deepening of the well appeared to have improved the inflow to about twenty-five gallons per minute, which was nearly double of the test made on May 28th without any deepening. As the Drilling Company employees only work five days a week, work was suspended until Monday June 2nd.

The work which had been done so far at this spring seepage appeared worth while, so I decided to run a traverse line and gather sufficient data with respect to its location, elevation, etc. I arranged with Mr. Mayo, the school principal, to loan me some Indian boys and during the next three days a traverse line has been cut and chained from the school to the spring, and levels completed by June 4th. From the data collected I have prepared a sketch plan and profile which can be used to secure a cost of developing this spring as a gravity water supply for the Gordon Indian School. The level datum is assumed, and is that established by Mr. Lyons. The bearing of the traverse line is referred to the tie made on the 1/4 post found on the northern boundary of Section 5, Township 27, Range 17, West of the 9th Meridian.

On Monday June 2nd the drillers continued the deepening of the well and carried the cribbing down to ground level. The cribbing has a depth of 5-6 feet and the well was deepened or dished in the bottom about two feet below the crib walls. To do so, two pumps throwing about 75 G.P.M. had to be used to keep the water sufficiently low to work in. The excavation was still in boulder gravel when the work reached this depth, and further deepening could not be proceeded with as the capacity of the two pumps was insufficient to keep the water low enough to work in. With one pump throwing about 45 G.P.M. the water level gained very rapidly for about five minutes after the other pump was cut out, after which it was much slower. Pumping was stopped at 4:30 P.M. and the well allowed to recover over night. Mr. Hainstock arrived at Punichy at 9:00 P.M. and arranged with his driller to make a flow test the following day.

On June 3rd Mr. Hainstock and the driller made a flow test of the deepened well at the spring. Inspection of this recovery indicated that the water level had recovered to within .75 feet of normal during the sixteen hours the pump was off. After pumping commenced the two pumps were run to full capacity for two hours, the discharge being taken about fifty feet away from the well. During dead low a sample of the water coming in from the spring was taken, after which the pumps were cut out and the water allowed to return to within 24" of normal. The smaller pump was adjusted to throw about 20 gals. per minute and continued pumping for five hours and fifteen minutes without showing more than a rise of 24" above normal, with no variation. A Flow test was made at 3:00 P.M. and a 45 gallon drum was filled in two minutes ten seconds, indicating that the average inflow at 24" below normal was approximately 21.4 Imperial gallons per minute. A sample of the water was taken and the pumps cut out at 3:15 P.M. Recovery after five minute duration, after pump was cut, was four-tenths and much slower until at two hours the well had recovered to within .75 tenths of normal. During the five hours and fifteen minutes of pumping that day, it is estimated that approximately 8,000 gals. had been pumped and as the tailwater from the pump was fifty feet away, a very small amount of the discharge had recirculated. It was also noted that during all the time the test was being made, the water hole twenty feet south of the well, was only drawn down fourteen inches.

Before Mr. Hainstock left for Regina he arranged for his driller to make test No.3 at Station 444 on the traverse line, in the hope that the water-bearing gravel of the spring might extend north towards the school. The result of this test is shown in the log of hole No.3 .......
hole No.3. From my own observation of the terrain I am of the opinion that the water-bearing gravel of the spring does not extend further north than the ridge that the traverse line crosses at P.I. Station 54 + 21.9 and that the gravel lifts onto a clay boulder formation that has considerable depth and extends throughout the area. It is doubtful if a deep hole down to bedrock could intercept any significant amount that had been laid down intermittently with the glacial clay formation. If deeper gravel beds were intercepted below the zone of the glacial clay, the waters found would be more highly mineralized than the gravel formation at the spring, and would not be fit for domestic purposes.

During the night of June 3rd a heavy thunder and rainstorm prevailed throughout the district for about three hours and when the site of the spring was inspected on the morning of June 4th the water layer in the well was 5 feet above normal, indicating that climatic conditions will affect the water level of the well. This, of course, is to be expected of any natural well. It is doubtful if the spring seepage contributed to any great extent the rise above normal water level recorded. For example, the surface well of Mr. Fisher's shown on the plan about 2000 feet west of the school, has a depth of about sixteen feet and has a depth of five feet of water generally throughout the season, but last fall, after the September rains, before freeze-up, the depth of the water was approximately nine feet. This was indicated by the rim of ice that still hung in the orifice when the well was inspected. No check was made on this well as to what effect the rainstorms of June 3rd had on the water level, but no doubt it was much higher than when inspected.

On June 5th the drillers got the rig set up at No.3 test hole by noon and had drilled thirty-one feet by 4:45 P.M. and were drilling in sandy clay with boulders. Water level at the spring well had gained .22 feet during the twenty-four hours and the water level, according to the datum, was 126.89 feet, approximately twelve feet above maintained water level in the storage tank at the school. Test drilling at No.3 hole was resumed on Friday June 6th, and by 4:30 P.M. had reached a depth of sixty-two feet. Drilling was much slower than the previous afternoon in view that some boulders were encountered and had to be drilled. At quitting time the bit was bounding on another large boulder and as there would be a layoff during Saturday and Sunday I left Punnichy for Regina at 7:00 P.M.

On June 7th at Regina I contacted Mr. Hainstock and discussed the drilling programme and advised him of the results of the test at No.3 up to closing time on the 6th. From his conversation he was doubtful that the test would be successful. However, I suggested that he continue the drilling and give the ground a thorough test and advise your office of the location of the hole drilled and the results. Mr. Hainstock conveyed to me the partial analyses he had got of the water samples taken at the spring, and these looked encouraging. Later I contacted Mr. Ostrander, Superintendent of Indian Affairs stationed at Regina and discussed the results of the present drilling test made at Gordon's Indian School and enquired about the records of the test made in 1921, but as his files on Punnichy only went as far back as 1926 he was unable to give me anything on these tests.

During my ...................
During my conversations with Mr. Ostrender in connection with the present and the future possibilities of securing a satisfactory water supply for the school, I outlined the unsatisfactory results that had been obtained so far from the drilling tests and informed him that if the department of Indian Affairs were prepared to expend about $20,000.00, a gravity pipeline could be laid from the spring 6600 feet to the school, providing that the analysis of the water samples taken was satisfactory and that if a daily pumping test of say two weeks indicated that a daily consumption of eight or ten thousand gallons per day would not deplete the storage of the water-bearing gravel from where the spring was drawing its supply. To this Mr. Ostrender was of the opinion that if the spring could not be developed and no usable supply could be found from drilling, with sufficient flow to meet the needs of the school, it would mean the closing of the school and the abandonment of a large investment by the government, or continuing the present costly and very unsatisfactory method of pumping, flushing water from the water supply lake and drawing on rain water from the roofs and supplying ice or hauling water from a surface well for drinking and domestic use.

After reviewing Mr. Hainstock's report dated June 17th I agreed with him that, of the various sites investigated, the spring, one and a quarter (¼) miles southeast of the school, offers the best possibility of obtaining a fairly good water supply, that would provide the estimated consumption of seven to ten thousand gallons per day required for the school, but I am not prepared to say that I would place the area as suspect, in view that the well did not fully recover before the heavy rainfall of the evening of June 3rd. From observations taken by me after the pumping of five and three hours during May 28th and 30th at a rate of about ten to fifteen gallons per minute, and before any deepening had been done, the recovery record of one-tenth below normal after a two day layoff would appear reasonable, and that after deepening on June 2nd and pumping for about seven hours at a rate of forty-sixty gallons per minute it is reasonable to say that static head would have lowered somewhat and that a full recovery to the original water level could not be expected, but the recovery after that day's pumping, and a night's layoff which was recorded as 7½ tenths below normal, compares very favourably with the recovery of June 3rd pumping test of five hours at the rate of about twenty gallons per minute, when after the pumps had been cut out, and after a two hour layoff, the water level had again recovered to within 7½ tenths below normal.

The facts as outlined here indicate that the spring at this well, if fully tested by a daily pumping test as previously suggested, has possibilities of a potential water supply that would meet the needs of the school. A summary estimate of cost of installing a three inch gravity pipeline, using G.I.P., is attached hereto. A four inch wood stave pipe could be used and would probably reduce the cost below $20,000.00.

The spring reported by Mr. Lyons and referred to in head office letter of June 20th is the water hole mentioned in this report, and is situated about twenty feet south of the cribbed well. At the time of Mr. Lyons' inspection the cribbed well was not dug. During the tests at this cribbed well we pumped this water hole out and the rough test of flow showed up considerably better than that mentioned by Mr. Lyons, but as the cribbed well was better for our tests the drillers did not concentrate in doing any work, or keeping any records of the actual flow, other than tab the drop in water level during the other tests.

With the twelve foot head available between water level at the spring, and the present maintained water level of the tank at the school, using a three inch pipeline there would be a hydraulic flow of 202 I.G.P.M., which is approximately three times the school's present sixteen hour daily consumption.
consumption. From the tests made at the spring on June the 2nd the test indicated an inflow of over twenty-one Imperial gallons per minute, in view of which - if the well stands up under further testing, the school's requirements can be met with a greater degree of assurance.

Discharge to the tank could be got by placing a booster pump on the main about Station 2900 and using the hydraulic flow of about 460 Imperial gallons per minute, which is available under the thirty-five feet head at this point. Further, if it is desirable to construct a new tank at the school to receive the spring water, additional head could be got by placing the new tank at a lower level and maintain a lower water level. In this case it would probably be necessary to place the pressure tank pump lower also.
