Dear Mr. Ostrander:

Re: Heating Plant - Gordon Residential School - Touchwood, Sask.

As requested by you, I am forwarding report on the heating plant at the above noted building.

I will refer you to your discussion with myself and Mr. Simonson, the heating Engineer, at the above noted school on Wednesday, September 3rd. Upon inspection of the existing plant I found it to be in a filthy condition and utterly inadequate to service the building in which it is located. I might further say that the entire plant has suffered from improper care and might I recommend that in the event of a new plant being installed that every reasonable effort be made to obtain the services of a competent engineer who could maintain and generally look after the plant in a manner so that you might hope for efficient heating.

I found that the drawings which you gave me of the building were not correct as to detail. It, therefore, will be necessary to arrange the radiation differently than shown on the drawings and it was agreed between Mr. Simonson and myself that he, as the contractor, would furnish and re-arrange adequate radiation and guarantee the efficient operation of the same for a period of not less than one year. I might further point out that you were singularly fortunate in obtaining the services of Mr. Simonson as he is undoubtedly one of the outstanding heating engineers in this province and a very highly qualified man.

Referring to the heating plant and hot water and steam supply, I would recommend that all the existing plants be discarded—that is, the existing heating boiler, the existing water heater, and the existing vertical high pressure boiler. I might say that none of these are, in my considered opinion, serviceable and by re-using any portion of the equipment you would merely be giving yourself a source of continual grief. I would, therefore, recommend that new boilers...
recommend that new boilers as indicated on the plans and specifications be installed and that a high pressure boiler of the horizontal type of about 15 H.P., operating at 100 pounds pressure, be installed. In the matter of indirect water heating, I would recommend that the indirect type of below water in boiler heater be installed. This could be made to operate from either the low pressure or the high pressure boiler. The high pressure boiler would furnish you with adequate hot water for summer use and if desired the heater could be operated from the low pressure boiler during the heating season. The object of recommending this type of installation is that there are no reducing valves or valves which might give a source of trouble and this, in my opinion, is as nearly a fool-proof installation as it is possible to install. The building being some considerable distance from town, I feel that every effort should be made to so design and install the plant that the man in charge would be able to carry out his own running repairs.

After having studied the building and become conversant with the problems and difficulties which have existed in the past, I would very strongly recommend the installation of a Dunham vacuum pump in the system. The boiler being located very much in one corner of the building, the entire plant will at all times tend to collect condensation and siltage and by use of the Dunham vacuum type pump you would be assured of ample heat in the most remote corner of the building. I might say that the Dunham type vacuum would entail a slightly greater cost, but I feel that such an expenditure would be justified in the interests of efficiency and simplicity. It would also tend to show a very decided reduction in fuel costs. Inspection of all the plumbing and heating pipe indicates that it is badly pitted and rusted, and I have reason to believe that this condition has been caused through the chemical action of the salts and minerals present in the water. The water is definitely of a very poor nature for boiler service. You indicated to me that a soft water tank was proposed. While soft water is a very good source of supply, at the same time it is not to be recommended unless handled by a highly skilled engineer. I would, therefore, recommend that a water softener be installed which would soften all hot water used in the building and at the same time soften the water used in the boilers. I would not recommend softening all water in the building as a very large amount is used for sanitary purposes and it would take an enormously large installation to handle the water which would be used.

I further found a great many cracked radiators and the Principal of the School informed me that members of the staff opened the windows, turned off the radiators, and left them, thus causing through condensation the radiators to freeze up and split. To overcome this condition, I would recommend that...
would recommend that small vents be bored or cut in the valve faces so that these radiators can never be shut off tight, thus a limited supply of steam will pass through them, overcoming the frost hazard.

The water filter which is presently in the building is obsolete and worn out and definitely beyond repair and as you indicate a new water supply is being led into the building and I feel quite sure that with a softener your water troubles will be over.

I found that all the main traps in the building were worn out, rusted and scaled. This condition unquestionably has arisen through use of very impure water in the boiler and possibly to a large extent caused through the improper handling of the heating at the boiler source. I further found that a great deal of sediment is present in many of the radiators. These will have to be removed, flushed and, in many cases, acid treated to make them clean.

I find that the existing smoke stack is of sufficient capacity to handle the proposed new boiler installation.

I am pleased to be able to inform you that Mr. Simonson has been successful in obtaining the services of Shannon Brothers, the general contractors, to carry out the necessary structural alterations. They are a highly reputable firm and you can rest assured that the work is in good and safe hands and will be well carried out. I propose visiting the school again in company with Mr. Shannon and going over the necessary structural alterations.

Mr. Simonson and myself prepared final details of the foregoing proposal before he left Saskatoon yesterday and as soon as possible I will forward to you sketch copies of the proposed new lay-out. As you will readily appreciate, it is going to take some considerable time to round up sources of material supply and prices, but I have been assured by Mr. Simonson that he will have a detailed price to you at the earliest possible moment.

Trusting that the foregoing is sufficiently comprehensive in information and will prove of value to you and assure you of my willing assistance in any further manner that you desire.

Yours very truly,

Dear Colonel Neary,

I have your letter 121-1-5 (WT) of the 9th and have read with interest the letter of Inspector Ostrander dated September 4th.

I may say that I have just returned from visiting the Gordon's School and was disappointed to find that no work had been commenced either on the water or heating systems. We have been maintaining a staff of workers at the school in anticipation of the early arrival of a group of workmen. The report I received on the ground was to the effect that the contractors are now beginning to search for material and that the date when the gang will reach the school is altogether uncertain. This places us in a very difficult position as we are paying salaries needlessly, without much hope of income, and if we dispense with the services of the present workers it may be hard to secure others when the need arises.

May I pass on also the serious warning uttered by our acting-principal, Mr. Mayo, in regard to the danger of damage by frost. The nights in the West are already cold and the building is now chilled through and really unfit for occupation. If nothing is done to maintain even a minimum amount of heat, any day there is serious risk that very costly damage will be done to the whole building when more severe frosts occur. Possibly the contractors have this danger in mind but they will need to move quickly in view of the date we have now reached.

A letter from the Director sent to this office on August 13th spoke of the decision to delay the opening of the school for at least two months. My impression gained on the ground was that it will certainly be the beginning of 1948 before the school is ready for occupation and
may very well be much later than this. In these circumstances, I trust that consideration will be given to the matter of responsibility for the building as we plainly cannot be expected to maintain an acting-principal and other workers to protect the interests of the Department in this building.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

N.A. Alderwood

Superintendent.

October 29, 1947.

Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School - Punnichy, Sask.

We have your letter of October 20th, 1947, and your remarks have been given careful consideration and it is noted that Mr. Ramage visited the school at the request of the Wm. George Co. We have reviewed Mr. Ramage's report on the present condition of the mechanical services at the school and have noted his comments and recommendations.

Regarding errors you report as appearing in our drawings for this project, we are mailing, under separate cover, one set of floor plans. It is possible that our engineer could have overlooked some minor changes when carrying out his inspection as he was mainly concerned with gathering data relative to the condition of the mechanical equipment and the piping distribution, and it seems unlikely to us that major changes to the building structure would have escaped his notice.

If changes in the position of partitions or other features have been carried out since the building was erected, would you kindly mark them on the set of plans and return them to this office as soon as possible. Upon receipt of same we will make the necessary adjustments to our layout which will include changes to radiator sizes as may be required.

You have stated that the only price you expect to receive will be based on Mr. Ramage's layout with Mr. Simsonson's approval. This Service has given a great deal of thoughtful consideration to the requirements, and with the data and observations noted by our engineer on his inspection, the layout was devised which will provide a satisfactory job. Should this layout be affected by changes that you state exist, our design will be adjusted to suit same, and you will be required to assure this office that prices are based on the drawings and specifications prepared by this Service.

Up to the present time, we can offer no comment on how a permanent source of water supply will be made available. As you are aware, drilling operations have been carried out during the past summer and the results showed little promise of an unfailing source of water.

Insofar as that matter affects the heating and domestic water problem, you will no doubt recall that in May 10th of this year at a meeting held in Colonel Neary's office, you suggested the use of roof water for boiler feed purposes and that our design should be prepared accordingly. It was agreed that this was feasible and since there are two 10,000 gallon capacity concrete storage tanks adjacent to the building, there would appear to be no difficulty in utilizing one of them for the collection and storage of roof water.

PRÉCIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Requesting authority to carry out major repairs to the heating system at the Gordon's Indian Residential School, in the Touchwood Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan.

Two copies of Order-in-Council are required.
November 13, 1947.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 Estimates, Indian Affairs branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for major repairs to the heating system at the Gordon's Indian Residential School, in the Touchwood Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part, as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ............";

THAT a competent plumbing contracting firm, namely the William George Plumbing Company, of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, who, our officials state, are very reliable contractors, have agreed to undertake immediately the repairs required to the heating system at the said school on the basis of cost plus fifteen per cent;

THAT the William George Plumbing Company estimate that the total expenditure will vary between thirty-three thousand and forty thousand dollars;

THAT it is considered that the repairs to the heating system at this school constitute a pressing emergency and are within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited, and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the major repairs required to the heating system at the said school, as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the school may be re-opened in the near future.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Repairs to plumbing and heating system,
Gordon's Indian Residential School

Attached is a draft Order-in-Council for the granting of a contract for plumbing and heating repairs at the Gordon's Indian Residential School. This school, which has a pupilage of 130, has been closed since the first of July, due to the fact that we were unable to interest a contractor in the repairs necessary to again open this institution, we have had much difficulty at this school, due to the lack of water and also due to the alkalinity of the water when it is available. These salts have corroded the entire heating system. Not only is the boiler completely useless, but the pipes and the radiators are rotted through to a dangerous extent.

When delays occurred in interesting a contractor in this work it was hoped that we could use the old boiler sufficiently to at least keep a little heat in the building and thus prevent frost damage. When Mr. Ostrander, our Inspector of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan, finally persuaded the William George Plumbing Company of Prince Albert to tender on this work, it was decided to send Mr. Hargreaves of the Surveys and Engineering Branch to Regina, in order to give him technical advice. Mr. Hargreaves has just wired his Branch, informing them that the old boiler is completely useless and that unless a new boiler is obtained at once serious frost damage will result to this valuable school. Mr. Ostrander and Mr. Hargreaves also long distanced our Superintendent of Education on Saturday, urging upon him the necessity of placing an order for a new boiler to be delivered.
within three or four weeks. Pending your approval, they were told to have the William George Plumbing Company place an order for this new boiler.

It is hoped that this order in Council can be proceeded with as expeditiously as possible. Included in our supplementary estimates for 1947-48 is the sum of $35,200.00 which we were advised by our Surveys and Engineering Branch as being necessary for the completion of the work at this school.

Director

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for major repairs to the heating system at the Gordon's Indian Residential School, in the Touchwood Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part, as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........";

THAT a competent plumbing contracting firm, namely the William George Plumbing Company, of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, who, our officials state, are very reliable contractors, have agreed to undertake immediately the repairs required to the heating system at the said school on the basis of cost plus fifteen per cent.

THAT it is considered that the repairs to the heating system at this school constitute a pressing emergency and are within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited, and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the major repairs required to the heating system at the said school, as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the school may be re-opened in the near future.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources
Ottawa, November 10, 1947.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Attached is a draft Order in Council for the granting of a contract for plumbing and heating repairs at the Gordon's Indian Residential School. This school has been closed since the first of September due to the fact that we were unable to interest a contractor in the repairs necessary to again open this institution. We have had much difficulty at this school, due to the lack of water and also due to the alkalinity of the water when it is available. These salts have corroded the entire heating system. Not only is the boiler completely useless, but the pipes and the radiators are rotted through to a dangerous extent.

When delays occurred in interesting a contractor in this work it was hoped that we could use the old boiler sufficiently to at least keep a little heat in the building and thus prevent frost damage.

When Mr. Ostrander, our Inspector of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan, finally persuaded the William George Plumbing Company of Prince Albert to tender on this work, it was decided to send Mr. Hargreaves of the Surveys and Engineering Branch to Regina, in order to give him technical advice.

Mr. Hargreaves has just wired his Branch, informing them that the old boiler is completely useless and that unless a new boiler is obtained at once serious frost damage will result to this valuable school. Mr. Ostrander and Mr. Hargreaves also long distanced our Superintendent of Education on Saturday, urging upon him the necessity of placing an order for a new boiler to be delivered within three or four weeks. Pending your approval, they were told to have the William George Plumbing Company place an order for this new boiler.
It is hoped that this order in Council can be proceeded with as expeditiously as possible. Included in our supplementary estimates for 1947-48 is the sum of $35,000.00 which we were advised by our Surveys and Engineering Branch as necessary for the completion of the work at this school.

Director.
It is hoped that this order in Council can be proceeded with as expeditiously as possible. Included in our supplementary estimates for 1947-48 is the sum of $35,000.00 which we were advised by our Surveys and Engineering Branch as necessary for the completion of the work at this school.

Director.

With reference to Mr. Hoey's memorandum of October 30th, bearing Mr. Wardle's notation of November 1st, 1947, in connection with the above, you are advised that our Mr. Hargreaves was sent to Regina on November 3rd in accordance with Mr. Hoey's request.

In brief summary, it could be stated that the difficulties which arose in connection with getting an estimate from the contractor, along with some criticisms brought to our attention by Inspector Ostrander were successfully dealt with, and a complete understanding arrived at.

Enlarging somewhat on the above, a meeting was held at which Mr. Thompson, Resident Architect Dominion Department of Public Works, Mr. Ramage, Heating Engineer from his staff, Mr. Simonson, Proprietor of the Wm. George Plumbing Co. of Prince Albert, Mr. Lunam, a General Contractor, Inspector Ostrander, Mr. Indian Agent Davis and our officer were present.

After a lengthy discussion of the matter, which began immediately after our officer's arrival, it was decided to drive to Punnichy the following morning. Consequently Messrs. Simonson, Ramage, Ostrander, Davis and Hargreaves left Regina at 8:15 a.m. on the 6th instant and after arriving at the school, inspected the boiler room equipment and piping distribution system.

Rapid deterioration had taken place in the boiler, and it was found to be in a very bad state. It was agreed by everyone present that no further repairs could be successfully carried out. Ways and means were discussed at considerable length to determine the best and quickest method of providing temporary heat in order to protect the building from serious frost damage. It was agreed that the most practical solution would be to procure one new boiler immediately along with a new vacuum return line pump and to make essential piping changes, all of which it is felt will provide enough heat for the building to protect it from damage during this winter.

As a result of this discussion, Mr. Hargreaves wired this office requesting immediate authority to instruct Mr. Simonson to proceed along these lines. Mr. Ostrander telephoned Col. Neary, Saturday the 8th instant, and our officer also spoke with him.

Mr. Hoey

Our officer succeeded in obtaining a verbal estimate from Mr. Simonson on the basis of the layout designed and specifications prepared by this Service. Mr. Simonson stated that his firm estimated that the cost of this work would be in the neighbourhood of $35,500.00. He also stated that his firm would be prepared to carry it out on the basis of cost plus 15 per cent.

This is considered reasonable. Recent wage increases to plumbers and steam fitters in the province along with certain provincial regulations governing statutory holidays and annual holidays with pay, has increased the contractors' operating overhead expenses approximately 30 per cent.

As a result of this visit our officer reports that he has satisfied himself as to the ability of the Wm. George Plumbing Co. to carry out the renovations if awarded the contract. Inquiries showed that Mr. Simonson is highly thought of in the province and is considered to be very reliable. In view of the foregoing it is felt that no better arrangement could be made.

Incidentally, Inspector Ostrander has been trying since June to get competent estimates but has not succeeded in interesting any other firm. If this work is awarded to the Wm. George Plumbing Co. at once, it is estimated that it will take from now to the beginning of April before all the equipment and piping can be purchased and delivered to the school. At such time the contractor has agreed, if awarded the work, to provide sufficient staff along with a competent foreman to complete the work in from eight to ten weeks, and that he will give the project his personal attention.

It was arranged with Mr. Mayo, the Acting Principal of the school, to provide board and lodgings for the contractor's workmen and amicable arrangements in connection with board and lodging was arrived at tentatively between Mr. Mayo and Mr. Simonson.

It is our recommendation, therefore, that the work be awarded to the Wm. George Plumbing Co. of Prince Albert on cost plus 15 per cent basis. It is further recommended that the contractor be informed as soon as possible that he is to be awarded this work in order that he may start gathering equipment and piping, as well as to make an immediate start on the very urgent repairs necessary to protect the building from frost damage.

Mr. Simonson stated that he would confirm his verbal estimate, by letter to this office, at the earliest possible moment.

"In replying to your Airmail letter of the 11th instant with reference to the last paragraph of your Airmail letter of November 14th, re the above, I would advise that on receipt of yours of November 14th, an effort was made to allocate a Junior Engineer to undertake the testing of the spring at Gordon Indian Residential School.

After having considered the situation, I decided that the said test would be begun on or about the middle of January, 1948.

My intention is, providing weather and other conditions are suitable, to send J.H. Mitchell along with a Junior Engineer to the Gordon Indian Residential School about the middle of January. Mr. Mitchell will remain there for several days - or until such time as the gasoline pump, etc., have been installed and until he has had an opportunity to instruct the Junior Engineer who will remain there, as to duties required. We are in receipt of Mr. Hoey's memorandum of the 20th instant, bearing your notation of the 20th, together with attached copies of letters from Mr. Cook and Mr. Ostrander, with reference to the above.

It is felt that it would be in order at this time to briefly review the circumstances in connection with the repairs and revisions projected for this school.

On the occasion of our Mr. Hargreave's visit to Punnichy last November, when he was accompanied by Mr. Simonson, the Contractor, and Inspector Ostrander, it was unanimously agreed that immediate temporary repairs to some of the important return flues be made together with the installation of one of the new boilers and the new vacuum pump. Mr. Simonson felt that he would be able to procure the necessary equipment to carry out this phase of the work.

Consequently, he was authorized to order the boiler and pump at once and to make such repairs to the piping as appeared to be absolutely essential, in order that some heat may be distributed throughout the building to prevent frost damage.

At the same time, the Contractor pointed out that it would take all winter to assemble supplies necessary to carry out the complete work, and that he intended to devote his energies to this end, and felt reasonably sure that such supplies would be on hand by the end of March, at which time he would put a full staff of workmen on the job and carry it through to completion without delay.

We have written to the Contractor several times for a statement of his progress, and his last letter to us, which was dated February 16th, outlined that the supply situation had been most difficult and that he had been keeping in touch with the school through Mr. Davis, the Indian Agent.

The Contractor also stated in his letter that the centre section of the building has been kept heated, and gave assurance that the building had suffered no damage. He concluded by stating that the work would be under full swing on Monday, February 23rd, and that it would continue without delay until completion. While he has made no direct statement to the effect that any work has been done at the school, we have had, up to now, no reason to doubt that the temporary repairs referred to in paragraph three (3) and four (4) have not been executed.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Mr. Ostander's letter of February 7th and Mr. Cook's letter of February 11th, both addressed to Col. Neary, state that no work of any kind has been done to date. Mr. Cook also states that radiators and pipes have frozen in the extreme ends of the building.

We are writing to the Contractor again and submitting point blank questions in an effort to get a clear understanding as to what has actually taken place. We have a great deal of confidence in the ability and judgment of this Contractor, and feel that he will be able to give assurance that nothing has been neglected in connection with the work.

Upon receipt of his reply you will be further advised.

Indian Agent Davis reports that Mr. Mitchell has been carrying out a pumping test at the spring for three (3) days, and that 8,000 gallons of water is being discharged in seven (7) hours. Also that the water level in the spring goes down about 2'-3" and recovers its level within 10 minutes after the pump has stopped.

It is stated that the average daily consumption of water by the school is about 4,000 gallons, which seems to us to be rather conservative.

Nevertheless, if the present rate of discharge and recovery can be maintained for a period of one (1) month it would appear reasonable to assume that the spring can supply the school with the required amount of water.

When Mr. Mitchell's report is received at the conclusion of his month's test, further comment will be submitted regarding this source of water supply.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Government Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

Further to our memorandum of February 25th in connection with the above, you are advised that we are in receipt of a letter from the William George Plumbing Company who are the contractors for the above work.

We are satisfied that the contractor has conscientiously done everything possible in the interest of this school. Equipment and piping have been in very short supply, particularly in the West, and it is only through the contractors wide business connection that he has been able to finally assemble enough material to make a start.

To date, one of the new heating boilers has been installed along with the new vacuum pump; and some radiators have been connected up temporarily. Part of the staff started work on February 23rd when enough materials had been delivered to the school to make it worth while. The contractor put a night fireman on duty to ensure that there would be no further interruption in the supply of heat.

While it is true that some radiators and pipes have been frozen, the contractor states that Mr. Mayo the Principal of the school, informed him that fewer freeze-ups took place this winter than the previous ones. This is due in part to the fact that it has been possible to keep all interior doors open, as the school children are not present. Also, under the contractors direction, the old boiler was carefully nursed along by the school staff, and the contractor gives full credit to them for their co-operation. He also states definitely that no damage to the plaster has occurred.

There is still a critical shortage of pipe required for the job, but promise of delivery has been expected and if fulfilled the contractor expects that the work can be completed by the end of May, provided also that the high pressure boiler is delivered on the date promised.

It is no surprise to this Division that some radiators and pipes have frozen, as our inspection revealed them to be badly clogged, particularly at the ends of the building. The original system was not installed in such a manner as to provide good drainage, and with the scaling of the pipes caused in part by hard water and mediocre maintenance efforts by previously employed boiler room staff, such a state of affairs was bound to develop.

We would like once more to reiterate our confidence in the William George Plumbing Company. We have every reason to feel that they have left no stone unturned in making every effort to get ahead with this work. As additional supplies are received they will put more men on the job in order to hasten the date of completion.

It is felt that the contents of this memorandum should reassure Mr. Hoey that everything possible is being done in the interest of the job, and should enable him to deal with the criticism as received from Mr. Cook, Superintendent, M.S.C.C.

Memorandum:

Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

Further to our memorandum of March 23rd you are advised that our Mr. Hargreaves has returned from a visit to the above school, and it is felt advisable to submit a complete report outlining the situation there.

As you are aware, Mr. Christian Simonson, the sole owner of the William George Plumbing Company of Prince Albert, with whom the Department had a Contract Agreement, died suddenly at the school on March 21st. Previous to his death he had requested the Chief Engineer to send Mr. Hargreaves to Punnichy to inspect the work already carried out and to consult with him in connection with the shortage of materials which he felt was delaying the work.

In the interests of the Department, our Officer was instructed to obtain all information relative to any arrangements which may have been made by the William George Plumbing Company to carry on with the work, and to advise the Department if such arrangements appeared to be satisfactory. As a result of his visit, the following summary of affairs as he found them is outlined below.

The late Mr. Simonson had drawn up a will leaving all to his wife and appointing her as executrix with a provision added, appointing his close friend, Mr. Nelson Grosser of Prince Albert as executor in the event of Mrs. Simonson's demise.

Within a short time after Mr. Simonson's death Mr. Grosser offered his full support to enable Mrs. Simonson to complete any and all outstanding commitments made by the William George Plumbing Company.

She expressed a desire to carry on with the work at the Gordon School, subject of course to the approval of the Department and immediately called Mr. Grosser into consultation to obtain his advice.

Mr. Grosser immediately consulted with the Bank of Nova Scotia of Prince Albert who had been given Power of Attorney by the late Contractor, and he at once deposited the sum of $15,000.00 to cover any outstanding accounts against the William George Plumbing Company. At the request of Mrs. Simonson he assumed active management of the Company and upon learning of our Officer's visit to the job immediately sent a foreman to the school to take charge of further operations, and came down himself for a full discussion.

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.
Our Officer reports that he is satisfied with the work carried out to date and estimates that it is approximately one-third complete. The new Foreman has been continuously employed by the William George Company for over 16 years and in our Officer's opinion is fully qualified and competent. This opinion was arrived at following a full two days discussion between the Foreman and our Representative.

Our Officer requested Mr. Grosser to have a document drawn up and legally attested to the effect that he was assuming all financial responsibility and direction of the William George Plumbing Company's affairs. This he promised to do as soon as he returned to Prince Albert and it is expected that this document will be forwarded to the Department shortly.

After thoroughly considering and reviewing the entire project on the job, it is recommended that the William George Plumbing Company should be allowed to carry out the balance of the work at the school. The Foreman and Mechanics now on the job were carefully sized up and examined by our Officer who states they are all men of wide experience in the class of work now being executed. It is also felt that Mr. Grosser is in a very favourable position with regard to obtaining the balance of supplies necessary, as he is well known and has a wide connection in the West.

Messrs Salter and Frith, Barristers and Solicitors, have provided us with a copy of the late Mr. Simonson's will and have advised that we can obtain full information regarding Mr. Grosser's financial standing and business ability from the legal branch of the Bank of Nova Scotia.

In conclusion we estimate that the job will be completed about the end of June or early in July, at which time it is contemplated sending our Heating Engineer to make an inspection before the final certificates are paid. It is also felt that the Indian Affairs Branch should be apprised of the contents of this memorandum.

Chief Engineer.

Our heating engineer on his recent visit to the school, investigated the possibility of using stokers in connection with the new boilers now being installed.

Memorandum

Re: Water Supply - Gordon's I.R. School Saskatchewan.

Referring to the instructions received from Mr. Wardle under date of October 16th, 1947, we have now received a report from Mr. Cornish dated April 9th with final report by Mr. Robinson dated March 22nd giving the results of a pumping test made of the spring situated 1½ miles south-east of the Gordon Indian School.

Attached herewith you will find duplicate copies of the report from Mr. Cornish and the final report from Mr. Robinson with attached blueprints showing recovery of water level and the elevation of water table in connection with this pumping test. You will note that Mr. Cornish gives us a favourable report but we should remember that the test only took place between February 4th and March 17th and we have no definite indication as to what the results might have been had we been able to test the spring over a period of three months during the winter.

On March 14th the weather changed and there was indication that very soon the snow would melt and that water would then find its way into the spring from the surface of the ground, thereby interfering with any further accurate test of the capacity of the spring.

The results of the test are certainly more favourable than we anticipated but we still think that the attached reports are just a trifle optimistic. We have written to Mr. Cornish to secure a final recommendation for this job with an up-to-date estimate of cost in connection with the proposal to pipe the water from the spring into the school.

Also attached herewith in duplicate is a water analysis of a sample taken at the end of the pumping test when the water table was at a low point. You will note that the water is hard and the total solids are high although perhaps not too high, and iron is present in the proportion of 3.5 parts per million. There is also a remark on the analysis to the effect that the water has a decided odour due to sulphur gas.

Dear Sir,- Re: Water Supply, Gordon's Indian School,
Punnichy, Sask.

I have reviewed Mr. Robinson's weekly reports on the pumping tests made at the spring well one and a quarter miles southeast of the Gordon's Indian School, and I am of the opinion that if a reservoir of say 10,000 gallon capacity were constructed at the site of the spring, an intermittent discharge of approximately 10,000 gals per day would be available from this source during the winter months for a drawdown of one (1) foot below depressed water table that would be established after the pipeline was installed and the spring had assumed its level of equilibrium from the heavy drain of pumping that would be necessary during the excavation of the spring reservoir. The opinion is based, primarily, on the pump test made from the 1st of March to the 17th, when operations were closed down.

For convenience and study of the result of the pumping test I have prepared a chart of the drawdown and water table readings reduced to the assumed elevation established by Mr. Lyons, and used by me in making the preliminary surveys last June. From this Chart, blue-prints of which are attached, it will be noted that during the first twenty-eight days of the test, while pumping at rates of 20, 15, 12 and 10 gals per minute, for a period of approximately seven (7) hours each day, recovery steadily declined, and water table was lowered from elevation 125.21 to elevation 123.16, a lowering of the water table 2.05 feet. Continued pumping during the next fifteen days, at 10 g.p.m., recovery was maintained at this elevation, which would indicate that the spring had reached a point of equilibrium for a discharge of approximately 4200 gals for seven (7) hours pumping for a depressed drawdown of approximately one (1) foot.

On the recovery chart, blue-print of which is attached, it will be noted that after the pump was cut out on February 8th the recovery was 7/10ths of one foot during the first hour; February 12th was .67 tenths of one foot; February 16th to March 3rd the recovery was slightly over 1/6 tenths of one foot and that, during the last fourteen days of the test was consistent .68 tenths of one foot in one hour. The recovery during the first five minutes after the pump was cut, during the early stages of the test averaged about .275 tenths of a foot, whereas after the discharge was cut to 10 g.p.m. the recovery during the first five minutes was .30 tenths of a foot. This compares very favourably with the test made in June 1947 when recovery was .40 tenths during the first five minutes. The exact time of full recovery was not clocked. However, the extension of the curve shown for March 4th to March 17th would indicate that total recovery to water table elevation 123.16 would probably be reached in six to seven hours after the pump was cut.

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Division,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

If we assume .......
If we assume that static water table was attained during the last fifteen days of the test for a discharge of 10 gals. per minute and a draw down of approximately one foot, it would appear that the spring could be pumped intermittently two times per twenty-four hours at least for a discharge of approximately 7200 gals., and it is possible to install a three or four inch gravity pipeline and a 10,000 gal. storage at the springs from which the school's present daily requirements of 6,000 gals can be drawn, this volume of water could be discharged at the school tank at the rate of 16 or 35 gal. per minute, depending on size of pipe installed, and if the drawdown reached the elevation 122.21 established during the present test, which is slightly over 8 feet above the water level to be maintained at the school tanks.

If we use a pipeline of 3" diameter, the 6,000 gals. could be delivered at the school tank in six hours and fifteen minutes, whereas by using a 4" line this amount of water could be delivered in approximately three hours. The longer periods between the discharge of 6,000 gals at the school would permit of the unused 1200 gals that the area is capable of producing to build up and gradually raise the water table, thus producing a larger storage in the gravel, thereby increasing the inflow to probably 10,000 gals per day during the winter months. Generally most springs are affected by surface precipitation during the summer months and as this was evidenced from last summer's test, it would appear that the spring is capable of supplying the school's present requirement of at least 6,000 gals per day for a drawdown that will not impair the head necessary to transport the water by gravity to the school.

Yours faithfully,

C. E. Cornish,
Supervising Engineer.

Test Procedure: The general procedure was as follows:

A tent and stove were placed at the well, and a 1½" London Centrifugal Pump was set up over the well connected to about seven feet of two inch suction pipe and 175 feet of ¾" discharge pipe. All the piping was arranged so that it was possible to drain the entire assembly at the end of each day's pumping.

The water level in the well was recorded before the test began, and this was used as a datum at assumed elevation 135.21. The pump was then operated at from ten (10) to twenty (20) gallons per minute, five to seven hours per day for the test period of six weeks. Detailed figures of each day's discharge have been given in the various weekly reports. Readings were taken of water level each morning, average draw-down, discharge; and recovery of water level for periods up to one hour after the pump was stopped.

Discharge was checked periodically by noting the time taken to fill a forty-five (45) gallon drum; and a graph showing typical rates of recovery is attached.

Temperature and weather readings were also included in the weekly reports.

Conclusions:

1. During the test period approximately 235,000 gallons were pumped from the spring, and the static water level was lowered 2.05 feet below datum. This would appear to be sufficient water to serve the school for about two months.

2. In spite of the erratic conditions of pumping at 10 g.p.m., it is felt that a continued flow of at least 10 g.p.m. is available. There was no evidence of recirculation, and as the ground was frozen solidly, all the water pumped must have come from storage in the gravel bed.

3. These tests appear to show that sufficient water is available in the spring to supply from four thousand to six thousand (4,000 to 6,000) gallons per day during the winter season, and hence that the school's present water requirements could be filled from it.

W. G. Robinson,
Junior Engineer.

Memorandum:

Re: Water Supply, Gordon's Indian Residential School.

In reply to head office letter dated April 16th, your File I.A. 1580-4, with reference to the pumping tests for a water supply for the Gordon Indian Residential School, etc., I would advise that the reference to a 3" and 4" gravity pipeline in my report on the review of the pumping test was merely to indicate the advantages between the use of a four inch pipe. Personally I would recommend the placement of a 4" main and as a wood stave pipe would be less costly than using either galvanized iron pipe or cast iron pipe, would reduce this cost considerably, and if carefully installed and maintained, would meet the requirements of the proposed low pressure main satisfactorily. Cast iron fittings can be supplied to connect all gate valves, tees and fittings to the wood stave pipe.

I attach a revised estimate of cost and a material list to cover the proposed installation. Excavation quantities have been reduced as advantage of lower ground can be taken to reduce cuts than that on which the traverse line was surveyed. Further if the trenching and grading is done by machine and bulldozer, considerable saving might be effected.

In view that the water level at the spring reservoir is close to the surface I have indicated on the blue-print attached that the top of the cribbing be covered by flooring and insulated, also that the walls and roof of the housing be insulated, and it is probable that during the winter months provision may be necessary to keep the interior above freezing point. At the commencement of the tests made in February and March it was necessary to cut a hole through 6" to 8" of ice before the test could be started and after the close of each day's test about 2" of ice formed over night. The insulation provided will prevent this to some extent, but in extremely cold weather it may be necessary to assist the insulation provided by using artificial heat to ward off the extreme temperatures.

I attach copies of recent quotations on wood stave pipe, received from the Canadian Wood Pipe and Tank Limited, Vancouver. Also quotations on Galvanized Iron Pipe and B.I.P., also Cast Iron Pipe from Crane Limited, Calgary. These quotations would indicate that 4" wood stave pipe can be laid down at Punnichy for about $88.00 per 100 ft. with delivery in about four months, and C.I.P., Bell and Spigot at $130.00 per 100 ft. with delivery in six to eight months; 4" galvanized and black iron pipe would be cheaper than the cast iron, and slightly dearer than the wood stave. However, delivery is indefinite on steel pipe and cast iron would not be available until next fall, in view of which it would appear that necessity leaves us with only one choice, that is - wood stave pipe.

Cost installed of wood stave pipe would run $1.10 to $1.20 per foot, whereas cast iron would be about $2.00. Excavation and back-filling has been provided for in the estimate attached hereto. In ordering valves, etcetera provide for type of pipe used.

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Further to our memorandum of April 26th and in reply to your notation on copy of a memorandum from Indian Affairs, dated April 30th, 1948, we are in receipt of a report from Mr. Mitchell, dated April 27th, duplicate copies of which are attached herewith.

You will note the recommendation is for the installation of a 4 inch diameter wood stave pipe from the spring to the school. As the water from the spring is mineralized and alkaline, metal pipe would no doubt after installation deteriorate in carrying capacity due to incrustation, so that the effective life of metal pipe might not exceed that of wood stave pipe. Minerals and chemicals in the water should not affect the carrying capacity of the wood stave pipe to any noticeable extent, and as wood stave pipe is cheaper and delivery more definite, its use is recommended. However, it should be borne in mind that any type of pipe will need maintenance to keep it in good condition, and where the available head and quantity of water is so small, leaks which are allowed to develop might interfere seriously with the delivery of water to the school.

It is quite possible that at the end of a winter, the consumption of water at the school might have to be controlled and rationed so as not to exceed the winter delivery from the spring and this will be especially necessary if leaks develop along the pipe line which are not properly repaired.

You will note the cost of putting the water into the school is estimated at $24,000.00. This cost does not include any expense necessary for softening the water for the laundry if used for that purpose, nor for chlorination which will be needed.

It is presumed that present equipment and arrangements for distributing the water within the school, will be continued as heretofore, and the estimate does not include any changes in this equipment that might later be found necessary.

Whether this new source of water will prove satisfactory for the requirements of the school, can only be determined after the system has been installed. Water obtained within a few feet of the surface of the ground is always liable to fluctuations in quantity due to precipitation and lack of precipitation in the immediate vicinity and might also be subject to reduction of flow, if the underground reservoir should be tapped by other users.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
This latter contingency could perhaps be guarded against on the reserve and prevented.

If Indian Affairs consider that the cost of this work is justified in order to be able to operate the school, then $30,000.00 should be provided. The cost of the work will depend on the amount of the bid received from the contractor and on the manner in which it is proposed to handle the contract, that is whether on unit cost or cost plus fixed fee basis. There will be some delay before work can start and as prices are advancing it seems wise to figure on an additional cost of $6,000.00 over and above the estimate of Mr. Mitchell.

Recent press reports indicate that very heavy precipitation has taken place on the Prairies this Spring, and it might be that the Water Supply Lake has returned, or has partially returned, to its former level and might now contain sufficient water of a satisfactory quality for domestic purposes at the school.

T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir,

As per your request, I am herewith submitting a report on the condition of Witte Deisle engine that recently burnt out a rod bearing, in spite of the fact that the sump was full of good clean oil.

Upon examination I found the crank case dry of oil and the babbit on con rod entirely burned out. Checking further after starting engine (after new bearing was installed) I found the oil pump refused to pump and I had to prime same before it would function. Its operating very erratic, in that the pressure would vary from 0 to 50 lbs pressure.

It would appear to me that the pump or oiling system was at fault. I recommend that this engine be thoroughly checked so as to ascertain the reason for failure of oiling system. I understand this is the second time that this has happened with oil sump full of oil.

I have also reason to believe that the cyl and rings are scored from lack of oil as I noticed quite a bit of blow-by coming from the breather screen.

In view of all this I warn you against running this engine until such times it has been overhauled by a competent mechanic.

Yours very truly,

LARSON & RICHMOND.

When I was in Prince Albert last week Mrs. Alice Simonson, widow of the late Mr. Chris. Simonson, of the William George Plumbing Company, asked me to call and see her as she was quite concerned about instructions which she had received from Mr. T.S. Mills, Chief Engineer, Engineering and Construction Division, Department of Mines and Resources, Lands and Development Branch, to the effect that a vertical high pressure boiler will have to be installed at the Gordon's Indian Residential School instead of the horizontal boiler which has been ordered and delivered at the school.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter which Mrs. Simonson has given me dated June 19th, 1948; copy of a letter from Mr. H.O. Grosser, on behalf of the William George Plumbing Company addressed to Mr. A.H. Hargreaves, 393 Nelson Street, Apartment 8, Ottawa; copy of a letter addressed to Mr. Grosser from Mr. T.S. Mills dated June 5th, 1948; and copy of a letter from Mr. Grosser addressed to Mr. Mills dated June 14th, 1948, on the subject of the boiler.

From Mrs. Simonson's letter it will be seen that she is in a very difficult position. I do not know whether the letter which Mr. Grosser addressed to Mr. Hargreaves received the attention of Mr. Hargreaves but I am inclined to think that it did not. I am of the opinion that the boiler which was ordered by the late Mr. Simonson and delivered at the school was ordered on specifications given to Mr. Simonson by Mr. Hargreaves as Mr. Simonson was working on a cost plus basis with regard to the equipment, and there seems no reason why he should not have ordered the boiler exactly as specified by Mr. Hargreaves. However, the fact remains that the William George Plumbing Company will be out of business at the end of this month as the licenses expire, and employees of the firm have sought and obtained employment elsewhere, expecting that the Gordon's School contract would be completed by that time. If Mrs. Simonson has to dispose of the boiler which has now been delivered, order a vertical boiler, await its delivery in perhaps six months' time, and endeavour to re-engage men for its installation, it will be very difficult for her.

The measurements of the boiler room at the school are in the hands of Mr. Mills and I feel sure that it is possible to install the horizontal boiler either as suggested by Mr. Grosser or to the right of the two low pressure boilers and parallel thereto in such a way that the high pressure boiler will be satisfactory if it is found later necessary to use a stoker. I would strongly recommend that Mrs. Simonson be given instructions to immediately install the horizontal boiler in either one of these two places. In this manner the contract would be completed by the time her licenses expire and while she still has the men to do the work. Also the heating and plumbing will be completed by the 1st of September.

If it is decided to carry out my recommendation Mrs. Simonson should be so instructed by telegram. If the Engineering Branch insist upon the installation of the vertical boiler it will be some months before the contract can be completed and even then, with some difficulty.
I may say that Mrs. Simonson gave me access to all of her records in this connection and I find that the high pressure boiler was not mentioned in the original contract and there is nothing on the files in the office of the William George Company to show when or how the horizontal boiler was ordered by Mr. Simonson. However, there is information supplied by Mr. McKeel, Manager of Western Supplies, Saskatoon, to the effect that Mr. Simonson called on him personally and placed the order for the boiler from particulars which he had in a small notebook and that Mr. Simonson was very specific in placing the order. The notebook in question cannot be found amongst Mr. Simonson's personal effects.

With reference to Department letter of the 22nd ultimo,
File No. 121-1-5 (S.1), addressed to Mr. Fred A. Mayo, Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, in connection with the engine supplied to that school, and which has given unsatisfactory service, I have to say that I was at the school when this engine was examined by Mr. Grosser, of Prince Albert.

I note that in the letter of Mr. Walter M. Petty, Sales Engineer of the Witte Engine Works, addressed to Mainguy's Limited, Montreal, he is under the misapprehension that Mr. Grosser is not competent to criticise this installation. I consider Mr. Grosser very competent. He is the head of the firm of Grosser and Sons, of Prince Albert, who are in the business of rebuilding and re-boring engines, and building and repairing machinery of all types. Mr. Grosser is a man of perhaps fifty-five years of age, with a lifetime of training and experience in such matters, and there are few in this province better qualified to pass judgment on an internal combustion engine.

I have had a further discussion with Mr. Grosser and he emphasized the following points:

1. The engine is too small for the work it is expected to do. It is a 12 h.p. and should be 16 h.p., preferably 20 h.p.

2. Being a Diesel type it is too complicated for satisfactory operation by inexperienced staff such as there has always been at the Gordon's School. It is very difficult to start and at times Mr. Mayo has found it almost impossible to start it. Consequently he has fallen back on the old Lister engine to supply power, and it was intended that the Lister engine should be an auxiliary engine and not have to do most of the work, as it has been doing.

It does not require an expert to know that the lubricating system of the Witte engine has not been satisfactory. Why it is not satisfactory I do not know, but certainly it has given a great deal of trouble. Possibly the excuse made by Mr. Petty that part of the trouble of faulty lubrication may be caused by the engine standing idle for long periods is true. However, when it has been standing idle, this, also, was the fault of the engine as Mr. Mayo had been unable to start it.

At the time the engine was purchased it was quite difficult to get engines of any kind but they should not be very difficult to get now, and I believe the Department should insist that the company who furnished it assume responsibility for immediately putting it in shape to operate if we are to keep it. However, I would much prefer that it be returned to the company and that company, or some other, be requested to supply a less complicated engine, and of at least 16 h.p.

If something is not done very soon about the engine the school will be re-opened with only the old Lister fit to use, and that, too, will break down.

Saskatchewan.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter from Mr. T.S. Mills, Chief Engineer, Lands and Development Services Branch, dated June 28th, 1948, his file I.A. 1580-4, in connection with the horizontal boiler referred to in my letter No. 1149-312-11 AGE, dated June 21st, 1948.

Since writing the letter referred to I have received a letter from Mrs. Simonson on behalf of William George and Company, which reads as follows:

"In connection with the high-pressure boiler for the above project, I am enclosing a letter received from Mr. Mills. Now the question is what to do with the high-pressure boiler delivered to Punnichy? Waiting your kind attention, we are..."

The contract of the William George Plumbing Company is almost completed at the Gordon's School but, of course, a high pressure boiler will not have been installed, and the horizontal boiler in dispute is standing at the school awaiting disposal. When the contract is completed I assume that Mr. Hargreaves will be sent to the Gordon's School for the final inspection. In a conversation with Mr. Grosser, who is Mrs. Simonson's advisor, and who assumed financial responsibility to have the contract completed following the sudden death of Mr. Charles Simonson, he assured me that he had sufficient faith in Mr. Hargreaves' good judgment that he feels Mr. Hargreaves will decide that the horizontal high pressure boiler could be, and should be, installed. Mr. Grosser is firmly of the opinion that there is sufficient room for its installation without interfering with the rest of the plant, and, in his opinion, the horizontal type will be much more satisfactory than will the vertical type boiler which it is contemplated installing some time later. Mr. Grosser gives as his reason for this the fact that the Gordon's School has never had a very satisfactory engineer, and may not have in the future. Mr. Grosser states that the tubes are always covered with rust on the horizontal type boiler, and not with the vertical type boiler; the tubes will give much less trouble and need replacing less often with the horizontal type. He also states replacement of the tubes of the horizontal type boiler will be less difficult than with the vertical type boiler.

I would recommend that the horizontal boiler be left at the school until after Mr. Hargreaves' final inspection and recommendation, and if Mr. Hargreaves recommends installation of the horizontal type boiler it be installed as soon as possible after his inspection, as a high pressure boiler will certainly be needed.

We advised our Director, Mr. R.A. Gibson, by memorandum dated April 24th that we would require $25,000.00 for the fiscal year 1948-49 to complete the above project. In our letter of July 9th we ask for an additional seven to eight thousand dollars, and $7,000.00 was transferred to this Division.

We now find that $17,500.00 only has been received of the original $25,000.00 allotment, and we would therefore ask that you transfer the $7,500.00 balance to this Division. We summarize as follows for your convenience:

| Original Allotment | 25,000.00 |
|-------------------|-----------|
| Additional Allotment | 7,000.00 |
| Funds received to date | 24,500.00 |
| Balance required | 7,500.00 |

$32,000.00

A detailed report will be furnished as soon as we have the Contractor's final accounts. The cost will exceed the original $33,500.00 estimate by a considerable amount, and we cannot promise that the $32,000.00 allotted for the present fiscal year, plus the $12,539.73 spent during 1947-48, will complete the job.

Present indications are that the total cost will be a minimum of $45,000.00 to a maximum of $50,000.00, the more likely figure being $47,000.00. P.O. 4781 places the estimated cost at between $33,000.00 and $40,000.00. Section 3, clause (a) of the contract reads as follows:

It is evident that approval must be secured before we can exceed the $33,500.00 figure. We cannot give exact figures at this time, but "the cost of the work" as defined above, apart from the Contractor's fee, will be from $39,000.00 to $43,500.00 maximum. We are presently holding accounts in excess of the contract estimate of $33,500.00 which cannot be released for payment until we have approval covering the increased cost.

In explanation for the increased cost, we would point to the fact that a repair job cannot be accurately estimated in advance. Necessary replacements often do not become evident until the work gets underway. Heavy expenses, mostly unexpected, were encountered on the project by way of structural changes made which necessitated knocking down concrete partitions, re-bricking etc. This work alone cost $14,470.00, not including the 15% fee. The cost of materials has been on the increase ever since the original estimates were given, and it is not surprising that costs have increased accordingly.

Our Mr. Hargreaves is leaving the end of the week for the West on an inspection tour, and we will give you a detailed report later.

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Sup't. of Welfare & Training,

Capital Theatre Building,
Ottawa, Ontario.

High Pressure Boiler - Gordon's Indian School,

Dear Col. Neary,

In reply to your letter of the 16th instant in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

I think it would be advisable for you to wire the Port Arthur Shipbuilding Co. and insist on the earliest possible delivery of the vertical high pressure boiler.

For your own information we can afford to wait for about a month as the School can not be opened very well before the new water supply system is installed.

I was informed by our Mr. Shaw, before leaving Ottawa, that arrangements were being made to have this work installed as soon as possible. I would imagine that it will take at least a month to complete this phase of the work.

Mr. Mayo, the Principal, informs me that the hard frost can be expected before the middle of October and for that reason every effort should be made to accelerate this work. May I suggest that you telephone Mr. Shaw and point out the importance of having the water line installed as quickly as possible.

I arrived here yesterday afternoon and am starting my inspection today. The boiler room looks very good and we have a plant that should prove to be satisfactory and efficient.

The work at Brandon and Elkhorn has been carried out excellently by the contractor and I have no hesitation in recommending that final payment be made. I expect to spend several days here as there is a lot of checking up to do before I can be sure that all items of the Contract have been carried out.

Sincerely Yours,

Arthur Hargreaves.

Re: Gordon Lake Indian Residential School

Dear Colonel Neary:

I am enclosing a copy of my interim report to Mr. Mills following
a detailed inspection of the work carried out by the William George
Plumbing Company at the above, for your off the record information.

In order to keep our original estimate within the sum of $40,000.00
some items of painting were omitted intentionally from the specifications.

The items referred to include the painting of new radiators, re-built
radiators, domestic hot, cold and return heating piping, and low pressure
steam and return distribution piping throughout the building.

Although there were no written memoranda to this effect placed on our
files, the above action was decided upon during the preparation of the plans
and specifications.

Mr. Mayo, the Principal of the school, has arranged with a local painter
to carry out this work. The painter has estimated that this work can be done
for $420.65 which includes material and labour. The work has already been
started before I arrived and the purpose of this letter is to advise you that
the sum of $420.65 was not included in the William George Plumbing Company's
contract.

After discussing the matter with Mr. Mayo we are wondering if this could
be charged to ordinary maintenance and repairs.

Very truly yours,

A.H. Hargreaves.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT in the 1947-48 estimates of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, funds were provided for carrying out major repairs and replacements to the plumbing and heating system in the Gordon's Indian Residential School, in the Touchwood Agency, Province of Saskatchewan;

THAT drawings and specifications were prepared by the Department, and calls for tender were issued, as a result of which only one tender, that of the firm of William George & Company, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, was submitted on the basis of cost plus fifteen percent (15%) for materials and labour. It was recognized that due to the nature of the work, the total cost would not be definitely known until the work got under way;

THAT Order in Council P.C.4761 dated November 21, 1947, authorized that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion;

THAT upon investigation, it was considered to be in the best public interest to accept the tender submitted by William George and Company of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, whose approximate estimate of the cost of the work was Thirty Three Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($33,500.00) plus a 15% fee;

THAT as the work progressed, additional essential repair items became necessary which together with increases in the cost of labour and materials, and including the Contractor's fee of fifteen percent (15%), have increased the total cost of the repairs to approximately Fifty Four Thousand Dollars ($54,000.00), which, after making provision for supervision, will involve a total estimated expenditure to the Department of Fifty Five Thousand Dollars ($55,000.00);

THAT the work is nearing completion at this date and the Department's supervising officer has reported that the work is satisfactory.
THE undersigned therefore has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for the payment of the additional cost of said repairs—the total estimated expenditure for the said repairs, including that previously authorized, not to exceed Fifty-Five Thousand ($55,000.00) Dollars, the said additional expenditure to be met from the appropriate vote of the Indian Affairs Branch 1948-49 Estimates (Vote 772, Indian Education), Department of Mines and Resources.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.
MEMORANDUM

Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

After a recent inspection trip through the West, our heating engineer submitted a report on the above, and the following is a summary based on the results of his survey:

From a detailed inspection lasting several days, it can be stated that the contractor has carried out the work generally in accordance with the plans and specifications in a competent and satisfactory manner, except that as expected, certain relatively minor items remained to be completed at the time of our officer's visit.

The work in the boiler room deserves special mention, and in spite of many delays caused by shortages of materials and labour difficulties, no effort was spared to carry out the intent of the plans and specifications.

The contractors' men had left the job before our officer arrived, but had stated their intention of returning to complete the work following the inspection.

During the course of the inspection, the late contractors' wife, Mrs. Alice Simonson and her business advisor Mr. Nelson Grosser, visited the school and conferred with our officer who provided them with a list of items of work which had not been carried out, but which it was agreed were part of the contract. It was clearly established after a careful check-up, that the work which remained to be carried out, had not been charged for. Specifically, the items in question included: the installation of wall, floor and ceiling plates throughout the building; the brazing of the radiators in certain rooms; the painting of equipment piping in the boiler room; the installation of a pressure relief valve on a cold water line to the domestic hot water tank and several additional minor items.

Mrs. Simonson agreed to have this work carried out as soon as possible. When this work is completed, it is felt that Indian Superintendent Simpson who was familiarized with the situation, can carry out the final formal inspection and recommend acceptance of the work.

It has been recommended to the Indian Affairs Branch in a previous memorandum, that the 15 horsepower horizontal high pressure boiler ordered in error by the late contractor, be purchased and used at the Cowessess Indian Residential School. This boiler with its accessories including boiler front, grates etc., is at present on the school property and is not being paid for by the contractor. Col. Neary has advised that a purchase order will be issued and the boiler in question will be moved and set up at the Cowessess Indian Residential School.

We are also advised by Col. Neary, that a purchase order has been issued to the Fort Arthur Ship Building Company for a new vertical 10 horsepower high pressure boiler to be set up at the Gordon's School. At his request, our officer made tentative arrangements to have another contractor connect this boiler when it arrives at the School. This work will not be carried out by the William George Plumbing Company.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary,

I was talking to Mr. Macintosh of Banff over the phone in regard to the laying in of our water supply. They are starting the work next week. He says there is no provision or mention made of putting the water into the barns or farmers cottages which will be passed by the main line. I particularly stressed when the survey was being made that provisions be made to take that into account.

We cannot handle stock successfully with no water in barns. It means providing a man and tank to haul and then ice cold water which is not good for stock.

The water line runs between the barns and cottage. The water could be run back in the same ditch from compassion tanks, very little extra digging about 200 ft west to barns and 50 ft east to cottage. I have taken measurements for this and it would take about 1000 ft of piping and I have on hand here that could be used for that purpose 700 ft. It would be a great saving to the Department to do this while the job was in hand than to be doing it later on when the whole distance would have to be again dug for a water supply. I would be very grateful if you would do what you can to ensure us getting the water now.

Yours faithfully,

I would recommend that no action be taken at the present time with regard to the refrigerator, but that provision be made in the Estimates to supply it in the fiscal year 1949-50 if the school has proved, in the meantime, that it is satisfactory in every other way.

Enclosed is copy of a letter from Superintendent S.H. Simpson, of the Touchwood Agency, copy of a letter which he has received from Mr. Mayo, Acting Principal of the Gordon's Indian Residential School, and requisition for a 48" flat work ironer at a cost of $528.00 F.O.B, Winnipeg.

There is no doubt that an ironing machine is needed at the Gordon's School, or the machine will be needed if they ever complete the installation of the water supply. Mr. Mayo asks that the ironing machine be delivered to the school to be on hand for installation at the same time that the high pressure boiler is installed. Of course this would be advisable, but I must say that at this time I am greatly in doubt that the Gordon's School will be open this winter. I have not seen the dragline which was to arrive at the school last week to commence excavating for the installation of the pipe line. However, I do not think it will be suitable for the excavation in view of the fact that many rocks and boulders of all sizes will no doubt be found in the excavation, and I am afraid that quite a number of the boulders will be too large to handle with the dragline scoop. Winter is nearly upon us, when we will have frozen ground to contend with, as well as the boulders.

As I understand the Appropriation for school purposes is not too generous, I see no advantage in spending $528.00 on an ironing machine to stand at the school until next summer before it is used. I would recommend that in the event approval is given to the installation of the ironer requested by Mr. Mayo, no order be placed for one until there is a certainty that the school is about to be re-opened.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

With reference to my letter 636-G11 of November 10th, pertaining to the construction of the water pipe line at the Gordon Indian Residential School. Punnichy, Sask. November 10th, 1948.

J.P.B. Ostrander, Esq., Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Regina.

With reference to our telephone conversation of this morning, I visited the site of the water pipe line now under construction at the Gordon Indian Residential School. The pipe line is dug and water pipes laid to within 2600 feet of the well which is now dug at the spring, and the well house is under construction. One of the workmen informed me that it is anticipated that water will have to be contended with in carrying the trench to the main water supply. Recent snow and rain and heavy frost has frozen the bottom and sides of the trench, and the loose earth to back fill the trench is now about 3" under snow.

I contacted Mr. Petefield, Engineer in charge, he is of the opinion that this work cannot be completed until next spring, due to conditions, I have already mentioned, and to having to test the pipe line for 48 hours prior to back filling the trench. He has written to Mr. C.R. Cornish, Inspecting Engineer at Banff, regarding this matter, and has promised to let me have a copy of his reply, which I will submit a copy thereof to you.

S.H. Simpson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
