Memorandum

Re: Water Supply Extension to Farm Cottage and Barns

Referring to the memorandum from Indian Affairs dated October 7th, 1948, and our memorandum to you of October 15th, we have received a report from Mr. Cornish which indicates that the suggestion of the school Principal to install an extension to the Farm Cottage and Barns from the pressure tank in the school is not possible at the present time due to a lack of sufficient pipe.

However, Mr. Cornish recommends an alternative scheme to supply the Farm Cottage and Barns by connecting direct to the new wood pipe and using pipe, pump and other equipment at present on hand at the school. This proposal might involve an outlay of about $1,000.00 including $400.00 for excavation, laying pipe and backfilling the trench by the Contractor at present on the ground at a contract rate for 400 lineal feet or $1.00 per foot.

In a telephone conversation with Mr. Phelan of Indian Affairs, we understand that the total amount of $1,000.00 for this work is available and it is desirable that the work be done. As the School Principal has agreed to handle all the work necessary beyond the excavation, laying pipe and backfilling of trench for the 400 feet necessary, Mr. Phelan asked that we should arrange with the Contractor for this trench work and submit the bill to Indian Affairs for payment. The rest of the work would also be paid for by Indian Affairs direct and no funds would need to be transferred to this Service.

Will you please advise this Office if we have approval to accept the bid of the Contractor, R.B. McLeod and Company Limited, to excavate, lay pipe and backfill for four hundred feet at a cost of $1.00 per lineal foot.

It is now getting late in the season and dangerous to open up further trenches for water pipe, but if Indian Affairs desire the work done we recommend this scheme as the only one which could be attempted at this time; payment for all the work to be made direct by Indian Affairs so as not to conflict with the present contract.

Re: Water Supply-Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

In reply to the memorandum from Indian Affairs dated January 6th, 1949, asking for a report on the completion of the water supply system to the above school, the following is submitted.

The waterline from the spring to the school has been installed and we understand is now in operation. The extension from the main 4" pipeline to the Farm Cottage and Barns has been installed so far as the work outside the building is concerned, and Extra Account No. 1, in the amount of $443.75, has been forwarded to you for transmission to Indian Affairs for payment. The school principal will handle the remaining inside work in connection with this extension, as arranged and referred to in our memorandum to you of November 19th.

The main contract with R. B. McLeod and Company, Limited, for the installation of the intake and 4" wood pipeline to the school has not been completely finished, as due to weather conditions the burning of the brush along the pipe right-of-way was not finished and tidying and cleaning up of the job was not completed. As the completion of the project in these respects cannot be done until Spring, money will be needed in the next fiscal year to make final payment to the Contractor. We understand he is likely to make an additional claim over and above the amount due under the contract for the work already done, which if allowed or partially allowed might have to be met from next year's funds. It is of course possible that some of the additional money needed might be available out of current Indian Affairs funds but it seems very likely that the amount transferred to this Service will be exceeded.

We are thus not in a position to say definitely at the present time how much money will be needed in the next fiscal year to complete payment to the Contractor, but we will advise you as soon as full information is available.

As part of the main wood pipeline to the school and the extension to the Farm Cottage and Barns were both installed in severe wintry weather, there is a danger that frost might penetrate to the pipe in sections during the present winter. To guard against leakage to the system Mr. Mayo, the school principal, has been advised by our engineer Mr. Pestfield, to regulate the flow of water by the gate valve outside the cistern at the school and keep water flowing through the main pipe continuously during the winter. If this flow threatens to fill the cistern, a bleeder could be opened on the pressure system while the school is closed and only a small amount of water is being consumed.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.
The caretaker should be advised to continue these arrangements and he should also endeavour to see that water is not allowed to remain motionless for long periods in the extension to the Farm Cottage during the present winter. These precautions should not be necessary after the present winter as the fill material in the pipe trenches will consolidate next summer and afford better protection for the pipes. The sections of pipeline where fill material has been piled up above the old ground level should be checked each year in the Fall, and any erosion should be repaired to ensure proper cover for the pipe during each winter.

The precautions to be taken this winter to keep water running in the pipelines should not be relaxed until there is no doubt that all frost has emerged from the pipeline.

The work on the water and heating systems inside the school has been completed. Sufficient heat should be maintained during the winter to protect the radiators and water system within the school.

Chief Engineer.
Regina, January 31st, 1949.

You will recall that a horizontal boiler which was ordered by the late Mr. Chris Simonson for use at the Gordon's Indian School was not used as it was recommended by the Department of Public Works Engineer that a vertical boiler would be more suitable because of a lack of space in which to install the boiler.

I received a telephone call today from a Mr. McKee, of Western Supplies, Saskatoon, asking me whether or not our Department have actually taken over this boiler for use at some other point. I have not been personally advised as to the decision of the Department, and had to so inform Mr. McKee. It would appear that Mr. McKee's interest now is in the fact that the lawyers who are endeavouring to settle the estate of the late Mr. Simonson have been informed by Mrs. Simonson that the amount of $932.86 is still owing by our Department on the boiler, and she wished to assign her interest therein to Western Supplies in settling her account with them.

There has been some considerable correspondence between this office and the Department in connection with the boiler, but, so far as I am aware, no definite decision has been made. I do not know of any place at the present time where the boiler could be used. However, there is no doubt that it might be used at some time in the future at one of our residential schools.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

Memorandum

Re Installation of Domestic Water Supply,
R.B. McLeod and Company Contract,
Gordon's Indian Residential School, Sask.

Under date of October 18th, 1948, a contract was executed between the Department and R.B. McLeod and Company of Saskatoon, for the installation of a domestic water supply to the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

Authority for the execution of the contract was obtained under Order in Council P.C. 4221 dated September 22nd, 1948.

Although bids were invited from six firms, only one tender was received and this was submitted by R.B. McLeod and Company on the basis of a lump sum price for the intake timber structure and unit prices for the excavation and other items.

The specifications for Excavation and Backfilling of the Pipe Trench provided that payment would be based on cubic yards of material but the pay quantities would be figured for a trench only two feet wide irrespective of the width actually excavated. This provision was considered necessary as it was impossible to know beforehand what width of trench would be excavated by the particular machine available to the successful bidder and generally at least a two-foot width of trench was considered necessary. R.B. McLeod and Company bid on the work under these conditions and their bid was accepted.

During the course of the work, it was discovered that much hardpan and many boulders were excavated in the trench which were not expected by the engineer, and a trenching machine excavating a trench three feet wide was necessary and was used by the Contractor.

A demand for special consideration has been made by the Contractor and our Resident Engineer, Mr. Pestfield, has recommended, with the support of Mr. Comish, that the Contractor be allowed yardage for his trenchwork, based on a three-foot wide trench which was actually excavated and to ignore the specifications which limited the figuring of the trench quantities to a width of two feet.

Due to the fact that the work was more difficult than expected and also due to the fact that it was necessary to work under adverse conditions, this recommendation is concurred in. The Contractor made a genuine effort to do this job as we require it to be done under a unit price contract, and was the only contractor who would accept such a contract.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
The cost of the three-foot wide trench will be $10,677.60 (6,673.5 cu.yds. at $1.60), as compared with $7,118.40 (4,449.0 cu.yds. at $1.60) figured on the basis of a two-foot wide trench. Allowing the Contractor payment on the basis of a three-foot wide trench (actually excavated) will thus increase the cost by $3,559.20.

We understand from Col. Neary of Indian Affairs that this extra payment could be made for this fiscal year from present Indian Affairs funds, but would require a Treasury Board transfer.

As the burning of brush along the pipeline right-of-way and the tidying up of the excavation was not completed by the Contractor, due to difficulties caused by the adverse weather, it will be necessary to have back $100.00 from the Contractor this fiscal year, and this sum will have to be provided in the Supplementary Estimates of Indian Affairs for 1949-50, plus $100.00 for other expenses, or a total of $1100.00 to ensure that the work will be completed.

Kindly advise if we have approval to disregard the specifications for the trench excavation and to pay for the material actually excavated, which will result in an additional payment to the Contractor of $3,559.20. As a Treasury Board transfer is involved and a further Order in Council will probably be required, we should be pleased to receive this approval as soon as possible so that the extra payment can be made from current funds.

Chief Engineer.

In reply to your marginal notation of the 5th instant appearing on Major MacKay's memorandum to you of April 2nd in connection with the lighting plant at the above school, we make the following comments:

In 1946 the Indian Affairs Branch purchased a new Witte Lighting Plant which it is reported, has been giving considerable trouble. Considerable repairs have been made on the engine since its installation, and it is further reported that even when the prime mover is operating satisfactorily, the unit is not of sufficient electrical capacity to handle the loads imposed on it.

This Division was verbally requested by Colonel Neary to express an opinion on this unit before the purchase was made, and he was advised that an investigation of the electrical situation would be necessary before we could make any comments. We discussed the question of capacity by telephone with Mr. Ferrie, an officer of the M.O.C., whom we were informed, was well acquainted with the requirements at the school, and he assured us that the proposed unit was sufficiently large to handle the electrical loads at the school. We were not requested to investigate the electrical situation at the school and did not, therefore, take any further action in this matter.

We do not have any information on our file regarding the electrical situation at the school with the exception of copies of correspondence between the Indian Affairs Branch, the Saskatchewan Regional Supervisor of the Indian Agencies, and the Suppliers of the Witte generating unit purchased.

Before we can make any recommendations, it will be necessary to have complete data on the electrical requirements, and to this end we have requested Mr. W.W. Ferrie, who left Ottawa for the West on April 11th, to make an inspection and submit a report. Mr. Ferrie advised that he expects to be able to carry out his work in the very near future, and upon receipt of his report, Indian Affairs Branch will be further advised.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I have had the opportunity today of a chat with Mr. Mayo about some matters concerning the operation of his School. He reports that, to date, the contractor has not returned to fill in the ditches properly. You know they were only partially refilled last autumn because of the snows. Children are moving into the School first of July and it will be dangerous to leave these ditches in their present condition.

Mr. Mayo also reports that the water is of fine quality but quite hard and mineral. If the taps are unused for a day rust colored water backs up in the pipes and takes quite a time to run off. If water is left standing in dishes or pans a scum of rust forms at the waterline and stains. Mr. Ostrander has requested Mr. Mayo to get an estimate on a water softener and the information has now been given into Mr. Ostrander's hands.

It would be appreciated if some action could be taken in relation to the two above-mentioned matters.

Yours faithfully,

Henry G. Cook

P.S. Mr. Mayo also reports that, to date, Mr. Perry has failed to visit the School in connection with the diesel-electric plant. HGC.

Inspection of the electrical system at the above school was made on June 9, 1946, and the following is submitted for your information and consideration:

The population of the school, including pupils and staff is normally about 160, accommodated in the School Building, Principal's Residence and Foreman's Residence. The buildings, together with the Barn, Cow Barn, Piggery, Machine Shop, Chicken House and Inns are lighted and serviced from a generating plant located in the School Building.

The generator room is at present equipped with the following engines and dynamos:
1 - Witte Diesel Electric Plant, Generator and Switch,
1 - Lister Engine Dynamo, semi-diesel,
1 - Wisconsin Gas Engine and Motor (for laundry power).

The Witte Dieselelectric Plant details are as follows:

Engine - No. Gaddis, Model WD, 12 H.P., Speed 720,
Bore 5", Stroke 6".
Generator - No. 79282A, K.H., Amps 73, D.C., Volts 115,
R.F.A.M. 1800, Type 1213, No. D.C.
Switch - Serial No. 54-8385, Model No. 612, Size
8000 W., Volts 110, Type D.C.

The Witte Plant was installed in 1946, but it has been out of commission for some time. The pistons in the engine are reported to be scored and the whole unit requires a general overhaul.

The Lister Plant, which is generating the power at the present time, is very much overloaded. The details relative to this plant are as follows:

Lister Engine Semi-Diesel
Plant No. 3007 L.H., R.F.A.M. 75,
Dynamo No. 100 54150 R.F.A.M. 600, Volts 110,
Amps 66.5, 14 H.P.

Lister Engine
No. 200 5a 150, Volts 110, Amps 66.5 R.F.A.M. 600.

This unit was installed about 1939 and is reported to have been overhauled about two years ago. The engine head is said to be warped and the engine is now leaking oil badly. A general overhaul is apparently required. The performance of the unit has been unsatisfactory for some time, due to the overload being carried, and the overhaul will have to be complete.

The above unit is connected with 54 batteries, each battery of 2 volts. Originally there were 56 batteries but two were broken (blow up). All batteries have a small amount of sediment in the bottom of each jar; the terminal posts are in bad shape and should be fitted with new nuts and the spacers are warped in about half the jars.

The engine runs about 10 hours per day in the winter months.

... to page 2 please ...
The fuel supply system consists of two 20 gallon tanks outside the building, but these tanks have not been in use for some time. Fuel is carried into the generating room in small drums and supplied to the engines from small hand containers.

The Wisconsin Engine and Motor, is a 3 H.P., unit, air-cooled, type A.F.M., size 350H, No. 141956, run by gasoline.

The unit was used some time ago for power in the laundry room, the laundry room equipment being operated from a line shaft which extended into the generating room. This system of operation has now been discontinued and the laundry room equipment is operated by small meters (electric) which are connected to the various appliances. These meters are as follows:

1 - 3 H.P. on line shaft
1 - 1/2 H.P. for ironer
1 - 1/8 H.P. for pump

The Wisconsin Engine and Motor is now only used as a stand-by and can be used for that purpose.

Additional meters are in use, or required as follows:

Motors in Boiler Room:
Patriot Pumping Pump, 2 H.P., 16.8 Amps, Speed 1750 R.P.M., 115 volts, Serial No. 132156. This unit pumps from the gravity supply tank, 10'x10'x10', outside of the building, to two 500 gallon tanks located in the boiler room.

Leland Dega Motor for pumping from heating system return.
Frame No. 54, 1100 V, 1.5 H.P., 115 Volts, 1250 R.P.M., 6.8 Amps.

Burton Vacuum Pump, Size VNS, Serial No. 025683, Float Control.

Required:
1 - 1 H.P. Motor for use with Cream Separator
1 - 1/2 H.P. Motor and pump for use in Foreman's Residence.

It is also proposed to install a walk-in refrigerator room in the school basement and the necessary power will have to be provided for this purpose.

The lighting arrangements, wiring and location of lighting panels are generally as shown on the wiring plans. Lighting cabinets or panels are located in the School Building as follows: One in basement containing six switches; two on ground floor with five and three switches respectively; two on first floor each with five switches. All switches are in good condition, with the exception of those in panel No. 2 on the first floor, where the push buttons are loose and should be repaired.

The wiring in the School Building and Principal's Residence is, as near as can be determined, all in good condition, but that in the barns and other out buildings will have to be replaced either wholly or in part.

... to page 3 please ...
The total light demands are as follows:

| Location                  | Watts |
|---------------------------|-------|
| School Building, basement | 3520  |
| School Building, ground floor | 4820 |
| School Building, first floor | 2960 |
| School Building, second floor | 960  |
| Principal's Residence     | 160   |
| Foreman's Residence       | 160   |
| Horse Barn                | 200   |
| Cow Barn                  | 80    |
| Pigery                    | 200   |
| **Total**                 | **13160** |

In addition to the above the principal requests that alarm bells and lights be installed at each fire escape exit. Lights are also needed in the Chicken House and Brooder — 2 40-watt and 1 60-watt respectively.

With appliances that might be used, the total lighting requirements if all lights were in operation at the same time may be estimated at 14,000 watts and the various meters require a total of 8 H.P.

It is evident from the above that neither the 6 K.W. "Mitter" unit or the 7.5 K.W. "Lister" unit has the capacity to meet the needs of the school, although one of them might serve as a stand-by unit when properly overhauled. It is impossible to furnish an estimate covering the cost of overhauling either unit at present as each would have to be torn down before any satisfactory estimate could be obtained.

When dealing with the supply of electrical energy at this school consideration may be given to each of the following:

(1) The replacement of one of the present D.C. units with a new one of larger capacity, and the use of the other as a stand-by unit. I have been unable to obtain any definite figures as to the cost of such a new unit together with batteries etc., but no doubt your electrical expert will have at his disposal the information necessary to compile such an estimate. The cost would no doubt be at least equal to that mentioned in (3) below.

(2) The construction of a transmission line to connect the school with the transmission line of the Saskatchewan Power Commission at Pumicito, a distance of 6.5 miles and the purchase of power from the Commission. Arrangements to this end could doubtless be made, but as the school would be the only user of the line to be constructed, the Power Commission would not be too keen about the project. The cost of constructing the necessary transmission line is estimated at $3200.00 to $3400.00 per mile, with an additional $400.00 to $600.00 expenditure for transformers, etc., at the outlet end. This would require an expenditure of approximately $9,000.00 to bring the power to the school, with no provision for stand-by service in the event of a breakdown at the plant of the Power Commission. As suggested under (1) one of the present units (preferably the "Lister") could be repaired and used for emergencies.

... to page 4 please ...
The installation of an alternating current plant, a 3 phase, 60 cycle, 10 kw continuous, 110/220 volt diesel electric plant would take care of the requirements of the school for some years to come and can currently be obtained at a cost of $8,572.00 f.o.b., Regina, Sask. The necessary synchronizing cabinet for use with such a plant is currently priced at $1,040.00 f.o.b., Regina, with an additional $60.00 for the switch between the generator and distribution system. The cost of rewiring the present meters for alternating current would amount to approximately $250.00. The cost of replacing the present generating plant with the 10 kw, diesel-electric transportation and installation charges, should therefore not exceed $9,862.00. The "labor" plant could be used as a stand-by with the motor reversed or changed to AC current.

Regardless of which of the above alternatives is decided upon there will have to be provision for an expenditure of approximately $600.00 to cover the replacement of poles in the lines from school to out buildings, new wiring on sections of the lines and inside the buildings and the provision of the new meters required.

K. R. Purdy,
Supervising Engineer.

In a memorandum dated April 2nd, 1949, we brought to the attention of your Branch the necessity for improving the lighting plant at the above school. In reply we received a memorandum dated April 13th, reading in part as follows:

Re: Water Supply and Drainage - Gordon's Indian Residential School, Saskatchewan.

We have received a report from Mr. Perrie in which he states that the work remaining to be done in connection with the water supply consists of a small amount of back-filling and the cleaning up of debris around the project. He states that this work can be done at any time, and there is no real danger to the children of the school while the trench is in its present condition.

We are now in receipt of a further report from Mr. Perrie, in regard to drainage in the vicinity of the Piggery and the Cow Barn as follows:

"When making an inspection at this school recently Mr. Fred Mayo, Acting Principal, advised me that on the occasion of any heavy rains water ran freely over the floors in the Piggery and Cow Barn. From inspection of the elevations shown on the enclosed plan you will note that the area South of these two buildings slopes rapidly to the North and it is therefore natural that the drainage from this area will flood the floors in these two buildings.

It would be a simple matter to remedy this situation by grading the driveway around the buildings as indicated on the plan, as the ditch on the south side of the driveway would intercept the water and cause same to drain to the West away from the buildings.

The cost of this work would be very little if there was any equipment such as a Blade Grader in the vicinity of the school, but it would cost a good deal to bring in a grader to do this little job. Mr. R.B. McLeod, Saskatoon, who still has some work to do in connection with the water supply at this school, has discussed the possibility of proceeding with this work within the next week or ten days and it is quite likely that the equipment that he will be using to complete his contract will be a small bulldozer. This unit would not be the ideal type of equipment to use for grading the driveway but it would serve the purpose and it is therefore recommended that...

MEMORANDUM

OTTAWA August 11, 1949.

Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School, Funnichy, Sask.

In reply to your marginal notation of the 27th ultimo appearing on Mr. T.R. MacInnes' memorandum to you dated July 22nd last in connection with the above you are advised as follows:

We have studied Mr. Perrie's report of the electrical installation and are of the opinion, in view of the existing power situation, that a storage battery type of installation is most suited to the needs of the school.

We prepared a specification for a new generating unit and forwarded same by hand to Col. Neary on August 5th to expedite the receipt of tenders. Copy of our specification is attached hereto.

The type of equipment specified is such that the storage battery supplies only a small percentage of the total plant capacity and during heavy load periods the generating set automatically starts and supplies the load demand directly, when the load drops below this predetermined level, at which the engine cuts-in, the unit shuts down automatically and the battery handles the load independent of the generator until such time as the load demand exceeds this set value. The present battery apparently is capable of further use with repairs carried out as suggested by Mr. Perrie, particularly with the type of generating unit specified.

In addition to a new generating unit, Mr. Perrie outlined electrical work necessary in several outbuildings and to the distribution system. It is considered advisable to provide a fuel oil storage tank to replace the present system whereby fuel is provided to the diesel engine in small hand containers.

We have written Mr. Perrie requesting him to obtain prices for providing a storage tank and fittings and for having the necessary electrical work done at the school.

This information should be available in the near future and upon receipt, the Indian Affairs Branch will be further advised.

Dear Sir:

The following extracts from the Boiler & Pressure Vessel Act 1948, are particularly drawn to your attention.

Section 14 An inspection certificate may set forth repairs or alterations to be made in, upon or in connection with any boiler, pressure vessel or plant, and the owner shall cause such repairs to be executed forthwith.

Section 17 Every inspection certificate shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the plant or near the boiler or pressure vessel to which it relates and shall be produced by the owner or other person responsible for or in immediate charge of such boiler, pressure vessel or plant upon demand of an inspector.

Section 20 (1) No owner shall cause or permit any high pressure boiler or steam plant to be operated unless:
(a) a chief engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as chief engineer, and who is not responsible for the operation of any other boiler or steam plant, is responsible for and personally supervises the operation thereof; and
(b) either such chief engineer or a shift engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as shift engineer is in immediate charge thereof and the chief engineer, shift engineer or some other person acting under the direct supervision of the chief engineer or shift engineer is in personal attendance on the boiler at all times, whether or not any such boiler is equipped with automatic control.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), no owner shall cause or permit any low pressure boiler or steam plant having a capacity of twenty horse power or more to be operated unless a person who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant is responsible for the operation thereof and in personal attendance thereon at all times.

(3) A low pressure boiler having a capacity of not more than seventy-five horse power which is equipped with an automatic low-water cut-out device approved by an inspector and designed to shut off the fuel fire in the event of low water, may be left unattended and in operation for a period not exceeding ten consecutive hours if:
(a) the safety valve is set to relieve at not more than fifteen pounds to the square inch;
(b) the safety valve and automatic low-water cut-out device are tested daily to ensure their efficient operation;
(c) the automatic low-water cut-out device is installed in such manner that it cannot be rendered inoperative by the manipulation of any manual control or regulating apparatus and the water column, water glass and the float chamber of the cut-out device may be thoroughly blown out each day.

Section 27 Every owner of a boiler, pressure vessel or plant shall provide and keep at all times in a readily accessible location an adequately equipped first aid kit for the treatment of minor injuries and shall produce such first aid kit upon demand of an inspector.

Our inspectors report that in some instances owners are employing persons to operate boilers who do not hold certificates issued under the Act and we sincerely hope that after receipt of this notice such violations will be corrected making further action unnecessary.

Your full co-operation in respect to all the requirements of the Act is solicited in the interests of public safety and will be greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 22nd, under the above file number and with reference to the lighting plant to be shipped to Gordon's Indian Residential School at Punichi, Saskatchewan under your purchase order No. 47744.

We are making arrangements with our representative in Saskatchewan to be in readiness in case you should require his services when this unit is installed. Unfortunately, I cannot give you his address at the present time, but I will be able to send this along to you shortly.

With regard to the actual installation of the unit, I can perhaps outline roughly to you what is involved. You have already received an installation drawing of the unit, our drawing number CD-2911. The usual practice is to install these units on a block of concrete, and for this particular unit we would recommend a block approximately two feet deep, five feet long, and three feet wide. This block should be made of reinforced concrete, and at least 18" of the block should be below the normal ground level. In some instances, these units have been installed on heavy timbers which are firmly embedded in the ground, but this practice is not to be recommended if a concrete block can be used. The generating set is complete in itself insofar as the engine and generator are concerned, and it is only necessary to connect the engine starting batteries and the fuel oil supply line in order to start the unit.

A fuel supply system will be required, and in this case the usual practice is
to have an underground storage tank for the main fuel supply and a day tank installed in the engine room. A pipe line is connected between the day tank and main storage tank, and a transfer pump, usually hand operated, is installed in this line. The day tank should have sufficient capacity for about at least two days continuous operation, and the engine attendant should pump this day tank full every morning. This day tank is connected to the fuel inlet on the engine. Depending upon the length of oil lines, they can be made of either copper tubing or 3/8" black iron pipe. If necessary, a plumber, with ordinary plumber's tools, can install the fuel tanks and fuel lines. The day tank should be installed above the level of the fuel inlet into the engine so that there is always a gravity feed of fuel to the engine.

A plumber could also install the exhaust silencer and exhaust piping. The main thing to watch here is to avoid any possible bends in the exhaust line, and to keep it as straight as possible.

With regard to the actual location of the engine installation, it should be located in a well ventilated room with sufficient clearance all around the unit to permit access to it for servicing and repairs. A clear area in front of the radiator should be allowed to permit free circulation of the cooling air through the radiator.

The generator control panel is being supplied for wall mounting. It will be complete, including all meters, internal wiring, and generator field rheostat, and will also include the automatic remote starting panel, and the reverse current relay. It will be necessary to supply the main leads between the generator and the panel, and the panel and batteries, together with the smaller leads from the automatic engine control panel to the actuating relay and the engine. Wiring diagrams will be furnished, showing all these connections, and I believe that provincial regulations usually require that this type of work be done by a licensed electrician. There is nothing particularly complicated about it, and a competent electrician could take care of it quite readily.

I trust that the above outline will give you some idea as to what to expect, and if there is any particular detail on which you would like further information, please let me know.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum

Re: Installation of Electrical Plant,
Gordon's Indian Residential School,
Punnichy, Sask.

In previous correspondence regarding the above, you were furnished with comment indicating that by replacing seven (7) wet batteries, the existing bank of batteries would be satisfactory for use with the new D.C. plant, recently purchased for installation at the school.

In a recent report from Mr. Perrie, after visiting the school with Mr. Koosar from this office, who was instructed to call there on his western inspection trip, the suggestion is advanced that consideration should be given to replacing the complete battery set consisting of 56 - 315 amp. glass cell batteries at a cost of $21.65 each.

Mr. Perrie has not commented on the condition of the existing batteries since his first examination in June last, when in his report he said:

"All batteries have a small amount of sediment in the bottom of each jar; the terminal posts are in bad shape and should be fitted with new nuts, and the spacers are badly warped in about half the jars."

In view of such comment, indicating a shortening life for the cells still intact, requiring progressive replacement, it is recommended that Indian Affairs authorize the purchase at once of 56 - 315 ampere glass cell batteries (Autolite or equal) to be forwarded to the school for installation as soon as possible, and that Mr. Perrie be authorized to arrange for the necessary labour, all costs to be met by the Indian Affairs Branch, Educational Vote.

The total expenditure involved would be in the neighbourhood of $1,300.00.

Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

R.A. Gibson, Esq., Director.

Re: Water Supply - Gordon's Indian Residential School, Saskatchewan.

The following has been received from Mr. Perrie under date of December 6th, and is forwarded for the information of Indian Affairs:

"I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 25th with attached letter from W.J. Westaway Company Limited relative to the water supply at the above school, and I have to advise that I am quite in accord with your suggestion that it might be wise to withhold action on the proposal to soften water at the school until after the school is in operation with a full complement of pupils and staff and a steady water consumption is being maintained.

It is true that, although the analysis covering the various samples of water taken at this school during the past two years show quite a variation in the nature of the water, all seem to indicate that it requires some treatment to make it entirely satisfactory for use in the school heating plant and for laundry purposes, and were it not for the high sulphate value of the water it would seem that the ordinary type of water softener would be all that is required at the school. To remove the sulphates would, as indicated in a letter from W.J. Westaway Company Limited, be too expensive an operation for this particular application and it is a question whether ordinary softening would take care of the problem.

The water level in the well has, since the well was cleaned out, never risen to anything like the level of last spring, and possibly, as you suggest in your letter, the spring thaws and rain, which will no doubt again raise the level of water in the well, will have an effect on the quality of the water and an analysis next spring may indicate somewhat different properties than would those taken previously. Some immediate steps should, however, be taken to have a hypochlorinator installed and the water treated at the present time."

Dear Sirs;

Re: Gordon School.

Although I have called your attention during the past few weeks, to the dilatory manner in which you are finishing up work at the above job, there seems to be no improvement. Except for the laying of the linoleum which has been going on for the last week, practically nothing has been done for over a month. The pulleys for the laundry machinery are not on, and the water tanks and filtration plant have not been left in a good condition. Pulley and push plates have not been put on the kalsomein iron doors to stair well, and thresholds to doors are not down. Sir:-

I wish to bring to your attention the fact that a root cellar is absolutely necessary at the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, some outbuildings are being erected there now, and while the carpenters are on the ground it would be well to have the root cellar built, as the school have no place to store their potatoes and other vegetables for the winter.

In building a root cellar with cement walls and roof it is necessary to reinforce it with iron and steel, and this would be expensive, as the labour alone would cost between $400.00 and $500.00, and as the Department has advised me that only expenditures that are absolutely necessary may be incurred, I would suggest that an ordinary root house be constructed, which would meet the requirements. This would be dug into a hill and lined with boards, and would have a pole roof covered with brush, straw and earth, and of course the necessary ventilators, etc. I find that I can build a place of this nature for from $225.00 to $250.00, and no doubt it would last at least four or five years.

I should be glad to have the Department's authority immediately to go on with this work, as it is absolutely essential, and I do not suppose the Church authorities have any money to build it themselves.

Dear Sir:

Re. Gordon's Indian School. Report No. 18.

As intimated in my last report we have run into some trouble on the water supply to the school. After cleaning out the well at the lake shore it was found that the water did not rise very quickly, and would not rise to the level of the lake surface. Upon investigation we found that the water level of the lake was down some four feet from its level of a year or so ago, and down below where the water could get into the gravel and stone around the well. It was necessary to immediately dig a trench to continue the original trench from the well to the lake. This I ordered done, and have had it filled with boulders and gravel, and have also had the forty foot culvert cleaned out and replaced in this trench out into the lake.

In order that you may have a better idea of this I enclose three photographs showing the work in progress.

Now that the water is again running to well there will be about eight feet of water in same. The last two years have been very dry up here and all bodies of water are at a very low point.

I have had the foreman keep careful time of the this work, and have checked up carefully myself.

The school is now completed except for the ash hoist, and the electric motor for the water pump, this latter being run temporarily by a gas engine. As soon as these two items arrive a day will suffice for the installation of them.

The contractors are now cleaning up around the building and tearing down the office and buildings.

The Sewing Room and one Class Room are in use, but the rest of the building is not being used.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;

Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School.

I herewith enclose copies of the final certificate, with copies of the extras and deductions as checked by me.

I also enclose clearances from the sub-contractors and supply firms who have had an interest in this job. The guarantee of the Contractors as called for is also enclosed.

The school is now in use as far as it can be with the limited amount of furniture they have, but there is one item i.e., the ash hoist which is not yet installed owing to delay in shipping the right one. This is expected on the job at any time, and as soon as it is there the contractors will send a man to install it. In the meantime I thought that an amount of say $300.00 might be withheld or the cheque for the final payment might be sent to Shoquist Bros. care of me; to be held until hoist is actually in the building.

REGINA, SASK., Dec. 19th, 1930

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just received a report from Archdeacon Knowles, who has returned from the Gordon School, and also from Mr. Waddy, to the effect that the Principal's residence is unfit for occupation at the present time. Mr. Waddy tells me that there is not a house on the reserve that is in such a filthy condition as is this one. The walls are black, and boards have been nailed across the plaster with the result that it is badly broken. The floors are so thick with dirt that it can be scraped off with a hoe. The paint is off the windows and the varnish off the woodwork, and as I say, the place is not in a fit condition for anyone to occupy.

I would ask for your authority to spend between $250.00 and $300.00 to put this residence in shape. In the meantime the new Principal and his family are occupying three rooms in the school building that cannot conveniently be spared.

I am of the opinion that with a lay Principal in charge we may expect a great change in the management of this institution. The man who is going in seems to be clean-cut and aggressive. There is a great deal to be done at the Gordon School to straighten matters out after four years of incompetent management.

I should like to have your authority for this expenditure by wire and I can send a man out from here to do the work, as I do not think we can get a local man. I have given the Principal's wife permission to select the paper that will be used on the walls.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian Residential School, Lestock, Sask., Report No. 15.

The weather during the past two weeks has been splendid for outside work. The septic tank is complete except for the stripping of the inside forming, and this we intend to have done by Thursday next. In order to take advantage of the good weather I had the contractors put the men on to the pit for pump over the new well as soon as they had the septic tank completed, with the result that this pit is now excavated and the concrete floor in, and the trench for pipe from pit to pump house has been dug. The forming for walls is in and concrete will be poured next week.

The Lister men have the plant assembled and in place, and yesterday had it running for a time. As soon as the electrician can get the main line run and the bulbs in the fixtures, which I expect will be by Thursday next, a test will be made under full load.

The Kelvinator engineer has installed the cold storage plant and will be back on the job for a test just as soon as we can give him power.

The plumbing fixtures are all installed and can be in operation as soon as the water system is in. Dear Mr. Scott:-

I beg to inform you that I have just returned from making a visit to the Touchwood Agency, and the two residential schools, Gordon's and Muscowequan. My visit was of short duration, but I was able to go into a number of matters.

At the Gordon School I found the work almost completed, although there are still some things to be done. The workmanship on the building seems to be first-class. The school is now under the management of Mr. Frayling and he is receiving a great deal of co-operation from Mr. Waddy. At the time of my visit there were 97 children in the school, and in a few weeks time this number will be increased to 120 if not more, according to reports I have received.

There are one or two matters in connection with the Gordon School which I think should receive your attention. I would point out that the drainage from the school to the sewage disposal is in very bad shape and the sewage is backing up over the basement floors. When I was there a quarter of the room was covered with back water and fetid matter, and the stench was unbearable. I am told that it was the duty of the contractor to put this drainage system in first-class shape. I later met Mr. Swan and told him what I had found. As Mr. Swan has been handling the business of the Department I thought he was the proper officer to speak to regarding matters of this kind.

I have secured for this institution a high class Engineer, which is something we should have in all our schools, a man capable of making repairs and keeping the machinery the way it should be kept. The school is paying a good salary to this man and no doubt will get good results. Since Mr. Frayling, the new Principal, who is a layman, has taken charge he has not had much chance to show what he can do, as he has been handicapped by not having the right kind of a staff. At the time of my visit he was short a Matron, a cook, and a couple more female members of staff. Whether he will be fortunate in securing the right type of people to fill these positions in the near future I do not know. He has advertised for them.

Mr. Frayling drew my attention to the oven, which has been the subject of considerable correspondence, pointing out that the requirements of the school were from 100 to 125 loaves of bread per day, and with an oven of the size which he is to receive it would be necessary to bake every day, including Sundays, and sometimes twice a day. I think he is correct in this, as I checked the matter up closely with the adjoining school, Muscowequan, where there are 65 pupils, and possibly a total of 85 including the staff. At this school they had an oven which is practically of the same capacity as you propose sending to the Gordon school, where they will have from 135 to 140 to feed when the school is filled. This oven was discarded at Muscowequan because it was not sufficiently large to take care of the requirements of this school where they have a pupilage of 65. I have since had installed at this school, as you know, an oven which can provide for the baking of two sacks of flour at a time, and in discussing this matter with the baker at the school she informed me that she bakes from seven to eight sacks of flour a week. This seems a large amount but she assured me it was the quantity used. Every child in the school gets rid of a pound loaf a day, this being the case you will see at once the situation at Gordon's. As the oven you propose sending there has only a capacity of 72 loaves it is quite unsuitable and should not be installed. It seems to me that this is a matter that could well have been left to officers in the field who are doing the actual work and understand exactly what is required. If the Department insist on supplying this type of oven we might as well have installed the one which was discarded at the Muscowequan School.
Another matter which was brought to my attention was the fact that the large outdoor cistern that we built in connection with the school that was burned down is intact, but there is no way of getting the water out of the cistern and through the house. Sir,

I beg to advise the Department that the service installation of Gordon's School, Punnichy, Sask., was inspected on 15th January 1931 and does not conform to the requirements of the Canadian Electrical Code, Part 1, in the following respects:

No branch cut-outs in "E" Box where wires change in size. The positive wire that runs from the panel to the front chapel lights are grounded to the conduit of the same run, causing a short circuit. Loom service used for entrance to barns and outlying buildings. Wires run down the side walls of the barns without any protection from hay or straw that might be piled against them. Building has not got a separate distribution panel for each floor.

The following changes are required to meet the approval of the Saskatchewan Power Commission:

Install branch cut-outs in "E" box where wires change in size. Run two new wires from panel to front Chapel lights. Install conduit service to outlying buildings and ground conduits of same. Board in wires on walls of barns so that wires are protected from hay, straw, and mechanical injury.

Mr. Swan informs me that the cost of the above work will be $90.00 and I shall be glad to receive authority to have it done while the electricians are there as it will cost a great deal more to send them back again. The above changes will make the installation safe and efficient.

Dear Sir-

With reference to the water supply system at Gordon's Indian Boarding School which was inspected by our Mr. Miller a couple of days ago, we beg to report as follows:-

There is two ways that the water pipe can be installed in the lake, first by building a cofferdam and then dig a trench deep enough so that the pipe would be below the frost line and secondly by laying the pipe on the bottom of the lake and then cover this pipe with earth and stones of sufficient depth to protect it from frost.

The cofferdam proposition would be considerably more expensive than laying the pipe on the bottom of the lake, so we are recommending the second scheme, that is to lay the pipe on the bottom of the lake and cover with sufficient earth and stones to protect from the frost.

We recommend that a pump be installed close to the lake, as the level of the lake is so low that the pump in the School will not lift the water at present, the pump to be installed in a well insulated building on the shore of the lake above high water level.

We also recommend that the water be pumped from the Pump at the lake to a tank of sufficient capacity, placed under ground at the most suitable location near the school, as it is not practicable to have a pressure pump so far away from the pressure tank in the School. The tank is required for purifying purposes and would also be a fine reserve supply in case of fire.

We are attaching a sketch showing the pipes as we propose to install them and will be pleased to have your instructions to proceed with the work.

Yours truly,

Memorandum: Dr. Scott.

The Gordon's Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire on the 1st day of February, 1929, and at that time it was decided to provide an item in the estimates for the next year for the reconstruction of the building. Later on however an item was placed in the Supplementary Estimates.

When the building was destroyed the only portion left that could be used in the reconstruction of the new school was the foundation. In order to have all the information necessary available for the preparation of the plans a blue print copy of the floor plans of the Old Gordon's School was sent to Commissioner Graham on May 13th, and he was asked to interview the Church authorities and return the blue prints with any changes desired indicated. As no reply was received on June 19th a further request was made to the Commissioner asking that the plans be returned as soon as possible in order that the plans for the new school could be prepared at once. The plans were received here on the 21st of June.

Plans and specifications were then prepared for the new building and on Sept. 5th tenders were invited. They were received on the 30th and on October 17th an Order in Council was passed awarding the contract to Shoquist Bros. of Saskatoon, the lowest tenderer. The work was commenced immediately and the contract completed on the 27th of September of this year.

During the winter months it was necessary to practically suspend operations, but as much work as possible was done when the temperature would permit, in order to assist the unemployment in that district.

Mr. William Swan, Architect of Punnichy, was appointed by the Civil Service Commission as Inspector of Construction. Mr. Swan had acted as Inspector when the old Gordon's School was erected and
his services were satisfactory. The Indian Commissioner also recommended that he be employed for this work stating that he considered that he was one of the most competent men in the Province of Saskatchewan and strongly advised that he be employed.

The new Gordon's Indian Residential School is entirely of fireproof construction.

In the furnishing of the Indian Residential Schools it has been the practice in the past to allow the Principal, after consulting with his staff, to submit to the Department a list of the furnishings required. When this list is received here it is carefully checked in order that the equipment will conform to that furnished other schools. It is necessary to disallow some of the items asked for, and in some cases to make additions. This list is then sub-divided and forms of tender prepared and submitted to the different firms for prices. The names of the firms who are asked to quote are obtained from the Minister's office.

In the case of the Gordon's School the Reverend Principal submitted a list which was carefully checked in accordance with the above procedure. On August 14th an analysis of the tenders received was submitted to you, with the recommendation that the order be placed with the firms quoting the lowest price. On the following day you submitted these prices to the Minister's office for consideration. On Sept. 6th you advised the Minister's Secretary that the Minister had instructed that new prices be invited, and on Sept. 16th the Minister's office submitted a list of names from whom prices were to be invited. The following day the firms were sent out to these firms and the prices were receivable on Sept. 30th to Oct. 6th. On October 13th an analysis of the prices received was submitted to the Acting Deputy which was approved, and on Oct. 14th the orders were placed.

When preparing the tenders forms to be submitted to the various firms it has always been found that there are certain items which it is more satisfactory to purchase by personal selection, such as curtains, rugs, and a few small items, these the Principal was authorized to purchase and was advised of the names of firms from whom to make the purchase.

There are certain articles of equipment which it is necessary
to build as they cannot be purchased ready made, such as clothes cupboards, lockers, benches, tables, etc. Mr. Swan, the Inspector, was instructed on Nov. 20th to make the purchase, the names of firms from whom prices were to be obtained being supplied from the Minister's office.

The orders for all the equipment required were placed with the Western branches of the various firms. The type and quantity of equipment, however, is not carried in stock by the branch offices and the orders were therefore forwarded to the head office and the shipment made direct to the School from the factories. Most of these factories are located in the East.

Memorandum:

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy

I have given careful attention to the letter of the 6th December from Mr. P. H. Gordon, K.C., of Regina, and also the letter from Mr. Graham, the Indian Commissioner, dated the 3rd December. These letters refer to the alleged delays in the completion of the new residential school building on the George Gordon's Reserve, near Punichy, Sask., and delays in furnishing the school.

This school is conducted by the Anglican Diocese of Qu'Appelle, and has for some years suffered from mismanagement which culminated in the destruction by fire of the fine school building. They seemingly have found it impossible to engage a competent person in Holy Orders to conduct this school. I suggested to Bishop Harding and Archdeacon Knowles when they were last in my office, in the autumn, that they ought to select a competent layman. They have selected a layman, and time will show whether he is competent or not.

The Building

The school was destroyed by fire on February 1, 1929. The Main Estimates had been prepared, and as we had obtained our full requirements, the Minister decided not to provide for the school in the Estimates of 1929-30, but to make it a leading item in the Estimates for 1930-31. However, owing to pressure from the ecclesiastical authorities he decided to place an amount in the Supplementary Estimates, and accordingly $90,000.00 was provided. Our Supplementary Estimates went to the Finance Department on the 6th May, 1929, and as soon as they had been approved, on the 13th May, blue print copies of the floor plans of the old school were sent to Mr. Graham and he was asked to interview the Church.
authorities and to make suggestions as to the changes in the plans. No reply was received from Mr. Graham, and on June 19th I wrote asking him to return the plans as soon as possible. My letter crossed one from him dated May 21st. I could not understand this and asked him for an explanation, and it appears that the letter was prepared on the 21st May but not mailed, and that the delay of nearly three weeks was entirely owing to negligence in his office. The plans and specifications were prepared, and tenders were asked for on September 5th. They were received on September 30th, and on October 17th the Order in Council was passed awarding the contract to Shoukist Bros., of Saskatoon, the lowest tenderer, $133,895.00. The Department was not hurried in the awarding of this contract advisedly and for the simple reason that we knew $90,000.00 would not build the school and that the construction of the school and payment of the contractor would have to run into the next fiscal year. Mr. William Swan, an Architect of Punnichy, was appointed by the Civil Service Commission as Inspector of Construction. Mr. Graham recommended that he be employed, stating that he considered that he was one of the most competent men in the Province of Saskatchewan. During the winter months it was necessary to almost suspend operations, but much work was done when the temperature would permit in order to assist unemployment in that district. Altogether $51,388.00 was charged to the Vote for 1929-30. Construction went on and the building was completed on September 27, 1930. The amount of $86,224.21 was charged to the Vote for 1930-31. The difference between the total amount paid, namely, $137,612.21 and the contract price was for certain extras allowed by the Superintendent of Construction. Considering the winter interval I think the school was constructed with reasonable despatch.

The Furnishings.

As for the general method employed in furnishing these residential schools, I may say that it has been the practice in the past to allow the Principal, after consulting with his staff, to submit to the Department a list of the furnishings required. When this list is received here it is carefully checked in order that the equipment will conform to that furnished other schools. It is necessary to disallow some of the items asked for, and in some cases to make additions. This list is then subdivided and forms of tender prepared and submitted to the different firms for prices. The names of the firms who are asked to quote are obtained from the Minister's Office. We have furnished all our schools under this system.
and it has been found to work well.

When the Gordon's school building was approaching completion the Principal was asked to submit a list which was carefully checked in accordance with the above procedure, and on July 10th the firms named by the then Superintendent General were asked to tender. On August 15th an analysis of the tenders received was submitted to you. After discussion you directed me to obtain new prices, and on September 6th I advised Mr. Buskard to that effect. On September 16th your office gave me a list of names from whom prices were to be invited, and on the following day prices were asked from these firms. The prices were receivable from September 30th to October 6th. On October 13th an analysis of the prices was submitted to you, and on October 14th the orders were placed. In this instance the change of Government was responsible for this delay.

I do not think I should take up your time by controverting some of the statements in Mr. Gordon's letter and by pointing out the characteristic attitude assumed by the Indian Commissioner. I should be pleased to go into the matter further if it is clear to you that I have not dealt with any important point in these letters.

Gordon Indian Residential School

The class room work is arranged as follows.

The senior room has 28 pupils on the roll and the following grades:

- Grade 3 - 6
- " 4 - 13
- " 5 - 5
- " 6 - 4

The intermediate room has 45 pupils enrolled.

- 27 in Grade 1
- 27 in " 2

The primary department has 20 on the roll.

The class work in both the intermediate and senior rooms is good and progress is being made. The work - books were -
books were tidy and all work neatly set down.

The children were well clothed, clean, and neat in appearance.

The primary work is carried on in the girls' play-room. At one end of this room a partition has been erected. This partition does not reach the ceiling and allows free circulation of air. No girls are in the play-room during class hours, so that there is no dust or interruption.

The various departments were all in operation and the matrons in charge appeared capable. The girls are taught cooking, bread making, and butter making. Some sewing is taught, but the Principal informed me this line of work would be enlarged upon during the coming year. It is the intention to instruct each girl, so that she can make all her own clothes and do other plain sewing. This fall the girls had no instruction in milking, but this work will be carried on during the new year.

The fire escapes are in good condition, also all other fire equipment. Fire drill is observed several times during each month, and the children are able to get out in from two to two and one half minutes. The fire escape doors are unlocked after the children retire. At present the bells connected with these doors are not working, but these are being repaired. The bells will prevent anyone entering or leaving unless the alarm is sounded.

The water system has been changed, and the system now installed should give excellent service and in case of fire will be of added protection. The changing of this system entailed a lot of work, but I would judge this has been well done.

The building throughout I found to be tidy and clean. The dormitories were all well aired and the beds neatly made. The children are provided with night dresses and pyjamas - in which to -
in which to sleep.

The dining room was clean and the meals appeared to be well prepared. The following is a general menu.

**Breakfast** - Oatmeal or cream of wheat - cornflakes on Sunday with milk and brown sugar, bread and butter or jam - tea or cocoa.

**Dinner** - Meat, vegetables - fish on Friday pudding, pie once a week, bread, water to drink

**Supper** - Potatoes fried, soup, pancakes, egg dishes or beans, fruit and cake on Sunday bread and butter or jam Tea for senior pupils, cocoa for junior.

Milk or cocoa is served at first recess to any children needing special nourishment.

The children are weighed each month and a record kept of their weights. The chart indicates in most cases a fair gain for each pupil.

The grounds have been greatly improved since my last visit, and present a good appearance. A proper road three quarters of a mile long leading to the school has been built and gravelled. This road has been well fenced along with all the play-grounds. These improvements represent a lot of hard work and expense and have transformed the surroundings.

Gordon's Residential School

You will note that up to the time of the Inspector's visit, no instruction in milking cows had been given the girls, but it is the intention to do so during the coming year. I am drawing the Principal's attention to this matter, asking him to see that it is attended to.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the batteries in connection with the electric lighting equipment at the Gordon Indian Residential School. It is noted that these batteries are now used up and that a complete set of replacements is required.

In reply I have to say it is considered that, unless extra attachments were used in connection with the lighting equipment, the batteries should have lasted a longer period. Our funds this year are so limited, that it is difficult to obtain the amount required in the purchase of new batteries. However, as it is necessary that the lighting plant be in good condition, the Department will approve of you obtaining prices, from only those firms on the list to receive consideration, for the supplying of the number of replacement groups as mentioned in your letter and for the quantity of sealing compound, bridge rests and sulphuric acid required.

It is noted that, in other schools where the Globe batteries have been in use, they have not given a lengthy period of service. It is not necessary that this type of battery be supplied in making the replacement at the Gordon School at the present time, and, in obtaining quotations, you should consider other well known and serviceable batteries.

It is noted, further, that you estimate the cost of the new batteries, installed, will be approximately $500. If possible, this amount should not be exceeded. You should place the order with the firm quoting the lowest price, and, after delivery has been made to your satisfaction, please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Please inform the Principal of the School definitely that the electric light equipment is to be used for lighting purposes only and that no attachments, such as electric irons, stoves, or pumping equipment are to be used.

The purchase and delivery of the new batteries should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report that on my visit to the Gordon Indian Residential School today, I found everything in very fair shape, with the exceptions noted below. The whole of the inside of the school has again been kiln-dried and painted this spring at the expense of the school authorities and is very clean. The grounds are kept in good shape, about thirty acres of garden and 120 acres of crop are in, and growing well. The pupils are all well, not one being sick at the present time, they are well dressed and tidy.

The principal asks me if I will enquire from the Department if he is to receive any compensation for the money he has expended on new buildings, roads, fences etc., that he has put in since he came here; he says he has spent about $7,500.00 and is under the impression he is to get part of this refunded.

Regards the repairs required here this year I would be obliged if the Department would advise me what money is allowed. What is required principally is a granary; the cost would be about $100.00. The root cellar has fallen in and requires to be dug out and the roof rebuilt; the cost of this would be close to $200.00. When this place was being built the money allowed only provided for a roof made of poles, these not cut in about three years.

The back entry to the school is in bad shape, the stone lintel and the bricks are all coming away from the building, and the door frame is loose; this should be repaired by a competent builder; the cost would be about $50.00 to make a good job and a lot of brick would have to be replaced. In the boys play rooms the plaster above the wainscot for a fact or so is all loose; this should have a strip of board inserted and the plaster repaired, about $25.00 for material and labor.

There is a pen made of poles here for the bull, this is rotten and should be replaced or the animal may get out and damage some of the pupils; a few years ago one did break out and he killed the farmer's horse. The principal asks for construction of an iron fence pen; this might seem too expensive, but something should be done here.

Ottawa, February 19, 1936.

Sir:

A report has been received regarding the serious accident sustained by Elsie Lapierre, pupil of the Gordon Indian Residential School, whose hand was caught in the bread mixer, necessitating the amputation of two of her fingers. The Department understands that this is the second girl to receive serious injury in the operation of the bread mixer.

The Department does not understand why there should be accidents occasioned in the operation of this machine. Bread mixers of the same type as at the Gordon School have been supplied to a large number of residential schools, and we have not been informed of any accident, such as suffered by Elsie Lapierre, having occurred at any of the other schools. It is considered that, when the mixer is in operation, it should be under the direct charge of a responsible member of the staff; we should have the services of the girls working in the bakery. It is not considered necessary that the pupils take any active part when the mixer is in operation. The only alternative would be to dispense with the use of the mixer and have the girls mix the dough by hand. No one but a staff member should be allowed to handle the mixer.

I should be pleased to have a report from you, regarding the accident to Elsie Lapierre and what definite action is being taken to prevent a re-occurrence.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:-

Enclosed herewith please find blue-print showing profile of the ground line on which a dam is proposed to be constructed for the purpose of preventing water at the north end of Lake contaminating the water being used for domestic purposes by the school.

I have proposed a fill 16 feet wide on top and protected by stone on the sides. To make this fill would take about 550 cubic yards of earth and about 60 cubic yards of stone. To have this work done by contract labor would cost from 25 to 30 cents per yard for earth and the placing of stone along the sides of fill, about $1.00 per yard, varying in proportion to the distance the stone would have to be hauled. Some of the stone may be obtained when excavating for the fill. Concrete culverts might be obtained from the local Municipality at comparatively low cost plus cost of hauling from the vicinity of Humby's Lake, where they are made. Altogether the total cost would be about $200.00, this cost might be reduced if done by local labor.

The profile of ground as shown on the blue-print is marked at each end by a blazed tree.

I shall be glad to give you any further information on this matter that you may require.

Yours truly,

(SIGNED.) Sidney Harding.
I have recently had the levels taken at the Dividing point by Mr. S. Harding, A.M.E.I.C., Surveyor, which his Blue - Print clearly shows, and that the work could be completed for about $200.00.

Apart from cutting off this undesirable half, the proposed Dam would give us a greater volume of Water to draw from, in place of running over the entire Lake as at present, giving depth as well as more and better water.

Should this project be approved by the Department, I would suggest an early start, as the little water that may have been there, is now frozen and the work could be completed before the Spring thaw sets in.

The earth could mostly be taken from near by points, and all work could be done by the local Indians, with one Supervisor.

The question was also raised by Mr. Murison to Dr. McGill when visiting the School and was also mentioned to Dr. Stone.

I would impress upon you the necessity for prompt action, and point out that we are certain to get some added water, and the small cost involved would go a very little way in digging wells, apart from the cost of finding a location.

Dear Mr. Waddy:

Re: SCHOOL WATER SUPPLY.

Serious consideration should be given the above. At the rate the water has receded the last few years, every possible means for conserving should be used.

The Lake (or slough) from which we obtain water is practically divided in half, an elevation, or Island in the centre, with shallow channels on either side. At the present time there is no water connection with the South and North portions. This latter portion (the North) is little better than a Cess Pool; Indians camp around there, drive in their Horses and Cattle and sometimes Bathe.

The Sask. Gov't. Laboratory findings have shown for the last 4 years viz; Organic Matter - Quantity; Bacteria per C.C. - Too numerous to count; E Coli - present.

R. H. Murray, C.E. Director of Division of Sanitation recommended that the Reservoir be chlorinated as it was unsafe for drinking purposes. This was done, at the given proportions. Sample after sample was again sent, each time the report was add more lime. And at last, until it can be tasted. This is and has been the practice since, and the proof of its effectiveness is shown by the good health at the School.

I firmly believe that the majority of the contamination has been from the northern end of the lake and should be separated.

Sir:

Gentlemen:

Attention Mr. Frayling

As per the writer's conversation with you you will find embodied in this report the recommendations which I made for the operation of your 3 and 6 K.W. Lister fully Automatic Lighting Plants.

Item No. 1 - That the entire cooling system, that is, all piping be renewed as the present piping has become so badly corroded that the cooling efficiency of the plant is reduced to approximately one-third of normal. This is very detrimental to the plant as it causes excessive heating on the head which increases cylinder wear as well as higher oil consumption than the engine, under normal conditions, would use.

Item No. 2 - That you change from the grade of oil you are using at present, which is No. 10 to No. 30 or No. 40, preferably No. 40, during the warm season of the year.

Item No. 3 - That the main clapper switches on your switchboard be properly cleaned once a week at least. If the carbons on the clapper switches as well as the brass contacts are not kept properly cleaned, it will eventually burn out the main coils on the clapper switch.

Item No. 4 - That cylinders on both plants be treated at once with a proper scaling compound to remove all scale from the water jacket.

Item No. 5 - That the oil in these plants be renewed every three weeks and their crankcases properly cleaned out.

Item No. 6 - In checking the present batteries of your lighting plants over I found that in their present state they are now practically useless other than for working the automatic features and the period of time which they will last and continue to operate the automatic features is very questionable. I feel that the question of replacing these batteries should be dealt with at the earliest possible date as I found when checking them over that the positive plates were in such a state that they are quite apt to explode from short circuiting which is caused from the sediment forming in the bottom of the jars and coming high enough up to touch the lower parts of the positive and negative plate causing a short circuit to across them.

- When replacing -

When replacing these batteries I would recommend strongly that you replace your present set with a 240 ampere hour rather than a 108 ampere hour which you have been using up to date, in that the plants are sufficiently big enough to take care of a larger size battery and by having a larger size battery you will get more efficiency out of the plant when charging the batteries. Also, the heavier battery will stand the discharge as well as charge the battery than a smaller battery.

As an example of which I refer to: You have in your smaller Generating unit a supply of 30 amperes when running at a maximum output. The present battery you have can only be charged at from eight to ten amperes. Therefore, you run your small plant at only one-third of its capacity to charge your present battery, but if you had a 240 ampere hour battery on it would be possible to run your plant closer to its maximum output and would charge the larger battery in the same period of time as it would the smaller battery, thus giving you in the larger battery, double the storage amperage. You will, no doubt, see from the above example that it is more profitable in this instance to install a larger battery even if the initial cost of installation is considerably higher.

We believe that if these instructions are carefully followed, you will eliminate considerable wear on your engines and cut your operating cost down considerably.

Yours very truly,

MUMFORD, MEDLAND, LIMITED.

"W. J. Montgomery"
