Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 121-1-5, dated April 9th last, with regard to the condition of the batteries and the Lister 6½ and 12 H.P. engines at the Gordon's Indian Residential School, Touchwood Agency.

The roads were very bad during the early part of April and I was not able to make the trip until the end of the month when I visited the school, taking with me the Shop Foreman of the Magneto Service Station of this City. In the meantime the Principal had had Mr. W. J. Montgomery, a mechanical expert of Mumford, Medland Limited, of Winnipeg, who handle the Lister electric lighting units, visit the school and examine the equipment. Mr. Montgomery submitted a detailed statement of the repairs required for the engine, but did not give an estimate of the labour. I wrote him requesting this information and his report came to hand during my absence this week at the Pelly Agency. I am enclosing his report, dated the 23rd May, giving the price of different sizes of batteries which he recommends be operated with this unit. I am also submitting a detailed report, dated April 16th, in connection with this plant.

It would appear to be the opinion of both Mr. Montgomery and Mr. Fanning that the batteries supplied in January, 1933, were too small to carry the load in connection with this unit. There are no extra attachments being used in connection with the batteries. The report of Mumford, Medland Limited submitted by their Agent Mr. Montgomery gives very full information regarding the condition of the plant and it is unnecessary for me to repeat what he says. I am of the opinion that it would be advisable to have this firm do the work. I have not been able to find any mechanics.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
find any mechanics in this City who are familiar with the Lister Automatic unit.

With reference to your enquiry regarding the qualifications of the engineer in charge, I may say that I was not favorably impressed with him. I have made considerable enquiry in a quiet way. Before taking up the work at this school, this man was engaged for three years with the Regina Steam Laundry and from what I could gather he is quite a good steam engineer, but he has not shown and no one can tell me his experience in connection with electric lighting plants; and from the condition of his plant I would say that he is not qualified and inclined to be a careless operator. It is my opinion that he should be replaced.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

Mr. Inspector Murison, Regina, has furnished a report regarding the condition of the lighting plant at the Gordon's Indian Residential School (Gordon Reserve, No. 86 - Electoral District of Last Mountain). An expert of Mumford Medland, Limited, Winnipeg, who handle the Lister electric lighting units in use at the school, examined the equipment and submitted a detailed statement of the repairs required for the engine and in regard to the batteries. He states the present batteries are now practically useless and that they will require to be renewed.

Mr. Orr, Architect of this Department, recommends that a new battery, with a capacity of 240 ampere hours, be supplied, and also that Mumford Medland, Limited, who are agents for the Lister Company, be authorized to make the necessary repairs to the plant.

The cost of supplying the batteries will be approximately $750 and the repairs to the engine and dynamo, $265 - a total of, approximately, $1015. Funds can be provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education. I would request your authority for the expenditure and that Mumford Medland, Limited, Winnipeg, agents for the Lister Company, who supplied the present equipment, be authorized to make the necessary repairs to the plant. I shall be pleased to be advised, also, if the order for supplying the batteries, of the type mentioned above, may be placed with this firm or what other firms should be asked to quote.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Dear Sir;

I have the honor to enclose report on visit made to the Gordon Indian Residential School. I am at this place frequently but do not report each visit, but I keep in touch with conditions there all the time. The Inspector is handling the water and electric light plant situations so I am merely mentioning them to show I know what is needed as I see it.

The water plant is giving quite a lot of trouble and it seems that the pump is not able to do the work. The Principal went to a lot of expense on this job before he located what the trouble really was.

The electric light plant requires a lot of repairs and a new set of batteries. Mr. Morrison is getting all these I understand.

The water filter is giving trouble but the principal knows what is wrong and no doubt will attend to it.

The principal has kalsomined and painted the interior of the building from cellar to roof and is paying for material and labor. He asks the Department to allow him a grant of $125.00 to help pay for the material, he will pay all labor. The work would have cost much more than this and I told the principal he should have asked for the allotment before. However, if there are any funds on hand for this work I recommend he be compensated.

Mr. Frayling asks for linoleum covering for the sewing room, it is cement floor, the finish keeps wearing away and is dusty and uneven at present. The area is about 700 sq feet. He also requests that he be given a granary as there is none here, he asks for allotment of $250.00. He also asks for consideration of an amount of $50.00 to get material to make a flour warehouse inside the old hostel building here. All these items are necessary if funds are available.

The school has in a good garden and farm this year.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, June 29, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, reporting on a visit made to the Gordon Indian Residential School.

Regarding the Principal's request, that a granary be erected, at a cost of $250, I beg to refer you to your letter of April 14, 1934, enclosing a letter from the Principal, in which he requested that a galvanized bin, of medium size, be supplied. You also furnished a diagram of a portable corrugated granary, at a price of $116.00, f. o. b. Winnipeg. In view of this letter, the Department included, in the Estimates for the current fiscal year, the sum of $150, to purchase a granary of the type mentioned. You might advise if a portable corrugated granary would not be satisfactory for the needs of this school, or, if not, what other type of granary you would recommend.

The Department will approve of an expenditure, to an amount not exceeding $50.00, in the purchase of material to make a flour ware-house inside the old hostel building. It is understood the school authorities will perform the labour. Purchase should be made from a firm on the approved list and you should forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Mr. Inspector Murison has submitted a report regarding the condition of the lighting plant and the need of new batteries, at a total estimated cost of $1,175. The supplying of the batteries and the repairs to the engine and dynamos are receiving attention. In view of the fact that this is an unforeseen expenditure, no funds were specially provided for the purpose. I regret, therefore, that it will not be possible to reimburse the Principal for the cost of the kalsomine and paint used in the redecorating of the interior of the school building. The only way this could be done would be to utilize the funds provided for the supplying of a granary. If the Principal would rather have the accounts paid for the cost of the kalsomine and paint than the providing of the granary, you may forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly receipted, attached to vouchers, in favour of the Principal - when payment will be made.

With reference to the linoleum requested, please have the Principal state the type and quality and, if possible, the approximate cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

From information received by the Department, it is considered that the engineer at the Gordon's Indian Residential School has not sufficient experience to properly handle the electric lighting plant. If the lighting plant and the other mechanical equipment in a residential school are not in charge of a very competent person, trouble is caused the management and considerable expense is entailed both for the Department and the school.

Taking the above into consideration, I consider that it would be in the best interests of the Gordon's School to secure, at the earliest possible date, a new engineer who is capable of properly handling all the mechanical equipment in the school. I trust that you will cooperate with the Department in this regard.

Mr. Inspector Murison is being directed to visit the Gordon's School about the end of September with a view to interviewing the new engineer and reporting to the Department whether or not he is fully qualified for the very important work that is required of him.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Re: Engineer.

Replying to your letter of the 3rd instant regarding the above. Mr. W.J. Warner, engineer, is now on holiday. I have had occasion to speak of his seeming indifference to his work and in June gave him a month to apply himself more thoroughly or tender his resignation, since which time there has been a great improvement.

I procured this man through the Saskatchewan Government department Steam Boilers and Industrial Inspection, and he holds First Class papers for Boiler and Electrical work. On his return to the school I will forward you his credentials that you might know it was on the face of apparent ability I engaged him. I might add that there is a great difficulty in obtaining an all-round, or what I term an institutional, engineer. I will obtain the best possible for the position, but apparently this can only be proven after actual work, not by written Provincial examinations.

I might add that but for one set of batteries there has been no expense to the Lister Engines and plant since installed until latterly,
and they have been in daily use since 1930. Taking this fact into consideration the cost now entailed is what might be expected, and that the present and previous batteries were not of the right capacity.

Mr. Warner commenced his duties here on July 12th, 1935. Mr. G.F. Angel, our previous engineer, suffered a stroke and left for England with the assurance that when recovered he would be reinstated. I regret to say this will not happen.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Further as to my letter of the 6th inst.

On approaching Mr. Montgomery, expert of Mumford, Medland & Co., Winnipeg, who has recently installed new batteries etc., he says that Mr. Warner, our Engineer is a capable man and knows his work. (Warner assisted Montgomery with the installation and the overhauling of the Lister Engines.) Adding that having become accustomed to the duties here, knowing the machinery etc., and my having given him a good talk as to the cleanliness etc. etc., it might be well to give him further trial. Also that men are not easily obtained for the all round work called for in institutions such as this.

I am enclosing Mr. Warner's certificates for your inspection and will ask for the return of same with careful mailing.

I have gone into the matter thoroughly again with Mr. Warner and he rightly claims that were he not absolutely efficient he would not be granted the Diplomas issued by the Provincial Government, and has never had complaint from the Provincial Boiler Inspector who visits plants at least once every year, and he shows 19 years experience and that number of inspections. I consider that by retaining his services I shall not be jeopardizing the mechanical part of the School property.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report that quite a lot of equipment at Gordon Indian Residential School requires attention; the main trouble is caused by the water containing minerals which have eaten out the various parts of the plant, as well as filling others with hard sediment.

1. Some sections of the radiators are eaten out and leaking badly; this matter can be left over at present as they will last out the winter.

2. The water distribution system requires the following:
   - 3 doz pair nickel compression taps for basins.
   - 1 doz nickel compression taps for baths—hot & cold combined.
   - 2 doz 5 inch copper toilet floats.
   - 2 doz brass toilet float rods 12".

3. Boiler requires one 1 inch straight away valve on bottom of water column and one 1½ inch blow down valve for back of low pressure boiler.

4. Kitchen ranges require two complete tops for McClary Army Ranges; they are burnt out. (General Steel Wares).

5. Pipes for cooling Lister plant are filled up with sediment which cannot be removed and this fills up the tops of water jackets in the plant and causes a lot of expense each year. New pipes should be supplied for this part of the plant. (Midland Mumford, Winnipeg, Man.).

6. The filter here is made by International Filter Co of Chicago. The sand inside the filter requires changing; I understand it is quite a costly matter, however, you have probably the same plant elsewhere and may know more about it. In any case the refill should be supplied. The engineer says it is a job for an expert or the agent of the company to make this change.

7. The back of fire box on low pressure boiler is burnt out; the engineer says he could fix this if he is supplied with 300 lbs of fire proof cement called Plibrico; if you consider this correct it should be supplied. I never used it myself; the engineer is quite competent and says this is the right material. He says it might cost about $25.00. If this is not supplied you would have to get fire brick to make fire wall in Leonard low pressure boiler.

8. The upright boiler used for laundry etc requires retubing again; it will have to be taken to Regina when roads open up. This is another job that only lasts a year and a half with the water we have here. It is being plugged up in various spots now and is dangerous.

9. The jacket heater which was supplied a couple of years ago has corroded up again; this boiler supplies the hot water used throughout the whole building. It is now—

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6311, file 654-5, part 8)
It is now plugged up from the outside with an iron plate held on with pressure clamp and will not last much longer; the pressure to supply the water throughout the place must be about 50 lbs. This jacket heater does not appear to be suitable. I enclose circular from the Leonard people of what they think should be used. Something will have to be supplied in immediate future and you might consider using the sort described. If so the measurements given on the plan would be required.

I beg to recommend that all the above be given consideration as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

At the request of Mr. J. W. Waddy, Agent of Indian Affairs at Punnichy, I went over to the Gordon Indian Residential School and looked over the various plumbing and heating requirements. The list of these requirements is as follows,—

No. 1. Jacket Heater.

Since being at the school the jacket heater has gone out of commission entirely, so have wired you as follows,—
(Jacket heater out of commission. No hot water. Price of new unit complete same as old one. Installed $175.00. Other estimates following by mail. This is urgent. Please wire instructions to E.H. Carter, Yorkton.)

In reference to the steel tubeless heater as mentioned in No. 1. I may say this is not readily obtainable, and owing to the urgency of the situation, I quoted you as above, for the same size and make of heater.

Dear Sir:

I enclose four letters from the principal at the Gordon Indian Residential School asking for the following appropriations.

1. Garage for use of school car ---------------- $450.00.
Last fall a fire took place at this school and burnt up our garage and two school cars. The principal says he requires more storage room at the school, he used part of the other garage for storage. He says he will build a store house from school funds if the Department will authorize the $450.00 he wants for a garage. As the fire took place after the estimates went in for this year no funds were asked for this purpose. It was no fault of construction or of anyone but the school staff that the fire occurred, they put a coal stove in the garage and next time they visited the place the stove had got in its work first. They were looking for trouble in my opinion. I am not recommending this expenditure but can say the school needs a garage.

2. Renovation of principal's cottage ------------ $100.00.
When I get funds for renovating houses of the employees here we are quite satisfied if we get $50.00, we usually get $10.00 each annually, but as this place has not got the annual treatment I would be obliged if you would consider giving authority to spend up to $50.00. If so would it be suitable to get wall paper and other material from T.Eaton Co., Regina.

3. Battleship linoleum for sewing room floor. The cement here is all gone dusty from poor material in construction, it should be covered. See my letter LIA.C.E. July 10 1935 on this subject. The cost would be about $170.00. I got my figures at that time from T.Eaton Co., Regina who handle a lot of this sort of work. I recommend that it be supplied for sake of health of the pupils.

4. When I visited the school yesterday I checked up on this request which is for renovation of the outside of the school. Five places require a lot of brick replacement, at doors and windows. All outside window casings need paint.

over.
It is hard to figure cost of the work until I know how extensive a job the brick work is, we have to dig in and find out. I would think that the labor and mortar etc would amount to about $20.00. The painting of casings etc would amount to $100.00. The principal mentions inside decorations. Every year he has kilnformed the inside of the place from top to bottom out of material he bought from school funds. I think he should be allowed $100.00 of material, this is the first time in six years he has asked for anything in this line.

Your obedient servant,

State plainly the catalogue, name, number and rated capacity of Boiler required; also number of square feet of Direct and if any, Direct-Indirect or Hot Blast Radiation, that Boiler is to take care of.

It is well to mention all letters or numbers in order in which they appear on part required. In case it is impossible to give any of the above requirements, send a sketch having dimensions marked on it, and a detailed description of part wanted. It will also be well to mention year number where same appears on front of Boiler, and if possible, the year in which the Boiler was installed, or better still, the date and number of the invoice pertaining to it. Especially mention whether the boiler is Round or Square. Where Round, if it is a grate bar that is required, mention which one, numbering from the front, and whether it has a lug or hook on it. Where section is required for a Sectional Boiler, mention which one, numbering from the front, and whether same has any tapped openings, and the size of the tapping, and whether the tapping is required or not. Where it is a grate bar, mention which one, numbering from the front, and whether it shakes on the left-hand side or the right-hand side.

Dear Sir,

Re: Water Situation, Gordon's Residential School.

In accordance with the instructions contained in your wire of the 4th inst., I visited the above school on September 11th.

The general scheme of the water system for the school is as follows:- Water is pumped from a small lake (really a slough) by a small rotary pump, capacity approximately 2000 gallons per hour driven by a gasoline unit, to a storage tank at the school. The water is treated in this tank and is pumped from there to pressure tanks in the school by a small typhoon self-oiling displacement pump electrically driven, capacity 1000 gallons per hour.

The difficulty encountered is in the suction line of the small rotary pump. The lake has lowered approximately eighteen feet in the last six years and this present summer the level has dropped approximately four and one-half feet. The 3" suction hose had been carried out approximately forty feet into the lake, below frost action, and thence along the lake bottom. This line plugged up and is possibly broken. A temporary suction line has been installed at the edge of the lake but will not do during the winter.

In my opinion the actual suction line should not be continued out into the lake below frost action because of the difficulty encountered in repairing the valves and line.

I would recommend that a well with timber lining be constructed near the shore connected by a pipe to the lake (approximately eighty feet long laid below frost action) as the subsoil is yellow clay, which would not permit sufficient filtration even for the small demand required. The suction line of the pump would then be located in the well and accessible at all times. The well would have to be covered and protected from frost action as much as possible.

The Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.
It is essential that the pipe leading from the well to the lake be in at least eight feet of water so that in the event of another dry season or two the pipe will not have to be lowered. In the event of two more seasons as dry as the present one, I doubt if there will be enough water left to supply the school demand, which is approximately 5000 gallons per day.

I believe that the recommendation made above is the most satisfactory rather than to go to the expense of locating a deep well. This may be necessary in the event of continued drought but, should average rainfall occur in the next seasons, there will be sufficient water in the small lake to supply the needs of the school.

The following is an estimate of the cost of construction of the proposed well and pipe into the lake:

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| Pipe & Fittings       | $125.00|
| Lumber, etc.          | $130.00|
| Labour                | $175.00|
| Rental Equipment      | $30.00 |

Total: $460.00

The fact that the intake will have to be carried below frost line, necessitating cofferdamming, accounts for the relatively high cost of such a small job. It may be found that certain of the present intake pipe may be salvaged without incurring too much expense.

The other alternative of laying a new intake below frost action could be considered. However the difficulty encountered in reaching the intake in case of trouble does not warrant the slight saving that might be made.

As I have mentioned, the only other alternative would be to consider the drilling of a deep well as I understand there are no shallow wells in that vicinity. Should this be considered it would be necessary to have a geologist's report of that particular section. The well would have to be located reasonably close to the school and possibly the location of the pump house and discharge lines would have to be relocated. I understand from Mr. Waddy that the school location is almost on the line of Sections 10 and 11, Township 27, Range 17, West of the 2nd Meridian.
In regard to the estimate of the cost, the estimate for labour may be high should conditions prove better than anticipated. This particular type of work really requires a pile driver for the sheet piling but the job is too small to warrant such expense as there is no equipment of that kind in the vicinity.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) H. Dempster

Junior Engineer.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: Gordon's Residential School, Punnichy

With reference to the above project the following is quoted from a report received from Mr. Dempster.

"Work on this project was completed on November 19th consisting as follows:-

A well 4.5' x 4.5' x 10' was excavated and lined with two inch plank and braced. At an elevation of three feet above the bottom of the well sixty-five feet of 3" pipe let into the lake to a screened inlet. The end of the pipe is 2½ feet from the lake bottom and is subjected to a head of 4.5 feet of water. It was necessary to cofferdam approximately 45 feet in order to make the excavation and considerable difficulty was experienced in driving the sheet piling (made up of three pieces of 1" x 8" plank with 1¼" tongue and groove) as it had to be driven by hand and the lake bottom was exceptionally rocky, resulting in numerous leaks in the cofferdam. In order not to have to cofferdam the full 65 feet to lay the pipe two 45° elbows were used to allow the last length of pipe to be lowered after the back filling was completed. The pipe is back filled to a depth of eight feet, with a layer of hay near the pipe for added protection. The pipe from the lake to the well may be regulated by a 3" gate valve. The original idea was to have the pump take the water right from the well. However Mr. Field had considerable trouble with black muck seeping into the well and eventually had to connect the suction of the pump to the pipe leading into the lake. What really should have been done when the excavation revealed black muck was to make the lining of a construction similar to the sheet piling only with a 3" tongue and groove. However the system is operating satisfactorily and, if found necessary, the well..."
could be concrete lined at some future date. When it was found necessary to connect the suction clear through to the lake, the last length of pipe was swung up by means of the elbows and a float valve connected.

Owing to the severe frost conditions it was necessary to protect the temporary intake from freezing. This was not anticipated when my original estimate was prepared, also the amount of trouble experienced with the cofferdamming was not expected, hence the necessity of additional funds.

The well section itself has been adequately protected from frost.

The expenditure, with the exception of the pipe and fittings, is as follows:

Labour........ $327.04
Lumber........ 138.18
Nails, etc.... 5.38

$470.60

The question of how long the new intake will prove satisfactory depends on whether or not the drought season continues as there is no inlet or outlet to the lake.

There is a sizeable lake approximately three and a quarter miles away, from which water could be drained into the lake at the school and I had Field run a set of levels over and gather certain information, which I will forward in the near future in case the question of feasibility of locating a deep well or filling the lake by draining from this other lake comes up.*

From this report, it will be noted that considerable trouble was experienced in the work carried out. The system is now operating satisfactorily but owing to the size of the lake from which water is taken, Mr. Dempster seems to be doubtful as to whether the water supply question has been finally settled for this school. He has had certain surveys run with regard to the supplementing of water in the small lake from a larger lake 3½ miles away. When Mr. Dempster's report is received regarding the findings of these surveys, you will be advised.

Respectfully submitted,

(Sgd.) T. S. Mills.
December 15, 1937.

Regina, March 29th, 1928.

Dear Sir;-

I have received a letter from Mr. J. W. Waddy, Touchwood Agency, in which he states the need of extensive repairs to the water system at the Gordon Indian Residential School, owing to the fact that the whole water distribution system at the school is gradually filling up with deposit, and considerable of the parts being eaten away due to minerals in the water.

A detailed list of repair parts necessary is attached hereto marked Lot #1.

The small laundry boiler also needs retubing, also a safety valve 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" and pemberthy injector left hand 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" replaced. This is listed under Lot #2.

The main large heating low-pressure Leonard boiler - 64 tubes - needs retubing. The principal states the boiler has been in daily use for over 8 years without cost. Listed under Lot #3.

Lists #4 are flanges and plugs for pressure tanks and Lists #5 and 6 gaskets for filter manhole and hot water tank. Repairs are needed for Fairbank-Morse engine 6 H.P., Z type 713583 listed under Lot #7 and repairs for Fairbank-Morse 5 H.P. engine Z type "B" 770678 listed under Lot #8.

Repair parts are also needed for Lister engines 6\(\frac{1}{2}\)" and 14 H.P. as shown on List #9.

The...

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
The Principal also asks for a new 2½ gas engine for baking (Fairbank-Morse preferred) stating that the one at present is beyond repair. It dates from the time of the previous school. This is listed under Lot #10.

The Principal states that the McClary Famous Army kitchen cook range needs a complete new top to ovens and fire boxes and new fire bricks and that a new stove would not cost much more than repair parts and mechanic's wages and asks for a new stove. Listed as Lot #11.

100 lbs asbestos cement for covering hot water boiler recently installed is also required. Listed as Lot #12.

Regarding the new kitchen cook range asked for, there is a very good range in storage at the File Hills Agency, which was formerly in use at the Indian Hospital, Lorie. This would be quite suitable for use in the school and I would recommend that authority be granted to transfer the range to the Gordon school.

I have obtained the approximate cost of Lots #1, 2, 4, 5, 6 and 12 delivered to Punnichy, which is $1172.25. The Fairbank-Morse Company's price on Lots #7, 8 and 10 is $148.46 and for repairs to Lister engine - Lot #9 - approximately $37.00.

I did not obtain prices on the 64 tubes for the Leonard boiler or for the 36 tubes for the vatical laundry boiler as we do not appear to have any local firm on this list handling this class of work.

The work of replacing the parts listed in Lot #1 could be done by the engineer at the school but the re-tubing would have to be done by a qualified man.

The cost of the repairs, etc., for which I have obtained prices is around $1350.00 and there are still several items to be accounted for as well as the cost of labor installing. It appears necessary, however, to have this done and I would recommend that authority be granted to purchase the necessary repair parts and for the installation of the same.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo enclosing list of repairs etc. requested by the Principal of the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

It was found possible to include in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39 an amount of $500.00 for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Gordon's Indian Residential School. I regret that it is not possible to allow a larger amount.

Please let me know which request of the Principal you recommend should receive first consideration, keeping in mind the fact that only $500.00 is available.

The Department approves transferring to the Gordon's Indian Residential School the new kitchen range which is at present in storage at the File Hills Agency.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir;-

In further reference to boiler repairs to Gordon Indian Residential School, I beg to say that Mr. Carter came here today from Yorkton, Sask. to see about putting in the tubes in boilers that require them. He says it would be useless to put in the few tubes that have blown out, we have two of them and six more plugged now in the vertical boiler. If these are put in the others will blow out. Last week when the tube blew the steam just missed scalding the engineer, so I have told the principal to shut off the boiler altogether. I do not know how he will get on, but he will have to do the best he can for a few days.

To-day I took this matter up with the inspector again, he has your last letter saying not to exceed $50.00 without taking up the matter again with you, but he told me to write this letter direct to save time and to give an exact estimate, or as good as possible, of the proposed work.

Mr. Carter has given me figures and I have placed the estimate on the enclosed sheets. This is not exact to a dollar and is not a tender, but is very close to what total cost will be.

Will you please wire either the inspector or Mr. Carter of Yorkton on receipt of this letter so we can get the job done at once, it should have been done long ago as we have been taking chances on serious damage to the old engineer of the school.

A recommendation was made years ago for a water softener at this place, this would do away with all this boiler expense, but the matter was refused.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with reference to the bake oven supplied to the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

You will probably remember that at the time the Department was outfitting the Gordon's School there was considerable trouble in connection with the bake oven. Through some misunderstanding between the Department and General Steel Wares the No. 115 bake oven was first supplied and when it was found that this was not large enough a No. 2 Homestead oven was purchased. Both of these ovens were paid for by the Department and, therefore, both of them are our property.

There was some correspondence in 1931 with a view to having the No. 115 oven returned to General Steel Wares. However, this oven was used for a time and, therefore, could not be sold as a new oven. Apparently, no further action was taken toward disposing of it as I note from the last paragraph of your letter that it has been in your warehouse for some years.

Before we can dispose of it it will be necessary to obtain the approval of the Salvage Officer. I would, therefore, appreciate if you would let me know the exact length of time that this oven has been in storage, also its present condition. I also note that the traveller

Dear Sir;-

Re letter 121-1-5 of May 17th last regards bake oven 115, formerly supplied to Gordon Indian Residential School, I beg to say that this oven has been in store here since 1931. The condition of the oven is good, it was used and is smoked up slightly.

I think the General Steel Wares people would refuse to take it back for cash, one time I asked about this and was told that if we shipped it to head factory and paid out freight they might be able to do something about selling it if they got enquiries for a second hand oven. This meant putting out good money without any real chance of recovery, the company is in business to sell new goods and would certainly try to sell their own stuff first.

If the Ontario people are like they were when I was a boy they make their pies in the kitchen, this is the only pie oven I ever saw or heard of, but the salvage people may get a customer for it, they come in contact with so many people, but I would not pay freight on it myself.

I kept mum about this oven because it was such a mess of a job of purchasing I did not want to get tangled up in any correspondence about the deal, I was not responsible for the purchase. Now that all the officials concerned are gone, and do not care what happens, I can bring the matter to light and try to salvage something, before I get so old that I will be off the job myself.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

With reference to the water supply for the above school, which is at present being pumped from a small lake approximately 900 feet from the school, this lake is not fed by any creek or springs, although there are signs of a small drainage channel which might have carried a small quantity of water into the lake in years of normal rainfall.

In spite of the abundance of rainfall this year the lake is lower than before. The possible reason for this is that due to the past years of drought the sub-soil moisture is practically negligible, and will take the moisture for some time before allowing any run-off, (run-off being the only available way to raise the lake level).

The question of water supply for the school is confined to two alternatives - (1) Attempting to locate a deep well close to the school site, or, (2) Bringing water into present lake from Fort Lake, a distance of a little over 3 miles. The enclosed sketch (not to scale) shows the relative location of chains of sloughs, etc., from Fort Lake to Gordon's School. This sketch was made by G.B. Field from a compass survey.

In bringing water from Fort Lake 3 methods are possible:

1. By Pumping.
2. By Gravity Flow through 6" corrugated iron culvert controlled by flood gates at Fort Lake.
3. By excavating a ditch and controlling the flow through it by gates at Fort Lake.

The main objections to method 2 is the cost of excavation to get a suitable grade. This may be seen by glancing at the profile.

The objection to method 3 is that the excavation would be heavier than that required in method 2 (although no pipe would be bought) and that many of the flat areas such as from station 55-00 to 75-00 would of necessity flood before water could arrive at the lake at Gordon's School.

To my mind, should it be decided to bring water in from Fort Lake, the best method would be to erect a small pump house at the lake and run a surface line down to the school.

The demand of the school is very small, a maximum of approximately 6000 gallons per day, and an average daily demand of approximately 4000 gallons per day.

I believe, were a pump installed at Fort Lake, having a capacity of 10,000 gallons per hour, by operating it for three months in the summer season or longer if necessary, a minimum of 6,000,000 gallons could be pumped
into the lake at the school, and hence the lake could be kept at the desired level.

I believe the question of water supply for the school boils down to either attempting to locate a deep well, or pumping from Fort Lake.

It is impossible for me to estimate the cost of a deep well, as one might drill several places and not locate water, or water might be found with the first attempt. From information I gathered last year while at the school, there is absolutely no chance of locating any shallow wells.

The following is an estimate of the cost of pumping water from Fort Lake:

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| Erection of Pump House at Fort Lake       | $1,000.00 |
| Gasoline driven centrifugal pump          | 700.00 |
| 2" Pipe (approx. 18,500 feet)             | 6,600.00 |
| Freighting & installing pipe              | 700.00 |
| Concrete present well at school           | 100.00 |
| Clearing tote road to Fort Lake           | 200.00 |
| Valves, drainage cocks, etc.              | 75.00 |
| Material for pipe trestles                | 100.00 |
| Contingencies                             | 525.00 |

$10,000.00

Two inch pipe is recommended because the spread in price (wholesale) between 2" and 3" pipe is nearly 40¢ a foot, and it is more economical to use the 2" and increase the horse power of the pumping unit rather than use a small unit and a larger pipe.

The fact that there are no facilities of any description at Punnichy, and the school is several miles away, greatly increases the cost of any work. All material will have to be freighted by truck to the school, and from there to the job, by team.

The enclosed sketch plan is not to scale, and the chainage on the profile is only paced. However, the levels were run by Mr. Field, and I have every reason to believe them accurate. The various sloughs, etc. shown, could not be counted on to be used to pump water, and Fort Lake is the only lake to supply such water.

In the event of a decision being made to pump water from Fort Lake, a more accurate survey will have to be made, and sounding, etc. taken over Fort Lake.

Dear Sir:

I beg to attach Requisition for repairs necessary for repairing the two gasoline engines at the Gordon Residential School.

I find that they have two engines for the operation of the lighting plant, one 2½ horsepower and the other 6 horsepower. The 2½ horsepower engine is now out of commission and the other is liable to go out any time if the repairs are not supplied. This would leave the school without any light. It has been the practice at this school to use the 2½ horsepower engine during light-load hours, using the 6 horsepower only when a heavy load was on. This made a considerable saving in the amount of gasoline and oil consumed. At the present time they have to use the 6 horsepower altogether.

These parts can be obtained only from the Hammond, Medland, of Winnipeg. If the parts are supplied the engineer of the school can install them. In checking over this school and buildings I find that the school itself has been whitewashed and painted from top to bottom each year. The buildings have been kept in a splendid state of repair. The Principal has expended over $1000.00 from the school funds on repairs to outside buildings in the last three years, in addition to considerable work in repairs to machinery and piping on the inside. The water used for the school is very hard on the boilers and water pipes, demanding continual attention and repairs. A stock of connections and piping should be carried at this school in order that the engineer would be able to make the necessary repairs immediately the trouble develops, otherwise a heavy plumbing bill will be necessary in the near future.

Mr. Waddy has placed $1,000.00 in his Estimates for the school this year. In this amount is an allowance for those connections, etc.

Mr. Freyling is to be congratulated on the condition of the school and buildings and the amount of work he has done from school funds which otherwise would have been a charge against the Department.

I would recommend that this Requisition be allowed if at all possible, as otherwise the lighting plant will be put out of business.

Dear Sir,

Re: SCHOOL WATER SUPPLY.

After an inspection of the water supply at the Gordon School I find the following conditions:

The small lake east of the school from which all water is pumped covers an area of about thirty-five acres, and from numerous soundings taken appears to have a fairly uniform depth of twelve feet; although several spots showed thirteen to thirteen and a half feet. The bottom shelves rapidly and at forty or fifty feet from the shore line this maximum depth is found. This area of water gives 8,447,000 gallons per foot of depth. At your present rate of consumption, 4,000 gallons per day, 35 acre feet of water is enough for six years.

Of course there is the loss by evaporation which has been very marked during the past ten years. Since the school was built in 1922 the vertical drop in the surface of the lake has been about ten feet, but the water pumped in that time would not account for more than three feet of this assuming an annual consumption of 1,500,000 gallons. With a return of wet years the annual rainfall will naturally more than take care of the water used plus evaporation.

At the present time a 3" intake pipe runs out into the lake and water is pumped direct to the school, but with the falling level this pipe is now only four feet below the surface and very near the danger line from frost. You can see the advantage of doing away with this and having the pipe run well underground to a reservoir or well which would be accessible at all seasons.
R. W. Frayling Esq.

Re: Water supply, Gordon's Residential School, Punnichy, Sask.

Jackson, Secretary and Chief Executive Assistant, also the officials of this Branch and was definitely advised that immediate action would be taken to improve the water supply at the Gordon's School.
As you can realize the question of the cost of improving the water system is a most important one to this Branch, especially in view of the fact that no funds were specifically provided for this purpose in the current year's appropriation and any expenditure that is made will mean that disbursements at other Indian Residential Schools will have to be curtailed. It is for this reason that I am suggesting in the first part of this memorandum a joint interview as it might result in arranging for the installation of a water supply at a much less cost than Mr. Dempster's original estimate about which you wrote me in your memorandum of August 23.

I might add that Archdeacon Irwin was definitely of the opinion that unless water could be immediately secured in conformity with the plan submitted by Mr. Dempster or Mr. Swan the school would have to be closed and the children returned to the Reserve.

REPORT RE WATER SUPPLY

Gordon's Residential School, Punnichy,
Saskatchewan.

With reference to the water supply for the above school, the area of the lake from which the water is taken is approximately twenty-four acres as compared to thirty-five acres mentioned by Mr. M. Swan. The enclosed plan shows the traverse of the lake and also the profile of the lake bottom taken by Mr. Lazorka. You will note that Mr. Swan states that a depth of twelve feet is found at forty or fifty feet from the shore line. From Mr. Lazorka's soundings it can be seen that a depth of twelve feet is reached at a distance of one hundred feet from the shore.

With reference to the suggestion made by Mr. Swan to filter the water through a gravel and stone gallery to the well, there is no doubt that if it would work the water would certainly be improved. However I am afraid that the black muddy bottom would eventually plug up the sand (how long this would take I have no idea) and affect the flow through the porous gallery.

It would certainly be advantageous if the water could be filtered somewhat as it is very poor and, according to the Principal, even with the pressure filters in the school itself small particles are present.

To my mind there are two alternatives:

1. Construct a concrete well with approximately 200 feet of 5" inlet pipe (flexible joints to permit laying from surface of lake). The end of the pipe would have a clearance of 3.0 feet above the lake bottom and would be subjected to a head of approximately 10 feet of water (see sketch). A well of approximately the size mentioned by Mr. Swan, 7' x 7' would have sufficient capacity to permit a certain amount of settling of the solid particles. A valve would be installed to permit the dewatering of the well so cleaning of sediment can be done.

The pipe sections above the lake bottom would be supported by cable suspended from piles driven well into the lake bottom. A small catwalk of timber would be placed upon the piling to permit the raising of the end of the flexible jointed pipe should it prove necessary to clean the screen at any time.

From the profile it may be seen that it is not necessary to carry the pipe any further than 130 feet from the shore line. However an additional 40 feet is suggested in order to allow hoisting of the flexible pipe. I have written for information regarding the maximum attainable angle of flexibility of two types of this pipe and, should it be found that a shorter length of pipe would suit, it would be used.

2. The suggestion made by Mr. Swan could be carried out at an increased cost due to the fact that his soundings were evidently in error. Also the 6" concrete well shown on his sketch would certainly not be sufficient to withstand the semifluid pressure due to the type of earth and water existing at the site.

As I have already mentioned, I would be afraid of the black mud bottom settling in and plugging the sand filter bed. In order to cope with this I would suggest that, while the cofferdamming is being done and the gravel and stone being laid, a pipe line as suggested in No. 1 above be installed as a precautionary measure against the plugging of the sand filter. The additional cost of this would be only the cost of the pipe and valve plus the labour of laying the pipe as the cofferdam work would have to be carried out in order to construct the gallery.

The main disadvantage of this would be the inability to bail out the well to permit cleaning. However this could be overcome by having two separate chambers to the well, one for Mr. Swan's proposal and the other containing the 5" pipe line inlet.

Below is a cost estimate of the two proposals:

**Estimate of Cost, Proposal No. 1**

- 7' x 7' x 16' Concrete Well $540.00
- 12" reinforced wall
- 5" flexible joint pipe, valve and fittings $400.00
- Cofferdam work including excavation $660.00
- Laying of pipe and constructing catwalk $150.00
- Contingencies $50.00

Total . . . . . . $1800.00

**Estimate of Cost, Proposal No. 2**

- Concrete well, 4' x 10' x 18' (with two chambers) $650.00
- 5" flexible joint pipe, valves & fittings $400.00
- Laying pipe and catwalk construction $150.00
- Cofferdam work & excavation $1000.00
- 150 c.yds. of graded rock and sand fill to a depth of 10 ft. below water level at $3.00 per yard in place $450.00
- Contingencies $200.00

Total . . . . . . $2250.00

Owing to the uncertainty of cofferdam work, it is necessary to be on the safe side in estimating and I believe the above figures are such. If no great difficulties were encountered, the work might be done for somewhat less than the figures above. Should the Department see its way clear to provide funds for Proposal No. 2, I believe it should be tried. However I would not guarantee the effectiveness over a long period of years of the gravel gallery.

According to the area calculated by Mr. Lazare of twenty-four acres, this gives a figure of approximately 8,790,000 gallons of water per foot of depth. This, of course, does not take into account the recession of the shore line. Also, in spite of the exceptionally wet year, the water in the lake has lowered a foot. I believe that,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6311, file 654-5, part 8)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
due to the condition of the subsoil, it will take at least three or four years of good rainfall to put the ground water table back to its normal level and hence until it reaches that level very little runoff can be expected. At the present rate of lowering, during a four year period the water will have receded four feet and by that time, if such thing happens, it may be necessary to look elsewhere for water to replenish the lake; if dry years occur, it may be necessary much sooner.

As far as the two proposals are concerned, No. 1 will provide ample water and is less expensive than No. 2. However the filtering of the water in by method No. 2 would be very useful providing (as I have already mentioned) that the black mucky bottom does not plug up the filter bed. Of course this still would not leave the school without water but would only mean the money spent on this part was wasted. If the Indian Affairs Branch have sufficient funds to permit method No. 2 being carried out, I would suggest it be tried out; if not, then method No. 1 should be used.

The water is so bad in the lake that the pipes corrode up and hence I have suggested a 5" line to the lake, not that it is required for the quantity of water but rather to safeguard against the plugging up of the line.

With reference to the work, there is no immediate danger of the present pipe freezing, providing the new work is completed before the end of January. There is only three feet of water over the present pipe and, should there be a very cold winter, the suction line would certainly be endangered.

It is also essential that some reputable firm be given the work either on a cost plus basis or by contract. Possibly by contract would be the most satisfactory as far as cost is concerned because in connection with the driving of sheet piling I recall Mr. Field mentioning that considerable boulders were encountered. The work could be most economically carried out once the ice is off the lake to withstand the weight of any equipment such as piledrivers, etc. that might be required although the work on the well itself could be done any time and the cost of concrete would be less than if winter precautions had to be taken.

As soon as a decision has been made as to which proposal is to be used, if you will notify me I will prepare more detailed plans and figures such as would be required for contract work. The prices on the flexible pipe are only approximate as the correct figures have not been received from the company.

It will be noted from this report that in Mr. Dempster's opinion the suggestion made by Mr. Swan could be carried out at an increased cost, this increased cost being due to the fact that Mr. Swan's lake surroundings were evidently in error. Also Mr. Dempster is of the opinion that the 6" concrete well proposed by Mr. Swan would not be sufficient, and should be made stronger to withstand the semi-fluid pressure due to the type of earth and water existing at the site.

Another point that Mr. Dempster is very doubtful of is the permanency of results that might be obtained from endeavouring to send filter the water. He is of the opinion that owing to the quantity and nature of the matter held in suspension in this lake water, that a sand filter would soon become clogged and useless. Mr. Dempster suggests two schemes, one at an estimated cost of $1800.00 and the other at an estimated cost of $2250.00. The only difference between these two proposals is that the latter one would try out the sand filtering scheme and if found feasible same could be continued. However, if a failure then the scheme would operate as Proposal No. 1.

Under the circumstances it is recommended that if the Indian Affairs Branch wish to have anything done at this point they should be requested to provide funds for Proposal No. 2, namely, $2250.00. For the additional $450.00 over Proposal No. 1, it is felt that it will be well worth while to try the sand filtering idea.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,

Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Waddy, Agent, Touchwood Agency, which reads as follows:

"I have the honor to report that the batteries at the Gordon Indian Residential School, used in the lighting plant, are out of commission. These were supplied in September 1935, see your file 312-11A C.E. of 9th Sept. 1935. They cost then the following:
Batteries less discount and allowance 577.58

Expert's expenses for installation 11.00
$632.73

"I have got a quotation, which is enclosed, from A. Shaw of Lestock, agent for Globelite for new set of 56--252 ampere hour capacity batteries installed: $636.00

"The batteries are urgently required."

When at Gordon's School this summer, Mr. Waddy drew my attention to the fact that these batteries were going down. We discussed the matter with the engineer, and while he stated they were going down, the feeling was that they might carry through for the year. Since then they have had Mr. Shaw of Lestock go over the batteries to see if removing the sediment and bringing the electrolyte up to the proper density would not make them continue to give service. Mr. Shaw's report is attached. In his opinion this cannot be done. Mr. Shaw has submitted prices on two different batteries, one of 168 Ampere Hour capacity for $418.00 and one of 252 Ampere Hour for $636.00, and strongly recommends that the heavier battery be installed.

I am attaching with Mr. Shaw's report, his quotations and Touchwood Agency Requisition for batteries.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the batteries at the Gordon's Indian Residential School. I also note the report from Mr. Shaw who quotes a price on new batteries.

No funds were specifically provided in the current year's appropriation for batteries for this school and in addition we have found it necessary, owing to the water situation, to expend a great deal more at this school than we anticipated at the time of the preparation of the estimates. Our funds for the current fiscal year are practically assigned and if it is found necessary to supply new batteries at the Gordon's School it will mean that some other school will have to be deprived of something required.

I should appreciate it, therefore, if you would request Mr. Waddy to consult the engineer at the school again with a view to ascertaining if he can make the batteries last for another year. I note that the present set of batteries was only supplied in 1935 and it is felt that with careful supervision it should not be necessary to renew them at the present time.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Waddy writes that the Poorman's Band are asking that there be erected, at the Gordon's School, a shed for horses and a shack for the people who visit the school to see their children. He states that so far as the Principal is concerned, there is little chance of him putting up shelters, as aside from the cost, he feels it upsets the pupils to have their parents hanging around.

The erection of such a building would no doubt be of considerable benefit to both the horses and the people, but if not under complete control, it would prove a nuisance. Lebret School has, in my opinion, the best system in this respect that I have met with, but there the Indians provide their own food and fodder, and are only allowed to remain, I think it is 24 hours.

With regard to this request, if it is favourably considered, I think the Band should be required to do the work themselves and pay for any material required out of their own Band Funds.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant with reference to erecting at the Gordon's school a shed for horses and a shack for the people who visit the school to see their children.

If such a building were erected I know you will agree with me that it would have to be kept under very close supervision. This would hardly be possible if the building were erected from Band funds as the Indians would probably consider that they had special privileges when they had provided the cost of the building.

Taking everything into consideration I feel that it is inadvisable to consider the erection of such a building at the Gordon's school at the present time.

Yours truly,

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Waddy, Touchwood Agency, advising that the stucco on the exterior of the Farming Instructor's house at the Gordon Indian Residential School is in bad shape, a lot of it being off altogether, and the covering coat is crumbling and should be repaired.

He states the plasterer there is Mr. W. R. Johnstone, who is on the approved list. Mr. Johnstone is asking $20.00 for labour. He would also supply the necessary gravel for $2.50, water for the job at $1.25; and cement from the N.A.L. company there would be (8 sacks) $9.60. This makes a total of $33.35.

The above work would include taking off all loose stuff from wall, repairing all bare spots, and refinishing with pebble dash.

Mr. Waddy says that the work should be done if funds are available. There is no doubt this work is necessary. I would, however, draw attention to the abominable, I might say criminal, condition that exists, when after spending millions of dollars in educating and establishing the Indians, our Agents and School Principals have to employ white labour to do work which the Indians should have been taught to do themselves. The Indians protest against this condition and are quite justified in doing so. I now think it is time for the Department to take a firm stand and notify both our Agents and our Principals that all future work of this kind must be done by the Indians. If they have no Indians competent to do this work, it is up to them to teach the Indians to do so, and I have no hesitation in saying that there are men on the Reserve who can do it.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Reference your 121-1-5 of Sept. 20th.

Attached account of W. H. McDiarmid.

This account is in connection with the work done at the Gordon School last year for the purpose of securing a water supply. This work was handled by the engineering department through their engineer Mr. Harry Demster of the Prince Albert National Park. The contract was on a cost plus basis but owing to the snow coming before the work was completed it was impossible to return the equipment to Regina until this spring.

Mr. Demster informed me at one time during the winter that McDiarmid in his opinion was asking an excessive price for the return of the equipment and that he was trying to get him to cut it down. Some time this last spring the Engineers Office at Prince Albert National Park called me by phone and asked me to secure prices from some of the local cartage people on moving this equipment back to Regina. I called Mr. Waddy by phone and asked him if there were any cartage people there who could move this equipment and if so to secure prices. I did this as I considered we could get a better price from a man at Punnichy than we could from local concerns as they would no doubt use Indian labor where the Regina people would take their van from Regina. Mr. Waddy agreed to do this but, about an hour later informed me that the goods had already been taken away and I notified the engineers at Prince Albert of this fact.
